<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="topic-1-overview-of-the-course">TOPIC 1: Overview of the Course<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#topic-1-overview-of-the-course" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="general-over-view-of-civil-procedure">GENERAL OVER VIEW OF CIVIL PROCEDURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#general-over-view-of-civil-procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="what-is-civil-procedure">WHAT IS CIVIL PROCEDURE?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-is-civil-procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Consider the following scenarios to understand how a civil procedure arises</p>
<ol>
<li>You want to ensure that you understand the cause of action displayed in the facts the client presents to you. What is the cause of action established by the facts.</li>
<li>Who is the Plaintiff or Plaintiffs</li>
<li>Where do I file my case in which court?</li>
<li>What remedy does my client have or ought to get.</li>
<li>Actual drafting of the pleadings (I am saying this because this will depend on the cause of action established in the facts) Once the pleading is ready and drafted properly</li>
<li>File the pleadings</li>
<li>Preparation of summons, get them signed and paid for, served. This is catered for in the Civil procedure rules.</li>
<li>The defendant who has been properly served may choose not to defend either of the free will or because of the oversight. If the defendant is served and he chose not to defend the action and not to file an appearance and you will be seeking judgment in default of appearance or it may be judgment in default of defense if it is not filed as much as there was filed appearance.</li>
<li>Then there could be an interlocutory or final judgment in default of either.</li>
<li>If the defense is filed and served on time then you as the Plaintiff's advocate must make a decision whether you can bring the suit to an end and the decision will depend on the cause of action. Under Order 35 you can go to court and apply for summary judgment however it does not occur in all cases but in some cases. If you make such a decision you will ask for Orders under the provisions of Order 35. You look at the defense and think whether the defense actually constitutes the defense and if it is not then you look at the provisions of the rule 13 of Order 6 the effect of both is to terminate proceedings. If you think you cannot succeed under both Order you can demand further particulars, matters clarified to enable you to determine next cause of action. This is done to expedite trial and cut the costs of the cause. If you are acting for the Plaintiff there is a risk that the subject matter may be at risk and therefore it is necessary to move the court to preserve the subject matter of litigation pending the trial. You do not want judgment at that place all you are interested in preservation of the subject matter of the suit and then you have to file an injunction and there are various types of injunctions. You may even got under the provisions of Order 38 which is similar to mareva injunction but there is a clear distinction. There are various types of interlocutory applications and it is important to determine which application you have to make. Once you through with interlocutory proceedings assuming that you have not brought the suit to an end but expedited the proceedings. You have to prepare your suit for trial and you have to fix the suit for trial and summon witness to give evidence in your favor and you will be interested in procedure of adjournment the suit. Assuming you have dealt</li>
</ol>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>with these steps and the suit came for trial you will be interested in knowing who has the right to begin.</p>
<ol start="11">
<li>
<p>Under the Civil Procedure Rules there are times when the Defendant must begin, where the defendant says that on the Plaintiff is not entitled to the relief he is seeking or on the point of law. This will depend on the pleadings that you have filed and the facts contained in the pleadings</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Whichever party commences giving evidence it is always wise to make a statement of what it is you cause of action is and you call your witnesses in the order you prefer and you allow them to be cross-examined and then re-examined and the other party will go through the same motion. The only time the sequence changes if the witness turns hostile and then the lawyer will have to establish that the witness is not a reliable person and the evidence be destroyed. In terms of giving evidence it is good to have an understanding with the witnesses before you got court and envisage the kind of cross-examination that may occur.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The court will then deliver judgment. The judgment must give reasons and be signed and read. Once the judgment is written, there is a procedure of extracting the decree, because it is the decree that allows you to execute and enforce it. There are steps which are very important to be followed to execute a judgment. Meaning that you take steps to convert the decree to the benefit to your client. You must apply for the decree to be executed, the only consolation that the decree does not go old. What mode of execution you want to adopt will depend on the decree you have – either attachment of property or winding up. Execution proceedings are important. There are difference modes of execution decrees and you have to know what will happen if there is an objection to execution, or where there is a property which you think belongs to the defendant but it is not in the hands of the defendant. A lot of times many other proceedings may take place before actual execution even when there is a decree in your client's favor.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>One may even be appealing against the decree or order and that will be an application for stay of decree or execution. If you are applying under the Order 45 then you have to prepare memorandum of appeal, but the procedure is different when you want to set aside a judgement.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Costs. If the judgement is tendered in default of appearance and defence that means you have to execute and a certificate of costs issued by the Registrar. You must file a bill of costs for taxation and once it is taxed that enables you to apply for the execution. This is appealable.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Judicial Review is provided under Order 53 of the Civil Procedure Rules and is within civil procedure it should not stand on its own.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="civil-law">CIVIL LAW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#civil-law" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Civil law may be described as the branch of law that regulates the relations between private individuals by enforcing obligations or compensating injured parties.</li>
<li>If a person's private rights are violated, the person has a cause of action. #</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>Causes of action are recognized by statutes. Customary law and by the common law. The person whose rights have been allegedly violated sues the alleged wrong doer.</li>
<li>Hence civil cases are styled as Plaintiff v Defendant. It is his duty of the plaintiff to adduce evidence to prove his case the burden of proof lies on the plaintiff.</li>
<li>The standard of proof in civil cases is on a balance of probabilities or on a preponderance of probabilities.</li>
<li>It must be more probable than improbable that the plaintiff's allegations are true. If the plaintiff discharges the burden of proof then he wins the case and is awarded judgment.</li>
<li>The relief's or remedies for one who has judgment in favour could take any of the following forms:</li>
</ul>
<p>(a) Damage, i.e. monetary compensation
(b) Injunction
(c) Specific performance
(d) Tracing
(e) Accounts
(f) Rescission
(g) Winding up/liquidation</p>
<ul>
<li>The aim or objective of civil law is</li>
</ul>
<p>i. First to protect rights and enforcement of duties;
ii. Secondly to provide legal remedies as and when a person's rights have been violated. There are however a host of wrongs which may give rise to criminal as well as civil liability. Example, if one drives and causes harm; he can be prosecuted by the state for dangerous driving at Criminal law and also by the injured person for careless and negligent driving at Civil law. Other examples assault and battery and defamation cases.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="what-is-civil-litigation">What is Civil Litigation?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-is-civil-litigation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Civil litigation is a process of making or defending or resisting a claim form the beginning up to its successful end by the enforcement of a judgment, if it is made.</li>
<li>The objective is to:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Ensure that ultimately there is a just determination of the case taken to court. Your documents and presentation before the court should therefore ensure this end is realized.</li>
<li>The determination will be efficient. There must be an efficient determination of the matter. There must be an efficient use of the available judicial and administrative resources.</li>
<li>The matter at hand must be disposed of in a timely manner. (expeditiously) This should be at an affordable or reasonable cost to the parties.</li>
<li>Proper application of proper technology at the proper time.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>There two types of laws procedural and substantive law</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="civil-procedure-as-procedural-law">Civil Procedure as Procedural Law<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#civil-procedure-as-procedural-law" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>PROCEDURAL LAW Procedural law consists of the rules which determine the manner in which the court proceedings are required to be conducted.</li>
<li>This law guides how a right is prosecuted under the criminal justice. It therefore aims to provide the rules of procedure or steps to be followed at law.</li>
<li>These procedures are not arbitrarily fixed by law but have evolved over a very long period of time on the basis of experience.</li>
<li>The bulk of the rules which constitutes the procedural law of Kenya are contained in the Civil Procedure Act, Criminal Procedure Act, Law of Evidence, Registered Land Act etc.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="difference-between-civil-and-criminal-law">Difference between Civil and Criminal Law<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#difference-between-civil-and-criminal-law" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>One of the biggest mistakes students make is to confuse the terms in criminal procedure and the terms used in civil procedure e.g. referring to the parties as the accused.</li>
<li>There are no accused persons in civil procedure and such mistakes will lead to no marks in an examination situation.</li>
<li>It is therefore important to differentiate the difference between civil law and criminal law for avoidance of doubt and confusion.</li>
<li>The table below illustrates civil and criminal law and by extension the two set of procedures</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th>CIVIL WRONG</th><th>CRIMINAL WRONG</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>• It is a private wrong against an individual</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Parties are the plaintiff and the defendant OR Applicant and Respondent</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Parties are free and are encouraged to compromise in any trial and even withdraw the case.</td><td>• It is public wrong against the state</td></tr><tr><td>• -Parties are the prosecution/state and the accused</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>• Action cannot be compromised since the state is the complainant unless in exceptional cases by the prosecutor applying to withdraw the case.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>|  • Plaintiff needs to prove his case on “balance of probability”. The evidence must be such that it is more probable than not.
• Objective is to restore the injured party to the original position before the wrong.
• The relief is usually by compensation, restitution, injunction etc.
• The suit is heard through civil procedure | • Burden of proof must be beyond reasonable doubt. Every person is therefore presumed innocent until proved guilty beyond reasonable doubt.
• Objective is to punish wrong-doers.
• Remedy is usually by imprisonment or fine or death penalty in the case of capital offences
• Cases are heard through criminal procedure  |
| --- | --- |</p>
<ul>
<li>Basically civil procedure deals with the court procedures and rules to be observed when a plaint is filled or originating summons till a judge enforces a judgment or an appeal is filed.</li>
<li>When an appeal is filed then the Supreme Court Act or The Appellate Court Act (Cap 29) is then followed or used.</li>
<li>Civil Procedure in Kenya is regulated by the Civil Procedure Act Cap 21.</li>
<li>We also have Civil Procedure Rules 2010 which gives further guidance.</li>
<li>Civil Procedure can be described as or is the body of rules that set out the rules and standards that the courts will follow when adjudicating civil cases.</li>
<li>Hence they</li>
<li>They govern how a case may commence.</li>
<li>Govern how opposite parties are to serve each other with pleadings and filed in court.</li>
<li>Govern the types of pleadings and applications that may be filed.</li>
<li>Govern the orders that the court may give.</li>
<li>Govern such matters as discovery of documents and sharing of the same.</li>
<li>Govern what derogatory may be served on a party to clarify the issues of controversy.</li>
<li>Govern how the hearing or the trial is to be conducted.</li>
<li>Govern the process of judgment and remedies available or how judgment may be enforced (decree or execution arising from a judgment).</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>Govern how the court or the parties are to conduct themselves.</li>
<li>In case of ADR the rules are fairly simple and parties can agree on their own set of procedures.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="history-of-civil-procedure-in-kenya">HISTORY OF CIVIL PROCEDURE IN KENYA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history-of-civil-procedure-in-kenya" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>In 1844 the colonial government borrowed the Indian Civil Procedure Code (Adhoc).</li>
<li>Until the colonial government took over the protectorate in 1895, the British Government directed that to be enacted a criminal and civil procedure.</li>
<li>In 1897 the East African order in Council comes into force. A protectorate court was created presided by judicial officer who was to apply the English Procedure (But actually continued to apply the Indian Civil Procedure Code).</li>
<li>It was not until 1913 that the then Chief Justice Hamilton (Of the Hamilton Mathew and Harris Law Firm fame) completed the first draft of the civil procedure code for the East African Protectorate based on the Indian Civil Procedure Code 1908.</li>
<li>CJ Hamilton then revised it in 1916.</li>
<li>But it was in 1924 that the core code was enacted as Ordinance No.3 without rules of procedure (Just the substantive Act). They also agreed that the rules will be made by a rules committee.</li>
<li>In 1927 the rules were made based on English procedure.</li>
<li>In 1927 October we had Civil Procedure and Rules.</li>
<li>The Acts and Rules as originally enacted have remained the same at least in letter and spirit, with various amendments to keep them in line with the English Rules.</li>
<li>The most comprehensive and recent are the revised rules Civil Procedure Rules 2010, which were gazetted and came effective on 17th September 2010 (have greatly borrowed from the United State practice e.g. Order 11 of the Pre-trial conference which is aimed at narrowing the disputes or they can negotiate).</li>
<li>The rules apply uniformly to all courts but the court of appeal is also guided by the Court of Appeal rules under the Appellate Jurisdiction Act and is expected that the Supreme Court will also be guided by some Supreme Court rules.</li>
<li>Under the Judicature Act and Magistrate Court the CJ is empowered to make rules of court relating to procedure and practice of subordinate courts. However no such rules have ever been made, lower courts and the High Court continue to apply the Civil Procedure as originally passed and amended.</li>
<li>The bulk of the rules apply to civil proceedings only and does not include other special proceedings. Rules can apply expressly if a certain Act so provides like in the Rent Restrictions Tribunal Act.</li>
<li>The rules are practical in the sense that they have been tested and applied.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sources-of-civil-procedure">SOURCES OF CIVIL PROCEDURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sources-of-civil-procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>There are three types sources</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Historical Sources - Tracing the history of the statute to see how it evolved over a particular period of time and how it developed</li>
</ol>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Material Sources- Concerned with physical source or repository where one can find law</li>
<li>Formal Sources- From which a rule of law derives its validity.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>When we are talking about sources of CP we are concerned with the physical repositories where one can find civil procedure and the sources from where the law of procedure derives its force and validity.
In a nut shell the sources are
i. Constitution
ii. Statute
iii. Rules of courts
iv. Case law.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-constitution-as-a-source-of-civil-procedure">THE CONSTITUTION AS A SOURCE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-constitution-as-a-source-of-civil-procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>It is the founding end from which all other laws, whether substantive or procedural, flow.</li>
<li>Article 2 of the 2010 constitution states this principle in these terms; 'This Constitution is the supreme law of the Republic and binds all persons and all State organs at both levels of government.'</li>
<li>Article 2(4) goes on to specifically pronounce the constitution's supremacy in relation to other laws. It states that 'Any law, including customary law that is inconsistent with this Constitution is void to the extent of the inconsistency, and any act or omission in contravention of this Constitution is invalid.'</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="statute-as-a-source-of-civil-procedure">STATUTE AS A SOURCE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#statute-as-a-source-of-civil-procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Statute law -we are concerned with the Civil Procedure Act Cap 21.</li>
<li>Sometimes it is assumed that anything non-criminal is civil and this is not correct. The Civil Procedure Act is basically concerned with cases of a civil nature in the court and their procedure.</li>
<li>We exclude procedures which are stated as having specific statutes granting specific procedures to be followed.</li>
<li>Winding up of a company has the winding rules and this is therefore excluded from civil procedure.</li>
<li>Matrimonial Causes Act also prescribes procedures for proceeding under this Act.</li>
<li>Contentious Probate matters are catered for under the Law of Succession Act and therefore excluded.</li>
<li>Therefore, where you have an Act of Parliament granting specific jurisdiction and prescribing procedure, then that is the procedure to be followed unless the Act itself states that the Civil Procedure Act and the Rules made thereunder are to be followed.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>The Civil Procedures Act (CAP 21 Laws of Kenya) creates jurisdiction in general terms, it is divided into 11 parts each containing sections which make provisions for particular subjects.</li>
<li>One very interesting feature of this legislation is the internal explanatory notes. It has marginal notes in respect of some of the Sections. Section 6 for example has explanatory notes on stay of suit, Section 7 on Res Judicata, Section 14 has notes on suits for compensation and Section 15 has illustrations on where to sue. This is not now common in legislative draftsman-ship.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="rules-as-source-of-civil-procedure">RULES AS SOURCE OF CIVIL PROCEDURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rules-as-source-of-civil-procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>S.2 of the CPA states that ‘unless the context otherwise requires- “Act” includes rules.’ The rules are defined by the same section to mean ‘rules and forms made by the Rules Committee to regulate the procedure of courts.’</li>
<li>The CPR are made by the Rules Committee composed of – two judges of the High Court, two judges of the Court of Appeal, the Attorney General and two advocates – one nominated by the LSK and one nominated by the Mombasa Law Society.</li>
<li>Their authority derives from Section 81 (1) of the Act. It provides that “There shall be a Rules Committee consisting of two judges of the High Court, two judges of the Court of Appeal, the Attorney-General and two advocates, one to be nominated by the Law Society of Kenya and the other by the Mombasa Law Society, which shall have power to make rules not inconsistent with this Act and, subject thereto, to provide for any matters relating to the procedure of civil courts.”</li>
<li>Subsection (1A) provides that “The judges referred to in subsection (1) shall be appointed by the Chief Justice, who shall nominate one of them to be chairman of the Committee, and the Chief Justice may himself elect to be a member of the Committee in which case he shall be the chairman.”</li>
<li>The power is vested by statute and thus the rules have the force of statute.</li>
<li>They are rules of procedure only and not intended to affect the rights of parties to a suit. They are a process by which the parties’ rights are enforced or determined.</li>
<li>Therefore, they do not confer new rights or derogate any rights. Neither do they confer jurisdiction.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="how-are-the-rules-made">HOW ARE THE RULES MADE?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-are-the-rules-made" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Section 2 and 81 of the Civil Procedure Act shows that the rules are made by a Rules Committee.</li>
</ul>
<p>Section 2: "rules" means rules and forms made by the Rules Committee to regulate the procedure of courts.</p>
<p>Section 81 (1): There shall be a Rules Committee consisting of two judges of the High Court, two judges of the Court of Appeal, the Attorney-General and two advocates, one to be nominated by the Law Society of Kenya and the other by the Mombasa Law Society, which shall have power to make rules not inconsistent with this Act and, subject thereto, to provide for any matters relating to the procedure of civil courts.</p>
<ul>
<li>The rules have to be ratified by the AG.</li>
<li>The Courts may also have inherent jurisdiction to control how things are done with respect to the matters before it, this power is not to be used to contradict any existing statutory provisions or rules of the procedures.</li>
<li>The rules of procedures will have a rule to dispense compliance of any other rule if it is in the interest of justice e.g. filing of a paper in a certain rule.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions-of-the-rules">Functions of the Rules<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-rules" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>As alluded to above</li>
</ul>
<p>i. Section 2 and Section 81 of the civil procedure act the civil procedure rules are made by a committee.
ii. The rules are meant to regulate the procedure to be followed in court.
iii. They don't confer any rights to any parties or affect the rights of the parties neither do they modify or remove that which is already acquired.
iv. They are meant to protect the rights of the parties.
v. The rules are required to be consistent with the provision of the Act.
vi. If there are any inconsistency between Act and the rule the statute will prevail. See Central District Maize Millers Association v Maciel [1944] 6ULR J130</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="central-district-maize-millers-association-v-maciel-1944-6ulr-j130">Central District Maize Millers Association v Maciel [1944] 6ULR J130<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#central-district-maize-millers-association-v-maciel-1944-6ulr-j130" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In Uganda Section 99 of the Civil Procedure Ordinance is a replica of our section 100, Section 100 reads that the court may at any time and on such terms as to costs or as it may think fit, amend any defect or error in any proceeding in a suit; and all necessary amendments shall be made for the purpose of determining the real question or issue raised by or depending on the proceeding.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>The court is given power to amend pleadings by Section 100 and that power includes power to make amendments for purposes of determining the real question raised. In Uganda they had another provision which was Order VII Rule 11 which provided that the Plaint shall be rejected (a) where it does not disclose a course of action – power to reject summarily a plaint which does not disclose a cause of action.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="facts">Facts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#facts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In a suit against a payee and first endorser of a promissory note the plaint contended on averment that no notice of dishonour had been given. In the written statement of defence the defendant alleged that the plaint disclosed no cause of action because it did not contain an averment that notice of dishonour had been given to the defendant.</p>
<p>The trial magistrate amended the plaint by inserting particulars of the notice of dishonour and having heard evidence gave judgment against the defendant. The Defendant appealed against the judgment and the main ground of appeal was that the Plaint should have been rejected because it did not disclose a course of action and that there was no power to amend.</p>
<p>The question that the High Court had to determine was whether on there being no averment that notice of dishonour of the promissory note was given the Amendment of pleading by the Magistrate was proper or whether the magistrate was bound by Order VII Rule 11.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="held">Held<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#held" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Court held that the correct way of looking at the matter would be to say that the plaint did disclose a cause of action but unnecessary averment was omitted which could be cured by amendment under the Act notwithstanding the provisions of Order 7 Rule 11 which appeared to be inconsistent with Section 99 of the Act.</p>
<p>The words ‘does not disclose a cause of action’ under Order VII Rule 11 must mean that the plaint must be such that no legitimate amendment can be made to give it a cause of action. Although the rules may seem to confer the right to amend a pleading to disclose a cause of action, an amendment would be allowed under the general powers provided for under Section 100 to rectify a bona fide mistake in a plaint. Where there is conflict between the rules and the Act the provisions in the Act will prevail over those in the Rules.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="manning-acting-cj-stated">Manning, Acting CJ stated:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#manning-acting-cj-stated" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>"Order VII rule 11 says that the plaint shall be rejected when the suit appears to be barred by any law yet it appears competent to a court to allow an amendment to show that it is not barred."</p>
<p>That being the case therefore the rules must be construed so that it does not conflict with provisions of the Principal Act and therefore the word ‘does not disclose a cause of action’ in the rule must mean that the plaint is that which a legitimate amendment cannot be made to disclose a cause of action. Where amendment can be made, the Act will prevail.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>Although the rules may seem to bar the right to amend a pleading to disclose a cause of action, an amendment would be allowed under the general powers provided for under Section 100 to rectify a bona fide mistake in a plaint. Where there is conflict between</p>
<p>vii. If the Act confers unfetted power or discretion on the court and the rule appears to limit that power or discretion then that rule is inconsistent with the Act and then ultravires.
viii. If a rule is capable of 2 constructions one which is consistent and the other inconsistent, then the court should apply the construction which is consistent with the Act.
ix. The civil procedure act and rules made there under are not exhaustive of the procedure that may be adopted by the court and by the various civil matters before them.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-rules-by-statute">OTHER RULES BY STATUTE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-rules-by-statute" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The Civil Procedure Act and the rules made under it are not exhaustive.</li>
<li>There are other rules contained in other statutes which give specific procedure jurisdiction and these other rules should be taken as complimentary to the civil procedure rules.</li>
<li>There are statutes that provide for specific procedure should apply in matters that arise in those statutes e.g. for a matter for winding up of a company or voluntarily wound up, then the petition to wind up is governed in the company winding rules under Company Act and the Company High Court Rules (You can only wind up a company in a High Court).</li>
<li>Others are dispute in Elections or Matrimonial Cases etc.</li>
<li>S3A of the Civil Procedure Act explains that where a specific procedure is provided for by an Act of Parliament then that of the procedure prevails.</li>
<li>The court proceeds on the principle of inherent powers that every procedure is taken as permissible unless it has been expressly prohibited.</li>
<li>See S S Gupta v Inder Singh Bhamra [1965] EA 439</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="s-s-gupta-v-inder-singh-bhamra-1965-ea-439">S S Gupta v Inder Singh Bhamra [1965] EA 439<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#s-s-gupta-v-inder-singh-bhamra-1965-ea-439" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The plaintiff filed a suit against the defendant as a drawer of a dishonoured cheque. Within 14 days of filing the case the plaintiff filed an amendment in the Plaint without leave and then explained why notice of dishonour was not necessary. The defence applied to the court to disallow the amendment invoking the provisions of ORDER VII rule 11 while the Plaintiff argued that the amendment was proper and that Order VII rule 11 must not be inconsistent with the Section 99 of Ordinance that allowed him the amendment. The court said that the rule ought not to conflict with the Civil Procedure Ordinance.</p>
<p>If a rule is inconsistent with the Act it is ultra vires to that extent. Secondly if the Act confers unfettered power or discretion, a rule which limits the exercise of the power is prima facie inconsistent with the Act and is therefore ultra vires. Thirdly if a rule is capable of two constructions one consistent with the provisions of the Act and the other inconsistent with the provisions of the Rules then the court should lean to the construction which is consistent with the provisions of the Act.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>See also <strong>Mohan Singh Chadha v Sadhu Singh Bhogal [1965] EA 775 at 777</strong></li>
</ul>
<p>Section 80 confers an unfettered right to apply for review and the only fetter is that the court should exercise this discretion judiciary. Order VLIV has qualifying words, it purports to set out grounds for review. The ruling was that the wording in that particular Order should be given a liberal construction to avoid inconsistency with the wordings of Section 80, there should be no limitation to Section 80. invoke Section 80 for review it is safer.</p>
<p>x. The Act the rules made thereunder are not exhaustive although the intention is that they should apply to all matters of civil nature in court there are other rules prescribed by other statutes which give specific jurisdiction but these other rules should be taken to complement the civil procedure rules.</p>
<p>xi. Where a statute specifically provides that the Act and the Rules shall apply then the Act and the Rules should be applied to those proceedings and the fact that no rules have been made where law grants jurisdiction to the court does not mean that that jurisdiction cannot be exercised.</p>
<p>xii. Section 3 of the Act confers jurisdiction to the Court and explains that where one has specific procedure provided by an Act of Parliament then that procedure ought to prevail, where it provides for the rules under the Civil Procedure, then that should be the case.</p>
<p>xiii. The court ought to act on the principle that every procedure is to be taken as permissible unless it has been shown to be prohibited. One should not proceed on the basis that every procedure is to be taken as prohibited unless it is permitted.</p>
<p>xiv. See <strong>Mansion House Ltd. v John Wilkinson [1954]1EACA 98</strong></p>
<p><strong>Mansion House Ltd. v John Wilkinson [1954]1EACA 98</strong></p>
<p>Winding up proceedings by way of Originating Motion. At that time the OM was unknown to the Kenyan Law especially as enacted in the Civil Procedure Ordinance, the original authority for the existence of an OM was to be found not in the Civil Procedure Rules as applied in Kenya but in the English winding up rules.</p>
<p>The court further held that while the primary civil jurisdiction is exercised under Cap 21 the court shall apply the laws creating special jurisdiction or conferring special power or prescribing any special form of procedure.</p>
<ul>
<li>See also <strong>Re Parbat Shah [1955]22 EACA 381</strong></li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Re Parbat Shah [1955]22 EACA 381</strong></p>
<p>The court held that the jurisdiction of Kenya courts is based first on local jurisdiction and secondly on applied foreign laws including where these are silent the civil and criminal jurisdiction of the High Court in England. In this case the application for habeas corpus and prerogative writs are made in the English Courts and may be either of civil or criminal in nature</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>and therefore accordingly in Kenya the HC has jurisdiction to entertain such applications on either its civil or criminal side according to the nature of the proceedings.</p>
<p>From the above cases, we can conclude that if a rule is inconsistent with the Act:</p>
<ol>
<li>The rule is to that extent ultra vires</li>
<li>If principal legislation confers an unfettered powers, a rule that limits exercise of that power is prima facie inconsistent with the parent legislation and therefore ultra vires</li>
<li>If a rule is capable of two constructions, one consistent with the Act and the other inconsistent, the court should lean to the construction that is consistent</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="application-of-the-rules">Application of the Rules<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#application-of-the-rules" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Section 1 (2) of the CPA provides that “This Act applies to proceedings in the High Court and, subject to the Magistrate’s Courts Act, to proceedings in subordinate courts.”</li>
<li>It follows that since the Rules are made under the authority of this Act, then their application is similarly restricted to the High Court, Magistrates courts and other Subordinate Courts.</li>
<li>The CPR are not the primary Rules of procedure for the Court of Appeal. It has its own Rules. However, they apply in the Court of Appeal as complementary Rules.</li>
<li>The complementarity of the CPR and the Court of Appeal Rules is reflected in the certain aspects e.g. when applying for a stay of execution of a decree of the high Court.</li>
<li>Therefore, if a decree has been passed by the High Court, one could apply for a stay of execution order under</li>
</ul>
<p>i) Order 42 r.6 of the Civil Procedure Rules and ask the High Court to order for a stay of execution and if refused, to proceed to the Court of Appeal as per the CPR
ii) Rule 5 (2) (b) of the Court of Appeal Rules straight to the Court of Appeal circumventing the High Court</p>
<ul>
<li>These are special rules which allow for preservation of suit property pending appeal. The Court of Appeal grants stay of execution if one shows that the appeal will be rendered nugatory on conduct of execution.</li>
<li>The High Court standard is to require that one furnishes security. As long as one can provide security then the stay is granted.</li>
<li>Thus the burden of proof required under CA Rule 5(2) (b) is slightly lower than that under the CPR. The risk one runs is that once the stay has been denied by the Court of Appeal it will be next to impossible to obtain it from the High Court.</li>
<li>Look at the Jurisprudence in these cases to establish the same:</li>
</ul>
<p>i. Kenya Shell Ltd v Kibiru &amp; Another [1986] KLR 410
ii. Jogoo Kimakia Bus Services Ltd v Electrocom International Ltd [1985] KLR 260</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>iii. Rosengrens Ltd v Safe Deposit Centres Ltd [1984] 3 All ER 198</p>
<p>Kenya Shell Ltd v. Benjamin Karuga Kibiru &amp; Ruth Wairimu Karuga (1986) KLR 410</p>
<p>The Respondents obtained a judgment and decree in the High Court against the applicant for payment of damages arising from out of the applicant's negligence. The applicant applied to the Court of Appeal for stay of execution of the decree pending appeal arguing that if execution were to proceed, the appeal would be rendered nugatory.</p>
<p>HELD:</p>
<p>In the resolution of this case, the Hancox JA observed that the application for stay of execution has been brought under Rule 5 of the Court of Appeal Rules, and not under [Order XLI rule 4(1) of the CPR]-Implicit in this observation is the complimentarily of both sets of rules on matters concerning the application of stay of execution of an order of the high Court.</p>
<ol>
<li>Under Rule 5 (2), the court must consider whether the proposed appeal would be rendered nugatory unless payment of the decretal sum was stayed.</li>
<li>There was no evidence on the record to justify a finding that the respondents were not likely to repay the decretal sum of the appeal was successful.</li>
<li>Per Hancox JA. Although there is no requirement under Rule 5 (2) that an applicant for a stay shall give security for the due performance of the decree, it was usual for the court to require such security.</li>
<li>Per Platt Ag JA. It is not normal in money decrees for the appeal to be rendered nugatory if payment is made</li>
</ol>
<p>Charterhouse Bank Ltd v. Central Bank of Kenya &amp; 2 others (2007)</p>
<p>HELD:</p>
<ol>
<li>An applicant in an application for stay of execution should satisfy the court that the intended appeal is not frivolous, that is, it is arguable and, secondly that unless the stay is granted the result of the appeal, it successful, would be rendered nugatory.</li>
<li>Where the stay or injunction would lead to illegality and undesirable consequences, the court will not be inclined to grant the injunction.</li>
</ol>
<p>David Thiong'o t/a Welcome General Stores v. Market Fancy Emporium (2007)</p>
<p>HELD:</p>
<ol>
<li>The jurisdiction of the Court of Appeal to grant a stay of execution, an injunction or stay of proceedings can only be derived from its powers under rule 5 (2) (b) of the Court of Appeal Rules.</li>
<li>It is the lodging of a Notice of Appeal that gives the Court of Appeal jurisdiction to grant any order of stay of execution under rule 5 (2) (b).</li>
<li>The stay of execution sought can only relate to the subject matter of the Notice of Appeal which is the decision of the superior court appealed from.</li>
<li>The Court of Appeal has no jurisdiction to stay the order of a subordinate court.</li>
</ol>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="inherent-jurisdiction-of-the-court">INHERENT JURISDICTION OF THE COURT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inherent-jurisdiction-of-the-court" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Inherent means existing powers of the court</li>
<li>In a case where jurisdiction exists, but no procedure is provided for it is the duty of the judge or the magistrate to mount a convenient form of procedure which would serve the ends of justice.</li>
<li>The court should not refuse to do justice just because there is no procedure provided for.</li>
<li>If a matter is before the court and the procedure is not followed the court may come up with a procedure (mount) in the name of justice.</li>
<li>The courts should not refuse to provide justice merely because there is no procedure provided.</li>
<li>There is inherent power in every court to provide the procedure for achieving the ends of justice.</li>
<li>This is the inherent power of every court, the power said under Section 3A of the Act. This section does not confer any powers, it indicates there is power to make such orders as may be necessary for the ends of justice to be met and to prevent abuse of court. This power is conferred in every court. 3A has emerged as an omnibus provision</li>
<li>The inherent powers have been mandated by Section 3 A which gives courts to make such orders as necessary to prevent abuse of the court process.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="saving-inherent-powers-of-the-court">Saving Inherent Powers of The Court<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#saving-inherent-powers-of-the-court" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>3A. Nothing in this Act shall limit or otherwise affect the inherent power of the court to make such orders as may be necessary for the ends of justice or to prevent abuse of the process of the court.</p>
<ul>
<li>An attempt to define inherent powers was attempted in <em>Montreal Trust Company vs. Church Hill Forest Industries (Manitoba Ltd)</em> (1971)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="montreal-trust-company-vs-church-hill-forest-industries-manitoba-ltd-1971">Montreal Trust Company vs. Church Hill Forest Industries (Manitoba Ltd) (1971)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#montreal-trust-company-vs-church-hill-forest-industries-manitoba-ltd-1971" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The court defined inherent powers as follows "The court inherent jurisdiction is the reserved or fund of powers, a residual source of powers which the court may draw upon as necessary whenever it is just or equitable to do so. In particular to ensure the observance of the due process of law to prevent improper vexation or oppression to do justice between the parties or secure a fair trial between them.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>The nature of inherent jurisdiction is to compare it with other jurisdiction.</li>
</ul>
<p>a) Inherent jurisdiction and general jurisdiction</p>
<ul>
<li>When one talks of general jurisdiction of the court one is concerned with unrestricted and unlimited power of the court in civil and criminal cases except insofar as this power is taken away in unequivocal terms by statutes.</li>
<li>When one says that the HC has unlimited original jurisdiction in civil and criminal matters, one means that the HC has the full power of a judicial nature in all matters concerning the general administration of justice.</li>
<li>It is therefore not subject to any supervisory control by any other court or organ. In contrast the inherent jurisdiction of the court is therefore an aspect of its general jurisdiction.</li>
</ul>
<p>b) Inherent jurisdiction and statutory jurisdiction</p>
<ul>
<li>Statutory jurisdiction will define the limits within which the jurisdiction granted is to be exercised in contrast inherent jurisdiction derives from the court in its nature as a court of law hence the limits of such jurisdiction are not easy to define and there has been no reason to define.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="juridical-basis-of-inherent-jurisdiction">Juridical basis of inherent jurisdiction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#juridical-basis-of-inherent-jurisdiction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Section 3 which states that it is to prevent the abuse of the process of the court – what is the juridical basis of inherent jurisdiction</li>
<li>What are the powers of the court when it is exercising inherent jurisdiction – note that one way the court may want to exercise powers under section 3A are by coercion and giving summary judgment, dismiss action, stay action.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedures-in-other-jurisdictions">PROCEDURES IN OTHER JURISDICTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedures-in-other-jurisdictions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Questions have arisen if parties bring matters that are not in the rules but are practiced in other jurisdictions (other countries).</li>
<li>The principle is the courts to proceed, that all procedure are admissible unless expressly prohibited.</li>
<li>See Mansion House Ltd vs John Wilkson (1954) and Re Parbat Shah (1955)</li>
</ul>
<p>Mansion House Ltd vs John Wilkson (1954) and Re Parbat Shah (1955)</p>
<p>This case concerns proceedings to wind up a company commenced by way of originating motion. At the time originating motions were unknown to Kenyan Law and was not provided for in the Civil Procedure Ordinance of 1924 or the Civil Procedure Rules of 1927.</p>
<p>The originating motion was however provided for in the English Company Winding Up rules and the court held that the primary civil jurisdiction exercised is under Kenyan Civil Procedure Ordinance the</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>court may apply rules creating special jurisdiction or conferring a special power of prescribing any special form of procedure and upheld the proceedings in question.</p>
<p>In summary matters filed under originating motions in the UK. Our rules don't have originating motions (we have originating summons). The argument was that the courts had no jurisdiction. The order in council in 1924 provided for borrowing of procedures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="rules-of-the-court-as-source-of-civil-procedure-practice-direction">Rules of the Court as Source of Civil Procedure/Practice Direction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rules-of-the-court-as-source-of-civil-procedure-practice-direction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Apart from the Civil Procedure Rules there are Rules, Regulations and Directions which the court uses to guide the smooth operations of the court process.</li>
<li>Regulations and directions the courts uses from time to time to guide the smooth operations of the court process.</li>
<li>This are given by judicial officers presiding from time to time e.g. There will be no hearing in the afternoon, this time will be used for judgments only</li>
<li>In Milimani Commercial Courts for example, there is the direction that rulings are for the afternoons hearings and mentions for the mornings – these are practice directions, to have orderly conduct for the business of the courts.</li>
<li>These practice directions are normally bestowed in the Judicial Officer presiding over that particular court or it could be from the CJ. The practice in UK is that they report these kind of directions in the Law Reports to be part of the records but here one never gets to know what happens.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="case-law-as-source-of-procedure">CASE LAW AS SOURCE OF PROCEDURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#case-law-as-source-of-procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This is achieved by way of judicial pronouncements.</li>
<li>See Tiwi Beach vs. Stamm (1991) KLR 658 See also Giela vs Cassman Brown and Murage vs Mae</li>
</ul>
<table><thead><tr><th><strong>Tiwi Beach vs. Stamm (1991) KLR 658</strong></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>The court of appeal upheld the high court decision to grant injunction despite the fact a material had not be disclosed by the applicant on the basis that there was no deliberate concealment of the fact. Secondly even if the in question had been disclosed the courts would still have granted the order.</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Giela vs Cassman Brown</strong></td></tr><tr><td>Requirements for grant of temporary injunctions and set procedure to be followed where parties are intent to obtain temporary injunctions. Prima facie case with probability of success, client must be likely to suffer irreparable harm that cannot be taken care of by damages.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="murage-vs-mae">Murage vs Mae<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#murage-vs-mae" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The court was considering the provisions of Order XXXVIII the judge was concerned with the provisions of Order XXXVIII and the Mareva Injunction. Can one really cater for the needs of their clients through an application under Order XXXVIII without applying for a Mareeva Injunction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="others-ways-of-solving-civil-matters">OTHERS WAYS OF SOLVING CIVIL MATTERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#others-ways-of-solving-civil-matters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="arbitration">ARBITRATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arbitration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The fundamental distinction between an arbitration and litigation is the consensual manner of arbitration. There must be agreement between the parties.</li>
<li>In arbitration an award is granted at the end while in litigation a judgment is granted.</li>
<li>There are two ways of going to arbitration i.e.</li>
</ul>
<p>a) Pursuant to a court order under Order 46 CPR. Order 46 R 1 provides that 'Where in any suit all the parties interested who are not under disability agree that any matter in difference between them in such suit shall be referred to arbitration, they may, at any time before judgment is pronounced, apply to the court for an order of reference.'</p>
<p>b) Pursuant to agreement of the parties where the applicable law will be the Arbitration Act (Act No.4 of 1995)</p>
<ul>
<li>The court does not have power to force the parties to undertake arbitration unless they are both willing. Inherent in the nature of arbitration is the fact that it is only effective if both parties are willing participants.</li>
<li>If any of the parties is not happy with the award or the conduct of the arbitration, he can apply to the court under order 46 Rule 16 to have it set aside. This rule [0 46 R 16] provides that (1) "The court may set aside an award on the following grounds only –
(a) corruption or misconduct of the arbitrator or umpire; or
(b) that either party has fraudulently concealed any matter which he ought to have disclosed, or has wilfully misled or deceived the arbitrator or umpire.</li>
<li>An Application under this rule shall be served on the arbitrator or umpire.</li>
<li>Where an award is set aside under this rule the court shall supersede the arbitration and shall proceed with the suit."</li>
<li>If there is an arbitration clause in an agreement between parties then neither of the parties to that agreement can refuse to go for arbitration- Scott v Avery.</li>
<li>An arbitration clause may stand on its own even after the agreement has broken down, it will still oblige the former parties thereto to arbitrate before litigating.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>If a party goes for arbitration pursuant to an agreement between the parties then the Arbitration Act No.4 of 1995 will apply. The Act governs any arbitration conducted in Kenya by agreement of parties.</li>
<li>Parties can categorically state which law will govern the agreement and it is that law that will govern the arbitration. They are at liberty as to the manner of arbitration and its seat. The Act has 42 sections:</li>
<li>S.37 of the Arbitration Act states the grounds under which an arbitral award can be refused recognition or enforcement. It states that: (1) "The recognition or enforcement of an arbitral award, irrespective of the state in which it was made, may be refused only-</li>
</ul>
<p>(a) at the request of the party against whom it is invoked, if that party furnishes to the High Court proof that-</p>
<p>(i) a party to the arbitration agreement was under some incapacity, or
(ii) the arbitration agreement is not valid under the law to which the parties have subjected it or, failing any indication of that law, under the law of the state where the arbitral award was made;
(iii) the party against whom the arbitral award is invoked was not given proper notice of the appointment of an arbitrator or of the arbitral proceedings or was otherwise unable to present his case; or
(iv) the arbitral award deals with a dispute not contemplated by or not falling within the terms of the reference to arbitration, or it contains decisions on matters beyond the scope of the reference to arbitration, provided that if the decisions on matters referred to arbitration can be separated from those not so referred, that part of the arbitral award which contains decisions on matters referred to arbitration may be recognised and enforced; or
(v) the composition of the arbitral tribunal or the arbitral procedure was not in accordance with the agreement of the parties or, failing any agreement by the parties, was not in accordance with the law of the state where the arbitration took place; or
(vi) the arbitral award has not yet become binding on the parties or has been set aside or suspended by a court of the state in which, or under the law of which, that arbitral award was made; or</p>
<p>(b) if the High Court finds that</p>
<p>(i) the subject matter of the dispute is not capable of settlement by arbitration under the law of Kenya; or</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>(ii) the recognition or enforcement of the arbitral award would be contrary to the public policy of Kenya."</p>
<ul>
<li>Under the Arbitration Act of 1995, there is a distinction between domestic and international arbitration.</li>
<li>Domestic arbitration is the arbitration that takes place in Kenya; the parties are Kenyan nationals or reside in Kenya. International arbitration is the arbitration where the parties reside in different states and their business is also in different states. If the agreement provides that a specific law should apply then that law will govern the procedure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="an-award-and-a-judgment">An award and a judgment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#an-award-and-a-judgment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>The judgment is a pronouncement of a court decision in open court i.e. it is uttered, pronounced and proclaimed in open court as per O.XX r.1 of the CPR. There is no judgment if it is not read by the court. The award is a written decision of an arbitral tribunal as per s.32 of the Arbitration Act</li>
<li>Judgments are pronounced orally or uttered at the end of the trial process. Awards are signed and delivered to the parties at the end of the case.</li>
<li>Judgments can be reviewed by their authors where new evidence or error has been obtained or for a sufficient reason. Awards cannot be reviewed by their authors but can be corrected or interpreted. S.34 of the Arbitration Act. After an award the arbitrator becomes <em>functus officio</em></li>
<li>Judgments are generally subject to appeal or review by superior courts. Awards are only subject to setting aside by the High Court under s.35 of the Act or O.XLV r.15 of the CPR</li>
<li>Judgments contain detailed analysis of legal principles distinguishing, following or overruling previous decisions. Awards analyse the facts and reach conclusions on matters in issue based on the common sense approach and the law. The emphasis is on common sense but based on accepted principles of law.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="conclusion">Conclusion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#conclusion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The Rules Committee have set up a website so that they can find a way of disposing of cases quickly i.e. formed the <strong>Expeditious Disposal of Cases Committee (EDCC)</strong> which is mandated to develop the rules to govern the procedure with the purpose of speedy disposal of cases under s.53 of the CPA. Rules Committee is mandated to make rules and adopts the recommendation of the EDCC.</li>
<li>Arbitration cannot be compulsory but the committee craft rules in a way that some disputes should be referred to arbitration. The rule of the court is to support and encourage private arbitration. Courts are encouraging what is called the principle of party autonomy.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>The arbitration procedure has not been successful in our courts because the legal profession has not accepted arbitration as an accepted alternative mode of solving disputes because of the kind of training and the adversarial system we have in Kenya.</li>
<li>The applicable law is the Arbitration Act of 1995 and the Civil Procedure Rules. S.10 of the Arbitration Act provides that except for as provided in this Act no court shall intervene in matters provided in the Act.</li>
<li>See judgments by A. Ringera &amp; Nyamu who upheld s.10 and the PTA case that did not uphold s.10</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>The EDCC is trying to bring awareness to the lawyer on arbitration</li>
<li>The court staff are being trained on mediation to become mediators</li>
<li>The case management approach is borrowed from Lord Hughes report (judge gets involved and manages, sets limit on time, frames issues so as to ensure that the whole purpose of the case is shortened)</li>
<li>The small cases courts i.e. three layers of courts</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>First track system which takes 6 months to handle i.e. no pleadings but only affidavits will be used to determine the case</li>
<li>Second track system which takes a maximum of 1 year to determine i.e. pleadings may be allowed for medium sized claims</li>
<li>Third track system for complex cases which take a maximum of 2 years</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li>Simplify civil procedure i.e. into Kiswahili &amp; improve right of access</li>
<li>The court to use common sense approach to avoid the technicality in handling and deciding disputes</li>
</ol>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>LECTURE 2: TUESDAY 23rd FEBRUARY 2016- MORNING SESSION (LECTURE HALL A)</p>
<p>TOPIC 2: TAKING OF INSTRUCTIONS IN CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>Topic Overview</p>
<p>a) Taking instructions and client -advocate interview and conferencing
b) The demand letter before action
c) Decision to litigate
d) Pre-litigation preliminary considerations
(i) The right parties
(ii) The nature of the cause of action (if any) disclosed and the appropriate proceedings to bring
(iii) Relevant statute of limitations
(iv) Appropriate forum
(v) Proper way of going to law in the chosen forum.</p>
<p>Topic Objectives</p>
<p>By the end of the discussion of this topic, and the relevant readings, learners should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>show the importance and indispensability of client instructions for Civil Litigation</li>
<li>demonstrate the conduct of an effective client-advocate conference</li>
<li>demonstrate the taking of instructions</li>
<li>show how to determine whether or not to litigate</li>
<li>explain the preliminary considerations before a suit is filed</li>
<li>demonstrate the drafting of a demand letter before action</li>
</ul>
<p>Readings:</p>
<ul>
<li>Order 1 of the Civil Procedure Rules, 2010.</li>
<li>Barclays Bank of Kenya v. KephaNyabera&amp;189 others &amp; 2 others [2007] eKLR</li>
<li>Nderitu&amp; Partners Advocates v. MamukaValuers(Management) Ltd.[2006] eKLR</li>
<li>Samuel Kinoti v. Erastus KithinjiM'magiri (in the matter of the Estate of M'magiri(deceased)[2005] eKLR</li>
<li>Republic v. District Land Registrar Nandi &amp; another ex parte KipronoTegeri&amp; another [2005] eKLR</li>
<li>Kenya Bus Services Ltd &amp; another v Minister for Transport&amp; 2 others [2012] eKLR</li>
<li>Millicent Wambui v Nairobi Botanica Gardening Limited [2013]eKLR (Cause No. 2512 of 2012)</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="taking-instructions-and-client-advocate-interview-and-conferencing">Taking instructions and client - advocate interview and conferencing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#taking-instructions-and-client-advocate-interview-and-conferencing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-purpose-and-scope-of-client-interviews">The purpose and scope of client interviews<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-purpose-and-scope-of-client-interviews" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It forms the advocate-client relationship;</li>
