<li>The advocate is able to learn of the client’s intention;</li>
<li>The advocate is able to elicit the facts, as perceived by the client;</li>
<li>The advocate is able to afford a legal opinion for the client;</li>
<li>The advocate is able to formulate a course of action, upon instruction by the client.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="advocate-client-relationship">Advocate-Client Relationship<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advocate-client-relationship" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The interview heralds the fiduciary relationship that is cemented by the retainer.</li>
<li>The knowledge acquired by the advocate in the interview from the client, should be treated as confidential and should not be disclosed to anyone else without the client’s consent – King Woollen Mills Ltd. v. Kaplan &amp; Stratton Advocates (1990-1994) EA 244.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-how-to-conduct-a-client-interview">A. How to conduct a client interview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-how-to-conduct-a-client-interview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Client interview is done in stages.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-preliminary-stage">1. Preliminary Stage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-preliminary-stage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Some form of communication before the interview. This may be in the form of a simple phone call or a short visit with the client. The purpose is to get a rough outline of what the case involves and allow the advocate to prepare for a substantive interview.</li>
<li>Because of the mistrust lay people have for lawyers, an advocate must endeavor to be forthright and approachable.</li>
<li>He/she should also prepare such information as fees and other costs that may be incidental to the case and be ready to discuss this at the very onset so that the client knows that he/she is getting into.</li>
<li>It may also be useful at this stage to examine any prejudices or biases that the advocate may have which may have an impact on how he handles the case.</li>
<li>It would also be prudent for the advocate to reflect on what the client expects from him. In this regard it is useful to think of the case from the client’s standpoint.</li>
<li>Regardless of the feelings of the advocate towards the client’s case, the advocate should let the client know that they will do their best to champion their cause and get them the best possible outcome given the facts of the case.</li>
<li>The initial communication with the client may also serve to give you an idea of the education, legal knowledge and sophistication of the client.</li>
<li>This will then help the advocate identify the best way of communicating with the client.</li>
<li>The advocate should also purpose to be positive in his attitude/approach to the client.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>This does not mean that he be overly optimistic and mislead the client about the possible outcome.</li>
<li>It simply means that he be prepared to put the best spin on the information provided and the facts that he will receive from the client.</li>
<li>After forming an initial opinion of the case, the advocate should then decide what basic information he needs to get from the client.</li>
<li>The advocate can also ask the client to bring any documents that he deems from his initial perception to be relevant to the case e.g. title documents in a conveyance transaction.</li>
<li>Once the advocate has identified what he will need for the interview, he proceeds to set down a date for the same.</li>
<li>It is important to stick to the date and time that is agreed on with the client and also not to schedule any other things at the same time.</li>
<li>This will enable him/her to give enough time to the client and his case and will also go a long way in making the client feel that his case is important to you</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-commencing-the-interview">2. Commencing the Interview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-commencing-the-interview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The advocate should take time to make the client feel comfortable before the interview starts.</li>
<li>He should bear in mind that in addition to people's foreboding attitude towards advocates, they also find them and their offices intimidating.</li>
<li>If possible, the advocate should personally meet them at the reception and walk them into their office or conference room, whichever is preferable.</li>
<li>Do not take your client into your office if you have an "ego wall"- a wall that is adorned with your achievements, photos of you with celebrities or newspaper clippings of your success story at the first meeting.</li>
<li>Do not let the clients see the "ego wall" before they have seen you and thus had a chance to form an impression independent of your achievements.</li>
<li>Introduce yourself to the client. You may also engage in some informal talk so as to break the ice.</li>
<li>Make sure that the room is comfortable for both of you and that it has a writing area if you plan to take notes.</li>
<li>You can offer the client some refreshment as a way of putting them at ease and making them feel even more comfortable at your office.</li>
<li>The way you receive your client says a lot to them about how you will handle their matter.</li>
<li>The advocate should also prepare to be uninterrupted. He can ask the secretary to ensure that this happens e.g. ask her to hold his calls</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-information-gathering">3. Information Gathering<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-information-gathering" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is the most important aspect of the client interview, and what counts is the type of information you get and how you go about gathering it.</li>
<li>The best way to get information is to let the client tell the story in his own words.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>Encourage him to tell the story by letting him know that the rules of confidentiality extend to the initial consultation, regardless of whether the client decides to engage your services.</li>
<li>When they start to tell their story, listen without interrupting.</li>
<li>Employ active listening skills such as nodding and making eye-contact to let them know that they have your attention.</li>
<li>You can make notes about what they are saying and mark the issues that need clarification.</li>
<li>Do not interrupt the client unless it is absolutely necessary.</li>
<li>Let them also tell you what they are hoping to get from you.</li>
<li>Once they have explained their situation, summarize the story that they have told in light of the relevant facts to ascertain that you understood them correctly.</li>
<li>Seek clarification on anything that did not come out clearly.</li>
<li>When seeking clarification, avoid judgmental cross-examination.</li>
<li>Confronting the client with the gaping holes in his story will come later, when you are preparing the client for trial.</li>
<li>Do not patronize him; neither should you be arrogant.</li>
<li>At this stage, the advocate should make room for vagueness, memory lapses and lies.</li>
<li>These are the natural responses from clients who think that they must convince the advocate of their saintliness.</li>
<li>However, in the interests of getting accurate information, ensure that you engage openly with your client and encourage them to be as forthcoming as possible.</li>
<li>Go through the list that you made in preparation for the interview and make sure that you have got the basic information from your client that you need for the case.</li>
<li>Address the client on your assessment of their case. At this point, you need to maintain eye contact so that they know that you are listening to them and that what you have to say is important.</li>
<li>Do not speak over their head; avoid legal jargon and take time to explain what is happening to the client.</li>
<li>Go over the elements of the case with your client and bring out the legal issues that arise.</li>
<li>If they have not brought any documents, ask them for documents which can support their case.</li>
<li>If the client is charged with a crime, try to bring out possible defenses by asking questions that will bring out witness or alibi information.</li>
<li>You can also find out whether they have potential character witnesses.</li>
<li>The information that you gather can also help you identify whether or not there are any possibly conflicts of interest arising or whether what the client is asking for is illegal or unethical.</li>
<li>It is important to let them know that privilege does not cover instances when they are contemplating a criminal act.</li>
<li>From the information you gather from their story and by asking questions, develop a case strategy.</li>
<li>However, be careful to identify the problem, fully investigate and strategize before you give firm dispositional advice.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>If you need more time to clarify the law and to consult, let them know and schedule another meeting where you can advise them more authoritatively.</li>
<li>You can also at this point decide that you do not want to take the case.</li>
<li>Consider if you have doubts as to whether you can function effectively possibly because of conflict of interest, lack of sufficient practice in the particular area of law that the case relates to or some other sufficient reason. See <em>Oriental Commercial Bank Limited v. Central Bank of Kenya [2012] eklr</em></li>
<li>It could also be that you can tell at the initial interview that the client is walking trouble and that you do not want to undertake representation.</li>
<li>You can decline the case orally and by letter.</li>
<li>If you decline because the case does not fall within your area of expertise, you can recommend another advocate that would be suitable</li>
<li>If you continue with the case, let them know the best and worst case scenario based on your experiences.</li>
<li>Establish trust with the client and treat him with respect.</li>
<li>How you speak to the client is an indication of how you will represent them.</li>
<li>Discuss the fees with the client.</li>
<li>Clients do not like to be ambushed with legal fees grossly in excess of what they thought they would be paying.</li>
<li>Let them know what you plan to do and how much it is likely to cost them.</li>
<li>Explain to them how you calculate your fees and agree with them on how the same will be paid.</li>
<li>If possible, sign a fee agreement and secure a deposit on your legal fees.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-closing">4. Closing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-closing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Explain to the client what you plan to do based on the strategy that you have come up with, what steps they have to take in that regard e.g. sign affidavits, deposit money for court fees etc.</li>
<li>You can then arrange another meeting to explain the progress that you have made.</li>
<li>Studies show clients are impressed with advocates who put extra effort, provide extra information and who consistently keep in touch.</li>
<li>Make a point of giving your best to the client’s case and keeping them appraised on the status of their case.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="summary-of-client-interview">SUMMARY OF CLIENT INTERVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#summary-of-client-interview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Client interview is an essential part of litigation process.</li>
<li>Through the interview: the client-advocate relationship is established, the advocate gets to know the facts of a case, from the fact you get to establish whether there is a cause of action and you get a chance to give a legal opinion.</li>
<li>Its importance in the civil litigation cannot be overstated.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>&gt; Client interview happens in several stages:
&gt; - ☑ The preliminary
&gt; - ☑ The actual interview</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="preliminary-stage">Preliminary stage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#preliminary-stage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; - ☑ It entails some form of communication with the client before the actual interview
&gt; - ☑ It can either be through a phone call or brief meeting with the client
&gt; - ☑ Its purpose is to give the outline of the client case and to enable preparation of the actual interview.
&gt; - ☑ It is the best stage to determine the legal costs of the case, to do research and form an opinion on the case, determine any conflicts of interests, gather relevant information toward the actual interview, ask client to bring any relevant documents to the case.
&gt; - ☑ Deciding on time and date of the actual interview</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-actual-interview">The actual interview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-actual-interview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>&gt; - ☑ Make client feel comfortable
&gt; - ☑ Gather the information and advising clients on several aspects of their case, decide whether you will take the case, advise them on the fees
&gt; - ☑ Closing – explain what you plan to do with their case
&gt; - ☑ Questions in a client-interview- the information you will need from a client
&gt;   - ☑ Personal information
&gt;   - ☑ Other parties involved/ concerned
&gt;   - ☑ Witnesses
&gt;   - ☑ The event that took place
&gt;   - ☑ What the client wants
&gt;   - ☑ Previous advise or assistance offered to the client on the same subject matter
&gt;   - ☑ Anyone else consulted and details of the consultant
&gt;   - ☑ Existing legal proceedings</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="special-problems-in-client-interview">Special problems in client interview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#special-problems-in-client-interview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>☑ Ethics in client interview – client might want you to falsify evidence so as to succeed in the case. The best approach to this situation is to explain to the client the offence of perjury which deals with falsifying of evidence.</p>
<p>☑ Handling of private/ embarrassing material – assuring the client that he can trust you in the handling of such kind of information.</p>
<p>☑ Handling possible client fabrication – telling the client that it is in his interest to tell you the truth. Gain the confidence of the client by stressing on the duty of confidentiality.</p>
<p>☑ Clients who want instant prediction of the case – explain to the client the work you will do to his case.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-questions-in-a-client-interview">B. Questions in a Client Interview<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-questions-in-a-client-interview" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-what-questions-to-ask-the-client">1. What questions to ask the client<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-what-questions-to-ask-the-client" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>When preparing for an interview, an advocate has to consider his information needs. To achieve this, the following need to be asked.</li>
<li>Personal information: Name, address, telephone numbers, family ties, work, age, nationality, income &amp; health.</li>
<li>Other parties concerned: Basic personal details, advocate instructed (if any), connection with client (if any).</li>
<li>Witnesses (if relevant): Basic personal details, witness to what and for whom, connection with client.</li>
<li>The events that took place: Dates, times, place(s), people involved, the cause and course of events, people affected, property affected, incident which precipitated the visit to the advocate.</li>
<li>What the client wants: Identify the main problem, desired outcome, difficulties in achieving outcome, people to be affected by outcome.</li>
<li>Previous advice and assistance offered to the client on the same subject matter:</li>
<li>i. Anyone else consulted and details of consultant; the advice given, action taken, effects of the action.</li>
<li>ii. Existing legal proceedings: Nature of proceedings, parties; stage of process; past or future hearing dates.</li>
<li>Based on the above information needs, the advocate must be sure to explore the following questions with the client:</li>
<li>i. The raw facts and the client’s source of knowledge</li>
<li>ii. All details relevant to the problem.</li>
<li>iii. Any questions required to prevent:</li>
<li>a) Accepting a client who creates a conflict of interest.</li>
<li>b) Missing the deadlines espoused in the statute limiting actions.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>c) Not taking emergency actions to protect a client threatened by immediate harm.
iv. All documentation relevant to the problem.
v. Questions as to what the argument of the opposing party would be in a court dispute.
vi. Exhaustive questions of evidence in court disputes.
vii. An evaluation of the client's value as a witness in court in court disputes.
viii. In transactional interviews, the status of the transaction.
ix. The parties' interests in a transactional interview.
x. Whether the client has talked to another advocate about the problem in issue.</p>
<ul>
<li>In asking the above questions, the advocate must have the following in mind:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Look at the matter in the client's perspective, that is, empathize with the client.</li>
<li>Maintain advocate-client confidentiality.</li>
<li>Set the timetable and layout the approach to be taken in helping the client.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-organizing-and-formulating-the-questions">2. Organizing and formulating the questions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-organizing-and-formulating-the-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>In formulating the questions above, the advocate should organize the questions topically, and ask the questions carefully as these will determine how the questions are answered.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="c-special-problems-in-client-interviews">C. Special Problems in Client Interviews<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-special-problems-in-client-interviews" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-ethics-in-client-interviews">1. Ethics in client interviews<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-ethics-in-client-interviews" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>When the client wants the advocate to assist in falsifying evidence and perpetrating illegalities so as to succeed in the case, the advocate should refrain from such requests/orders.</li>
<li>The best approach for the advocate is to interview the client and explain the law since falsifying testimony amounts to the offence of perjury.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-handling-private-and-embarrassing-materials">2. Handling private and embarrassing materials<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-handling-private-and-embarrassing-materials" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>In handling embarrassing or private material, the advocate should give the client time to appreciate that he/she is a person of discretion who can be entrusted by the kind of information that the client might not even be willing to tell his/her friends about.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-handling-possible-client-fabrications">3. Handling possible client fabrications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-handling-possible-client-fabrications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The main cause of fabrication is by fundamental manipulation by the client.</li>
<li>Therefore, the advocate should explain to the client that it is in the client's interest to tell him the truth.</li>
<li>To this end, the advocate should gain the confidence of the client by stressing to the client his duty of confidentiality to the client, and the privileges of the advocate-client communication.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>In doing this, the advocate will obtain accurate information that is valuable to any proceeding, be it litigation or alternative dispute resolution.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-handling-a-client-who-wants-instant-predication-of-the-case">4. Handling a client who wants instant predication of the case<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-handling-a-client-who-wants-instant-predication-of-the-case" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This problem arises out of the clients need for assurance that the case has chances of success.</li>
<li>The advocate can, therefore, explain to the client what work he/she will do, what issues the advocate will research on and the facts that advocate needs to investigate.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-difficult-client">5. Difficult Client<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-difficult-client" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-the-difficult-client">a) The Difficult Client<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-the-difficult-client" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The cab-rank rule provides that advocates should make legal services available to the public in an efficient and convenient way that commands respect and confidence and is compatible with the integrity and independence of the profession without discrimination, including too difficult clients.</li>
<li>At some point in an advocate’s career, he or she has to deal with difficult clients.</li>
<li>Clients may be difficult for any number of reasons: they may have unique behavioral traits that are exacerbated by their legal matter; others may have mental health issues.</li>
<li>The fact that a client is difficult should not generally deter the advocate from representing the client.</li>
<li>Managing difficult clients, however, presents numerous challenges.</li>
<li>Advocates should be alert to indicators that a prospective client may be difficult and take steps to ensure that the “difficult” advocate-client relationship is effectively managed.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-identifying-the-difficult-client">b) Identifying the Difficult Client<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-identifying-the-difficult-client" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Some indicators that suggest the prospective client may pose challenges for the advocate:</li>
</ul>
<p>i. Previous advocates: This should be an interrogation on the number advocates the client has had in the past on the same matter, outstanding accounts or unpaid accounts, any unjustifiable criticism of the advocate, description of the previous advocate as demanding; wanting calls or letters returned promptly and client not willing to oblige etc.</p>
<p>ii. Litigation history: This should inquire whether the matter has been litigated for years and has been very contentious, whether the client is presently representing himself or herself, whether the client will not tell you the reason why his or her previous advocate got off the record and he is also not keen on you getting in touch with the previous advocate on record regarding his case and the level of the client’s knowledge of the case and court process.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>iii. Personality traits and behavior: This is done to find out personality type of the client, the client's feeling about the importance of the case, the client's use of a lot of the advocate's time and that of his/her staff. It also includes the client's low expectations about the outcome of the matter, time it takes and unrealistic costs and his continuous failure to provide instructions. On behavior, it includes whether the client is verbally abusive to the advocate and his/her staff or whether the client writes abusive letters to the advocate.</p>
<p>iv. Communication in the case: This provides indicators as to whether the documentation/orders that the client provides are different from the information provided over the telephone and the advocate has a difficulty understanding the client's reason(s) for the difference. In addition, it could be that the client is not clear or coherent in his instructions. A difficult client could also fail to respond to correspondence.</p>
<p>v. Client's ability to pay for services rendered by advocate: A difficult client might ask for concessions even when they have the ability to pay. The client could also plead with and beg the advocate to stay on even though there are difficulties in the relationship. The client might also indicate directly or indirectly to the advocate that he / she will not testify at the trial. It might also become apparent to the advocate that the client will not or that there is likelihood that he/she will not pay fees.</p>
<p>c) Managing the Difficult Client</p>
<p>i. The advocate should explain his/her role and set the boundaries early on in the retainer: The advocate's role is to analyze a given situation and offer a solution to the problem presented, or a means of achieving the goal the client has presented.</p>
<p>ii. The advocate should document everything he/she possibly can, including telephone calls, voice mail messages and e-mail messages. The advocate should have the client's instructions in writing as confirmed by the client (also in writing). It is also necessary to include, in writing, the possible consequences of various courses of action the client may be contemplating.</p>
<p>iii. The advocate should recommend counseling for the client, if possible, so as to place the client in a state of mind to discuss the matter soberly, realistically and reasonably.</p>
<p>iv. The advocate should set realistic expectations for his/her client early on in the case.</p>
<p>v. The advocate should manage needs and expectations of the client, about service, timing, results and costs efficiently.</p>
<p>vi. The advocate should discuss the client's difficulties with his/her staff and include his/her staff in an action plan for the client: The advocate must ensure the staff understands the risks of acting for a difficult client, so they can behave in ways that minimize those risks. The advocate should make sure the staff is dealing with this client the same way that the advocate is, especially in terms of documenting contacts, instructions or information.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>vii. The advocate should ensure that the client understands the importance of openness and honesty in the advocate-client relationship.
viii. In handling the difficult client, the advocate must be calm, patient and clear.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-client-counseling">6. Client Counseling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-client-counseling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-the-purpose-and-scope-of-client-counseling">(a) The purpose and scope of client counseling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-the-purpose-and-scope-of-client-counseling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>There is always a real temptation and a tendency in client counseling to make judgments and give orders, and a tendency in clients to depend on their legal counselors for judgment and direction.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-purpose-of-counseling">(b) Purpose of counseling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-purpose-of-counseling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>To avoid unethical practice, it must not escape the notice of an advocate that the main goal of legal counseling is to help the client decide what to do.</li>
<li>As advocates call it, they counsel with the goal of "opening up options."</li>
<li>To achieve this, as an advocate, you should always keep to the following ethical guidelines:</li>
<li>i. The advocate should not lecture to the client and leave him no room to make choices.</li>
<li>ii. The advocate should remember that in most cases, the client knows what he wants, but needs to decide what to do.</li>
<li>iii. The advocate should put his client’s best interests first.</li>
<li>iv. The advocate should maintain confidentiality as his core.</li>
<li>With these in mind, you will recall that counseling is client-centered but not advocate-centered.</li>
<li>The purpose of counseling is to let the client lead but the advocate opens up options.</li>
<li>The advocate should not decide for the client.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-the-scope-of-counseling">(c) The scope of counseling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-the-scope-of-counseling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>An experienced legal counselor uses different counseling styles as appropriate and sets up a relaxing and trusting environment early on.</li>
<li>A good legal counselor is honest, recognizes and has a respect for and acceptance of a need to put some distance between himself/herself and the client.</li>
<li>Before obtaining crucial information from a client, it is sometimes imperative that an advocate deals with some underlying issues that may be related to or isolated from the issue in question.</li>
<li>The question that weighs on the advocate’s mind is how far one can go in dealing with these underlying issues.</li>
<li>How far can one counsel go?</li>
<li>To understand the scope of counseling, one needs to look at the common and practical problems and challenges in practice.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>(d) What if the real problem is not legal?</p>
<ul>
<li>On occasion, an advocate will encounter a client who either does not have a true "legal" problem or who has other overwhelming non-legal problems that must be addressed.</li>
<li>The stereotypical situation is where a client has a minor legal problem such as a traffic ticket, or a dispute with a neighbor, and it is apparent to the advocate that the "real" underlying problem is that the client needs professional counseling or therapy.</li>
<li>Another example would be where there is a legal problem such as a landlord tenant or debt problem that can be easily addressed legally, but it is apparent that the underlying issue for the client is substance abuse or dependence.</li>
<li>In both of these situations, the advocate would be wise to address any legal problem in the usual manner, and then to address the underlying problem.</li>
<li>In my view, unless the advocate has a unique background or specialized training, the appropriate counseling response is to refer the client for specialized care by a person or agency that deals with the particular problem involved.</li>
<li>An advocate's counseling should stay focused on legal problems and that clients requiring specialized counseling should be referred to specialists.</li>
<li>In all cases where an advocate feels there may be important "non-legal" issues, these issues should be carefully considered for a clear plan of referral or counseling developed where appropriate.</li>
<li>An advocate can get into serious difficulty if he or she tries to counsel outside of his or her experience and training.</li>
</ul>
<p>(e) Can an advocate decide for the client in counseling?</p>
<ul>
<li>Making important decisions can be difficult for most human beings.</li>
<li>Having an "expert" make those decisions can sometimes be easier for the client.</li>
<li>One of the most commonly encountered problems for advocates in the counseling process is that the client wants the advocate to make the decision for them.</li>
<li>After all that is what "they are paying the big bucks for."</li>
<li>The problem with this approach is that roles are being reversed and the advocate may be getting himself or herself into a professional trap.</li>
<li>The core of client counseling is that the client must make the decisions.</li>
<li>The role of the advocate is to chart out the alternatives and then make sure the client makes a fully informed and volitional decision.</li>
</ul>
<p>(f) Duties to a client when counseling</p>
<ul>
<li>From the discourse above, it is clear therefore that in the process of counseling, an advocate owes a client duty to avoid professional malpractice.</li>
</ul>
<p>i. Duty of care</p>
<ul>
<li>Where there are underlying issues that are not legal, an advocate has to be very careful not to mislead the client.</li>
<li>If the advocate does not have a background training in counseling, he should not engage in the process but should instead make a referral where necessary.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>This should be done where the problem at hand requires necessary expertise to deal with prior to dealing with the legal questions.</li>
<li>However, even where he has background training, he should let the decision making to the client. If he makes a decision and the client acts based on it, he is entirely responsible for the outcome of the action.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-duty-of-confidentiality">ii. Duty of confidentiality<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-duty-of-confidentiality" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Confidentiality is at the core of any counseling process.</li>
<li>A client should be at ease when giving information knowing that it will not leak to a third party.</li>
<li>Exceptions to client confidentiality: Where the information,</li>
<li>was given and received to perpetuate a crime or fraud;</li>
<li>is needed to prevent certain death or serious bodily harm or to establish a claim; or</li>
<li>is for the defence of the advocate in a controversy between the advocate and the client</li>
<li>Has resulted in a client's perjury as stated in the case of <em>Hunt v Blackburn</em> (1888).</li>
<li>This duty however applies only where legal advice is sought from a professional legal adviser in his capacity as such, when the communications relating to that purpose made in confidence by the client, from disclosure by himself or by the legal adviser, except the protection be waived</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-client-s-best-interest">iii. Client's best interest<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-client-s-best-interest" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>An advocate should always put the best interest of his client first.</li>
<li>There should be no conflict of interest.</li>
<li>Where there is a conflict, the advocate should disqualify himself from acting or advising the client.</li>
<li>Similarly, in counseling, the advocate should not only open options that would be beneficial to him.</li>
<li>One should give both advantages and disadvantages of the advice.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-duty-to-listen">iv. Duty to listen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-duty-to-listen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Listening is a virtue that is learnt.</li>
<li>An advocate should be a good listener.</li>
<li>Good listening will encourage the client to give the important information that is needed by the advocate.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-duty-not-to-decide-for-the-client">v. Duty not to decide for the client<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-duty-not-to-decide-for-the-client" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Even where a client insists that the advocate should decide for him/her, the advocate MUST NOT.</li>
<li>The advocate should elaborately open up options and let the client decide.</li>
<li>If the advocate decides for a client, he/she may be setting up himself/herself for a blame in case of an undesirable outcome.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>(g) Forms of client counseling</p>
<p>i. Transactional counseling: this is the form of counseling on how to structure deals/transactions (especially commercial) with other organizations and how to conduct their affairs so as to minimize the taxes and legal liability of the organizational and individual clients.</p>
<p>ii. Dispute resolution counseling: This is counseling and advice on litigation issues, and would include pre-litigation where the advocate advises the client whether a law suit or alternative dispute resolution mechanisms are necessary. Dispute resolution counseling also includes the strategy in litigation or alternative dispute resolution (whichever is adopted by the client).</p>
<p>INSTRUCTIONS TO ACT</p>
<ul>
<li>Instructions can mean the authority of a client or a prospective client to an advocate to pursue litigation.</li>
<li>The authority with a request to act on his behalf in legal matters.</li>
<li>The information given by a prospective or actual client to a lawyer to act, on the basis of which the advocate acts on behalf of the client.</li>
<li>Instructions are the inception of any legal process. It is a very delicate process and how the client is treated will affect whether or not they opt to retain you and also the quality of instructions you receive.</li>
<li>There are two ways of receiving a client by an advocate:</li>
</ul>
<p>i. Sitting at the desk as the client walks in – may show that the client is busy, but appears crude and high handed. NEVER make a client get the impression that you are too important to them. This can only be remedied by standing up as they walk in and giving them a warm greeting. Alternatively, meet the client at the door and escort them to the seat.</p>
<p>ii. It is preferable to fetch the client from the reception yourself. Give them a warm greeting and develop small-talk as you escort them to your office. Make the atmosphere as relaxed as possible for the client. Make them feel wanted. Continue with the small talk for a little while depending on their demeanour. Then, find a nice way to get into the matter at hand. Sometimes, you can make recognition of the fact that they are in a hurry...merge the small talk into the issue at hand.</p>
<p>a) The matter at hand</p>
<ul>
<li>The question-answer method of obtaining instructions is not always very effective in getting the story. Restrict your questions to the minimum and encourage them to talk more.</li>
<li>The questions should only be for quick clarifications.</li>
<li>Do the listening – encouraging them to go on with the story. Be warm and put them at ease.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>Make quick clarifications, being careful not to ask leading questions.</li>
<li>Ask questions to fill in gaps in the story.</li>
<li>Take down key points including areas for clarification – make sure the client is comfortable with your note taking. In the process, never lose eye contact with the client.</li>
<li>You may use a recorder but make sure it is one that will not disrupt the proceedings, and also make sure they are comfortable with that form of recording.</li>
<li>Watch the body language of the client. This will help you form an opinion on what the client is saying. This will enable you to note matters that are key, those that make the client uncomfortable, matters they are leaving out, etc.</li>
<li>Put the points in a logical order in writing – this can be done afterwards.</li>
<li>You may repeat the story to the client confirming its correctness. The written version should be sent to the client for clarification and approval. When returning it, the client should sign it.</li>
<li>Where a conflict of interest arises, it is important to let the client know and advise them to go to another advocate.</li>
<li>Form a preliminary classification of what the case is. This is to enable you ask the right questions based on the legal requirements.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pre-trial-preliminary-considerations">PRE-TRIAL PRELIMINARY CONSIDERATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pre-trial-preliminary-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="considerations">Considerations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>i. Determining the Existence of a Cause of Action
ii. Time limitation
iii. Feasibility of the Law Suit
iv. Turning Down a Case
v. Ethical Consideration in Accepting a Case
vi. Ethical Consideration after Accepting a Case</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="objective">Objective<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#objective" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>i. Explain the importance of a cause of action to the litigation process.
ii. List the reasons why an advocate must be familiar with the elements of a cause of action.
iii. Define the various types of time limitations on filing a lawsuit.
iv. List the practical considerations that affect the decision to accept a case.
v. Explain the procedure for turning down a case.
vi. Identify the ethical standards an advocate must consider before accepting a case.
vii. Identify the ethical requirements for an advocate during the course of litigation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-determining-the-existence-of-a-cause-of-action">1. Determining the Existence of a Cause of Action<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-determining-the-existence-of-a-cause-of-action" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Not all issues determined in a client interview are resolved through litigation process.</li>
<li>A legal right must exist.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>This legally recognized right to relief is known as a cause of action.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cause-of-action">Cause of action.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cause-of-action" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Facts sufficient to support a valid suit...</li>
<li>The legal theory upon which a lawsuit ("action") is based; In the pleadings this will include:
a) the pertinent facts distinct in each situation;
b) the particulars (if any) which relate to the actions of the defendant; and
c) The reaction of the plaintiff in relation to the acts of the defendant that caused the plaintiff to incur a loss or to be damaged.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example">Example<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Suppose that Juma drives his motorcycle negligently and fails to stop at a stop sign. He is hit by Somi, who is driving in accordance with all traffic laws, in a careful and prudent manner. Juma is the only one injured in the accident. Can Juma recover his damages from Somi?</p>
<ul>
<li>In determining whether a cause of action exists, you must examine both the law and the facts in the case.</li>
<li>First, you must determine what general area of substantive law applies to the case.</li>
<li>Second, the general substantive law area of law must be narrowed and a more specific topic identified.</li>
<li>Then you can examine that specific area and determine what factors or elements must be present before a cause of action is created.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example-kombo-case">Example: Kombo Case<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example-kombo-case" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Seven months ago June Kombo was injured in an automobile-bus collision. The accident occurred when the brakes on the bus failed, resulting in the driver's inability to stop for a red light. The bus, in which Kombo was a passenger, was hit broadside by a car entering the intersection at the green light. The bus was owned and operated by the city.</p>
<p>However, all maintenance on the bus was performed by Allied Auto Repair, a private company under contract with the city to maintain and repair all city buses. Kombo has requested that your firm represent her in a personal injury lawsuit for injuries she sustained in the accident. Your pupil-master has requested that you do some preliminary research to determine whether this lawsuit should be accepted and, if so, whether any immediate action must be undertaken.</p>
<p>The Kombo case is controlled by the substantive law of torts. More specifically, it is covered by the tort of negligence.</p>
<ul>
<li>A review of the law of negligence reveals that for one to have a cause of action, the following elements must be shown:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>The defendant must have a duty of due care toward the victim.</li>
<li>That duty must have been breached (by a careless act).</li>
<li>The defendant's careless act must be the actual cause of the damages.</li>
</ol>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>The defendant's careless act must be the proximate cause of the damages (i.e., the damages must be foreseeable).</li>
<li>Damages must have been sustained.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Once the elements of a cause of action have been ascertained, the final step in determining whether a cause of action exists in a particular case is to review the case itself to see if facts exist that support each of the elements.</li>
<li>In determining whether Kombo has a cause of action in negligence against Allied Auto Repair, the analysis might go as follows:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>An auto repair company owes a duty of care to all users of vehicles that it maintains or repairs. Because Kombo was a passenger on the bus, Allied owed her a duty of due care.</li>
<li>If the bus has been properly maintained, the brakes would not have failed. Thus, there is some evidence of the breach of the duty owed to the users of that bus.</li>
<li>If the brakes had not failed, the accident would not have happened. Allied's failure to properly maintain the brakes is, therefore, the actual cause of Kombo's injuries</li>
<li>Kombo's injuries were a foreseeable consequence of Allied's actions. This establishes proximate or legal causation.</li>
<li>Kombo has sustained injuries and incurred expenses, thus establishing damages.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Because each of the elements of the cause of action is supported by facts, the conclusion is that Kombo does have a cause of action against Allied Auto repair for negligence.</li>
<li>Identifying the elements of a cause of action is important in the litigation process for various reasons.</li>
<li>Most important is that each of the elements must be proven at trial for the plaintiff to prevail.</li>
<li>That is, to win a case the advocate must present evidence that supports each element of the cause of action.</li>
<li>Also, the initial pleadings must allege facts that support each element of the cause of action.</li>
<li>Knowing the elements of a cause of action in a particular case is essential to any litigation lawyer in undertaking pre-trial preparation.</li>
<li>Understanding what you must prove at trial enables you to gather appropriate evidence and conduct relevant discovery.</li>
<li>It also equips you to prepare pleadings that comply with legal requirements and to review opposing pleadings for legal deficiencies.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-time-limitations">2. Time Limitations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-time-limitations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="statute-of-limitations">Statute of Limitations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#statute-of-limitations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Unless a case is filed within the appropriate statute of limitations, it will be dismissed, regardless of the merits of the case.</li>
<li>Only the court's discretion can be exercised to revive such a case, with sufficient cause shown to explain delay.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="how-calculated">How Calculated?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-calculated" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The time limitations are usually easily calculated.</li>
<li>For example, a plaintiff might have three years from the date of the accident in which to file an action for personal injuries.</li>
<li>Because the date of the accident is easily determined from the police reports and witnesses, the statute of limitations is calculated with no difficulty.</li>
<li>However, in some cases, time limitations are not easily determined.</li>
<li>For example, in professional malpractice cases or in fraud cases, the statute of limitations might start to run not from the date of the malpractice or fraudulent act, but from the date that the plaintiff discovers or should have discovered the malpractice or fraud.</li>
<li>Sometimes this is years after the defendant’s wrongdoing.</li>
<li>This kind of statute of limitations often presents numerous legal and factual questions, and proving the date on which the plaintiff discovered or should have discovered the wrongdoing becomes an important part of the trial process.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calculating-the-statute-of-limitations">Calculating the statute of limitations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calculating-the-statute-of-limitations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>In calculating the statute of limitations you do not count the first day, but you count the last day.</li>
<li>Thus if you are filing a lawsuit for injuries from an automobile accident and the accident happens on Friday, January 28, 2012, you begin counting on January 29, 2012.</li>
<li>Assuming that you have a three year statute of limitations, it would run out on Wednesday, January 28, 2015, and your complaint would have to be filed by that date.</li>
<li>However, if that day is a court holiday, you would have until the next court day to file your complaint.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="limitation-of-actions">Limitation of Actions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#limitation-of-actions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>One should consider whether the action sought to be commenced is caught up within the provisions of Cap 22, e.g. limitation of actions:</li>
<li>in defamation is one year,</li>
<li>against state corporations is one year,</li>
<li>against the Government (vide the Govt Proceedings Act) is one year,</li>
<li>in tort is three years,</li>
<li>in contract is six years,</li>
<li>in land matters generally, is twelve years.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tolling-the-statute-of-limitations">Tolling the statute of limitations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tolling-the-statute-of-limitations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Some events will sometimes toll or extend the statute of limitations.</li>
<li>When a statute is tolled, the time stops running.</li>
<li>The most common reason a statute of limitations is tolled is that the plaintiff is a minor.</li>
<li>The statute is tolled during the minority of the plaintiff and begins to run once the minor reaches the age of majority.</li>
<li>Don’t assume, however, that the statute of limitations is always tolled during a child’s minority. You must check the appropriate statutory law.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="claim-statute">Claim Statute<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#claim-statute" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Most of the civil suits are guided by the Civil procedure Rules, 2010.</li>
<li>This rules require that a written claim be presented to the defendant before a lawsuit can be filed.</li>
<li>Some statutes, for example the Government Proceedings Act require that a 30 day notice be given to the Government (s.13A(1) cap40) (See <em>Kenya Bus Services Ltd &amp; another v Minister for Transport &amp; 2 others [2012] eKLR</em>)</li>
<li>Naturally, there are time limits for presenting the claim.</li>
<li>They require that the prospective defendant be notified that a claim is pending, who is making the claim, what the claim is for and the amount of the claim. The party then has the opportunity to pay the claim before any lawsuit is filed.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laches">Laches<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laches" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Equitable cases (cases in which the plaintiff is asking for something other than money damages) are governed by another limitation known as <strong>laches</strong>.</li>
<li>Laches is an equitable principle that prevents lawsuits from being filed when, in fairness to the defendant, too much time has elapsed, even though the statute of limitations has not expired.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example">EXAMPLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>For example, suppose Njeri and Ouma sign a written contract in which Ouma agrees to sell his house to Njeri for 3.5 million. For various reasons, Ouma changes his mind and refuses to complete the sale. Rather than sue on the contract, Njeri finds another house for the same price and takes no immediate legal action against Ouma.</p>
<p>Three years later, however, after a surge in the real estate market, Njeri decides to do something. Ouma’s house is now worth 15 million, and Njeri assumes she can purchase the house for the contract price of 3.5 million, and can immediately sell it and make a large profit. She therefore sues Ouma for specific performance of the agreement. Assuming the statute of limitation is six years.</p>
<ul>
<li>Technically, the complaint could have been filed within the indicative time duration of limitation. However, with regard to fairness and equity, Njeri waited too long to file her action.</li>
<li>Thus laches could prevent her from prevailing in her action</li>
<li>Remember laches applies only in equitable cases.</li>
<li>If Njeri sued Ouma for money damages for breach of contract, and the appropriate statute of limitations had not expired, then fairness and equity will not be a bar.</li>
<li>Njeri’s claim for damages would be the difference between the contract price and the fair market value of the house at the time the contract was to be performed and not at the date that the action was filed.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tickler-systems">Tickler Systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tickler-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Missing a statute of limitations can result in a malpractice claim against the law firm.</li>
<li>Therefore, most litigation firms have calendar or tracking systems to remind them of these or other important dates.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>These calendaring systems are known as tickler systems.</li>
<li>This involves documenting the case files for bring ups, when the matter is for filing or as a notice of any other issues to be attended to on the file.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-feasibility-of-the-lawsuit">3. Feasibility of the Lawsuit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-feasibility-of-the-lawsuit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Even though you may determine that a case has merit you may nevertheless decide that the lawsuit is not practical.</li>
<li>Litigation takes a great deal of time and can cost a great deal of money, not only in advocate fees, but in costs.</li>
<li>Before an advocate accepts a case, he should always review it to see if it is practical.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-turning-down-a-case">4. Turning Down a Case<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-turning-down-a-case" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>If an advocate decides not to accept a case, he must clearly communicate this to the concerned individual.</li>
<li>This should be done in writing so that there is a record of the fact.</li>
<li>In turning down a case, an advocate must exercise care in stating an opinion regarding the merits of the case to the individual.</li>
