<li>It is also advisable to warn the person about any possible statute of limitations.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="example">EXAMPLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Mr. Mlalamishi
21 City Square
Nairobi County</p>
<p>Dear Mr. Mlalamishi</p>
<p>Thank you for considering us regarding your dispute with ABC Corporation. As I explained to you on telephone, our law firm is presently unable to represent you in this matter. Please note that our inability to accept your case is not a reflection or comment on the merits of your case.</p>
<p>If you wish to pursue this matter you should consult other legal advice. If you decide to do so, you should act as soon as possible.</p>
<p>As we have previously explained to you, the statute of limitations in this kind of cases is three years from the date of injury. If you have not filed a lawsuit within that time you will be prevented from doing so.</p>
<p>Thanking you for considering us.
Regards.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-ethical-considerations-in-accepting-a-case">5. Ethical Considerations in accepting a Case<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-ethical-considerations-in-accepting-a-case" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is based on the Rules of Professional Conduct and involves:</li>
</ul>
<p>i. Competency to handle the case.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>The advocate should not accept a case if he does not possess the ability, knowledge, or time to handle it. The advocate can also not ignore the case once he has accepted it.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-frivolous-claims">ii. Frivolous claims<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-frivolous-claims" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Lawsuits that have no merit should not be pursued.</li>
<li>If the advocate handles a frivolous case, he risks being sued himself by the defendant in the action, in addition to subjecting himself to disciplinary proceedings by the Disciplinary Tribunal.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-conflict-of-interest">iii. Conflict of Interest<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-conflict-of-interest" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Conflict of interest usually arises when a firm is asked to sue a party whom it currently represents or previously represented in another case (although not always)</li>
<li>The conflict of interest is directed to whether the matter currently handled is in congruence and directly detrimental to the interests of the client or former client in the erstwhile matter.</li>
<li>A conflict is determined by whom the firm represents, rather than by whom any particular advocate in the firm represents.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-ethical-considerations-after-accepting-a-case">6. Ethical Considerations after Accepting a Case<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-ethical-considerations-after-accepting-a-case" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-communication-with-the-client">i. Communication with the Client<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-communication-with-the-client" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Lawyers owe a duty to their clients to keep them advised about the status of their cases.</li>
<li>Failure of lawyers to do this is the basis of one of the most common complaints against advocates.</li>
<li>You should establish some procedure for regularly advising the client about the status of their action.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-communication-with-the-opposing-party">ii. Communication with the Opposing Party<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-communication-with-the-opposing-party" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>It is unethical for an advocate to personally contact an opposing party who is represented by their own advocate.</li>
<li>However, if the opposing party is not represented by counsel, communication is allowed.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-confidentiality">iii. Confidentiality<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-confidentiality" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Communication between a client and an advocate is confidential.</li>
<li>The advocate is prohibited from disclosing any information revealed to him by his client</li>
<li>The right of the client is also upheld under Chapter 4, the Bill of Rights-Article 31(d) which states that every person has a right to privacy, which includes the right not to have the privacy of their communications infringed.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iv-honesty">iv. Honesty<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-honesty" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>An advocate must never knowingly make a false representation about a case to a court or other tribunal.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>In addition to honesty with the court, advocates should always be honest in their dealings with other advocates.</li>
</ul>
<p>v. Advocate fees</p>
<ul>
<li>The fees should not be unreasonable or unconscionable</li>
<li>Fee arrangement, including any additional expenses, should be clearly explained to the client.</li>
<li>The litigation fee can be either set at a flat fee, or fixed sum, to handle the case or in a hourly billing, where the client is charged a fixed amount for each hour the law firm spends on the case.</li>
<li>There can also be a contingent fee, a common arrangement in personal injury cases.</li>
<li>In the contingent fee agreement the advocate takes a percentage of whatever recovery is obtained.</li>
<li>If no recovery is made, the advocate receives no fee.</li>
<li>Contingent fees have been allowed on the theory that they permit people to pursue cases they could not afford otherwise.</li>
<li>A fee is the compensation that an advocate receives for his time and efforts in a case.</li>
<li>However, it is not the only expense incurred during a litigation process.</li>
<li>Courts require filing fees to process documents, process servers have to be paid to serve papers.</li>
<li>These are out-of-pocket expenses known as disbursement costs.</li>
<li>Most advocates require their clients to pay the costs of the suit in addition to the fee charged.</li>
<li>Even if the case is handled on contingent fee basis. Here the advocate can advance the requisite fees and expect a reimbursement in addition to his fee when the case is settled. This should be made clear to the client.</li>
<li>There are several fee related issues that one needs to note these are</li>
</ul>
<p>(a) Written Fee Agreements</p>
<ul>
<li>The fee agreement between the client and the advocate should always be in writing and signed by the client.</li>
<li>The fee agreement is usually included in a document referred to as a retainer agreement.</li>
</ul>
<p>(b) Fee Sharing</p>
<ul>
<li>Generally, an advocate cannot share a fee in a case with a non-lawyer. (s.37, cap16)</li>
</ul>
<p>(c) Property of Client - Trust Accounts</p>
<ul>
<li>See the case of Kamau John Kinyanjui v. R [2010] eKLR</li>
<li>An advocate cannot commingle his own assets or property with property belonging to a client.</li>
<li>The advocate should have a trust account into which they deposit all money belonging to their clients</li>
<li>In litigation, trust accounts are utilized for two main purposes – advances by the client and settlement or satisfaction of judgments</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>In the latter case the settlement cheque is primarily the property of the client, however, the advocate has lien against the settlement.</li>
<li>But he cannot put it into his personal account. It can only go to the trust account.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="exercise">EXERCISE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exercise" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Determine the cause of action in the following:</p>
<ol>
<li>Caleb and Luta enter into a written agreement whereby Caleb agrees to purchase Luta's house. Prior to signing the agreement, Caleb asked Luta about the condition of the roof, Luta tells Caleb that the roof is in good repair. In fact, Luta recently had a roof inspection done and was told that the roof was in terrible condition and should be replaced immediately. Shortly after Caleb moves into the premises, a storm occurs and the roof leaks in several places.</li>
<li>Edward buys a pre-assembled student desk for his son. When an overhead light goes out in his son's room, Edward stands on the desk to reach the light. The desk collapses and Edward is injured.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-demand-letter-before-action">THE DEMAND LETTER BEFORE ACTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-demand-letter-before-action" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="what-is-a-demand-letter">What is a demand letter?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-is-a-demand-letter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>A demand letter is a formal notice demanding that the addressee perform a legal obligation, such as rectifying a problem, paying a sum of money or honouring a contractual commitment, on specific terms and within a specified time.</li>
<li>The letter gives the recipient a chance to perform the obligation without being taken to court</li>
</ul>
<p>In certain types of legal proceedings, a demand letter is mandatory.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="scope-of-demand-letter">Scope of Demand Letter<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#scope-of-demand-letter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Where it is pleaded a demand is required to be made as a matter of law.</li>
<li>It is a letter sent to the person against whom a grievance is raised</li>
<li>It is sent before the commencement of the suit</li>
<li>The letter is intended to elicit a payment or compliance from the part of the prospective defendant</li>
<li>It serves to inform the adversary of a pending claim</li>
<li>The adversary is given a time-frame within which a response is required</li>
<li>A demand letter may be written by the person seeking redress or by a lawyer on that person's behalf.</li>
<li>A copy is made and the original must be sent in a way that provides proof of delivery.</li>
<li>It can be sent by registered mail.</li>
<li>It can also be served by a registered legal clerk</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="purpose-of-the-demand-letter">Purpose of the Demand Letter<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#purpose-of-the-demand-letter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The purpose of a demand letter and notices prior to litigation is to afford both parties an opportunity to avoid embarking on unnecessary litigation or incurring additional costs, especially within the context of our overburdened judiciary and the reality of a constricted economy. Today, it is a very important step in legal proceedings.</li>
<li>It also serves as notice to the other party, that there is an issue against them.</li>
<li>It offers parties a chance to settle the matter out of court.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="out-of-court-settlement">Out of Court Settlement<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#out-of-court-settlement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Important because it is required by the Constitution of Kenya, 2010, as an alternative solution, Article 159 (2)</li>
<li>It’s expeditious, allegedly.</li>
<li>Allegedly cost-effective</li>
<li>Privacy</li>
<li>Amicable way of solving disputes ...win-win situation</li>
<li>Maintain a business relationship/peace</li>
<li>Flexibility, the parties choose arbitrator/mediator/etc...parties choose their judge</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="demand-letter-mandatory">Demand letter mandatory<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#demand-letter-mandatory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>In most types of legal proceedings, especially civil suits guided by the Civil Procedure Rules, 2010, a demand letter is mandatory.</li>
<li>Where it is pleaded a demand is required to be made as a matter of law. (O3, r2 (d)).</li>
<li>Where it is excluded, a party may not be able to claim for costs in the suit.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reasons-for-making-formal-demand">Reasons for making formal demand<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reasons-for-making-formal-demand" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It is usually advisable as per the Advocates Practice Rules so as to avoid incurring additional costs of suit should the claim be admitted by the other party</li>
<li>If the demand letter achieves its results, litigation is avoided</li>
<li>To avoid suits that may be vexatious or brought out of malice.</li>
<li>To give notice of intention to right a wrong against a legal right</li>
<li>However, it may be preferable not to give the debtor warning through the demand letter especially if he’s a flight risk (to be discussed later)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="contents-of-a-demand-letter">Contents of a demand letter<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contents-of-a-demand-letter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(a) A date, the recipient’s contact information, and the legal phrase WITHOUT PREJUDICE to protect the sender with regard to the contents of the letter
(b) The authority to act for the claimant
(c) A summary of the matter in issue
(d) A demand for a specific relief or payment
(e) A deadline by which the matter must be settled
(f) Consequences of non-adherence to the demand of claim
(g) The term demand letter stated in the body of the letter to direct the recipient to act accordingly</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="what-should-be-included-in-a-demand-letter">What should be included in a demand letter?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-should-be-included-in-a-demand-letter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>a clear intimation that payment is required...it must be of a peremptory character and unconditional...' as per <em>Re Colonial Finance, mortgage &amp; Investment &amp; Guarantee Corporation Limited</em> (1905) 6 S.R.N.S.W. 6</li>
<li>Under the Law Society of Kenya Digest of Professional Conduct and Etiquette (1982 Edn Revised 2000) on Paragraph 19, the period a party must normally be given to respond to a letter of demand:</li>
<li>i. 7 days, where debtor resides in the same town as advocate,</li>
<li>ii. Not less than 10 days, where he resides in a different town in Kenya,</li>
<li>iii. 15 days, where he resides outside East Africa</li>
<li>Note: A demand letter should be signed by an advocate. Why?</li>
<li>i. It is a document that is chargeable under the Advocates (Remuneration) Order, 2009 and therefore attracts the prohibition u/ss 34 &amp; 35 Advocates Act, cap 16, i.e., not to be drawn by an unqualified person, or remuneration thereof accepted by an unqualified person.</li>
<li>ii. Further, signing in the name of the firm is not sufficient as it is not safe – it may lay the demand letter open to challenge as not being given either by the party or by an advocate as his representative on his behalf. See <em>Singh v Munshi Ram</em> (1937) 4 EACA 9</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="what-should-not-be-included-in-a-demand-letter">What should not be included in a demand letter?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-should-not-be-included-in-a-demand-letter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A threat that criminal proceedings would be initiated against the debtor in event of non-payment. See <em>Khanbhai v O'Swald</em> (1933) 15 KLR 53</li>
<li>Letter of demand may not demand from the debtor the costs of the advocate giving notice – there is both a statutory and professional bar to making such a demand. See Rule 13, Advocates (Practice) Rules subsidiary legislation to the Advocates Act, cap 16 and Under the Law Society of Kenya Digest of Professional Conduct and Etiquette (1982 Edn Revised 2000) on Paragraph 19.</li>
<li>But, if subsequent to the original letter of demand, the debtor requests to be allowed to make payment of demand sum by installments, and these terms are accepted, then it is permissible to add the advocate’s costs to the principal sum owing.</li>
<li>This must be done at the time of accepting the proposal of payment by installments.</li>
<li>This is permissible because fresh consideration is being given by the creditor, for adding those costs to the principal amount.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-considerations">Other considerations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-considerations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It must be kept in mind that the demand letter or notice will later become highly relevant in subsequent applications and hearings in the suit, as well as to an assessment of the conduct of parties. See <em>Mbogo v Shah</em> (1968) EA 94</li>
<li>Court shall order particulars of notice; Express provision is made in the Civil Procedure Rules, 2010 for a court to order that particulars of any notice pleaded to be supplied to the opposite party.</li>
<li>Where the plaint is at variance with the demand letter, particulars in explanation must be given by the plaintiff. See <em>Abdulla v Esmail</em> (1969) EA 111 a and <em>Jared Benson</em></li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>Kangwana v Attorney-General (unreported) HC Misc. Civil Application No. 446 of 1995</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="when-demand-letter-would-not-be-advisable">When demand letter would not be advisable<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#when-demand-letter-would-not-be-advisable" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. Anton Pillar Order
ii. Mareva Injunction
iii. Initial application for this is usually made ex parte without notice to the defendant
iv. Knowledge by defendant that the application is pending may defeat the very object which the plaintiff is trying to achieve, through dissipation of the subject matter of the suit, or removal of assets of the debtor from the courts jurisdiction, etc. A demand letter would obviously adversely affect the element of surprise and thus the efficacy of the court orders.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="without-prejudice-communication">Without Prejudice communication<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#without-prejudice-communication" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Upon reply the person who is being claimed against will quote the legal phrase "WITHOUT PREJUDICE" to protect the sender with regard to the contents of the letter. See Millicent Wambui v Nairobi Botanica Gardening Limited [2013]eKLR Cause No. 2512 of 2012</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="scope-of-the-protection">Scope of the protection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#scope-of-the-protection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The protection goes only insofar as protecting the communication between parties that genuinely attempts to resolve the disputes between the parties</li>
<li>The doctrine protects admissions, concessions or offers made by parties in communication</li>
<li>The words 'without prejudice' impose upon the communication an exclusion of use against the party making the statement in subsequent court proceedings.</li>
<li>A party making a 'without prejudice' offer does so on the basis that they reserve the right to assert their original position, if the offer is rejected and litigation ensues</li>
<li>However, the 'without prejudice' communication could be admissible if the issue was whether or not the negotiation resulted in an agreed settlement</li>
<li>Without prejudice means that you are making offers and counter offers and the negotiations are unsuccessful and they go to court, they should not be used to prove anything in court. See Section 23 (1) of Evidence Act.</li>
<li>Based on public policy that matters should be settled out there and not burden court system</li>
<li>Exceptions (where without prejudice communication can be produced as evidence):</li>
<li>i. Where the parties consent to the production of the without prejudice doc in court (where there is waiver).</li>
<li>ii. IN cases of fraud and concealment</li>
<li>iii. To prove reasonable action, to explain delay...delay defeats equity/aids the vigilant</li>
<li>Without prejudice communication may be implied from the letter of offer to settle matter (n/b: not demand letter). The reply to this offer does not have to have the without prejudice statement on it, it is implied from the first letter already.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sample-1-intention-to-sue-in-an-accident-case">SAMPLE 1 (INTENTION TO SUE IN AN ACCIDENT CASE)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sample-1-intention-to-sue-in-an-accident-case" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>«REFNO»
«OWNER»</p>
<p>«DATE»</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="registered">REGISTERED<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#registered" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>RE: ACCIDENT ON «DATEOFACC»
ALONG «ROAD» ROAD NEAR «NEAR»,
INVOLVING MOTOR VEHICLE REGISTRATION MARK «REGNO»
CLAIMANT: «INJURED»</p>
<p>We have been instructed by our client, the above named injured person to write to you and address you as hereunder:-</p>
<p>THAT on or about the «DATEOFACC» the said «INJURED» was lawfully walking along the verge of «ROAD» road when near «NEAR» or thereabout your driver, agent or servant in the course of his employment with you, so negligently drove, managed and or controlled your motor vehicle registration mark «REGNO» that he caused or permitted it violently to collide with our client and to knock «HIMHER» down to the ground.</p>
<p>As a result of the said collision, our client sustained severe bodily injuries and had to be hospitalized thereby suffering loss and damages.</p>
<p>It is our instructions therefore to <strong>Demand</strong> from you as we <strong>Hereby Do</strong>, an immediate admission of liability in damages to our client. Once we have your admission of liability, we shall go into the question of quantum of damages payable.</p>
<p>Please <strong>TAKE NOTICE</strong> and be advised that unless we receive your admission of liability within the next <strong>TWENTY-ONE (21) DAYS</strong> from the date hereof, we have instructions to file legal proceedings against you for the recovery of damages at your own risk as to costs and further consequences arising therefrom.</p>
<p>Since you are <strong>insured</strong> against accidents of this nature we suggest that you forward this letter to <strong>your INSURERS</strong> with the request that they communicate with us directly concerning this accident within the above stated number of days so that this claim may be settled with <strong>minimum expense and inconvenience to you</strong>.</p>
<p>Yours faithfully,</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>for: ROMBO &amp; COMPANY ADVOCATES. The full details of the claim are well within your knowledge. In an attempt to settle the said claim, you issued to our client various cheques Number drawn in favor of NNNN Limited. The said cheques drawn by you were presented by our clients for payment on various occasions and were upon presentation returned unpaid. You have since then flagrantly and blatantly neglected, ignored, refused and or otherwise failed to satisfy the amounts covered by the cheque namely, Kshs. 2,525,730/=, as previously agreed and mutually scheduled by the parties hereto. Our instructions are that the said sum of Kshs. 2,525,730/=, still remains owing and continues to attract interest until payment in full. TAKE NOTICE that if we do not receive the said sum of Kshs. 2,525,730/=, in cash or by banker's cheque at the expiry of FIFTEEN (15) DAYS from the date of service of this letter, we have mandated instructions to institute legal action against you for the amount owed and the costs of the subsequent dishonour of the said Cheques, without any further reference to you and at your own risk as to costs and expenses and other incidentals of such action. FURTHER please treat this as the Written Notice of Dishonour as contemplated by Section of 48 and of the Bills of Exchange Act, Chapter 27 of the Laws of Kenya.</td></tr></tbody></table>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lecture-3-tuesday-1st-march-2016-morning-session-lecture-hall-a">LECTURE 3: TUESDAY 1ST MARCH 2016- MORNING SESSION (LECTURE HALL A)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lecture-3-tuesday-1st-march-2016-morning-session-lecture-hall-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="topic-3-courts-structure-and-jurisdiction-of-courts">TOPIC 3: COURTS STRUCTURE AND JURISDICTION OF COURTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#topic-3-courts-structure-and-jurisdiction-of-courts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="topic-3-courts-structure-and-jurisdiction">TOPIC 3: Courts Structure and Jurisdiction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#topic-3-courts-structure-and-jurisdiction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(NB: Originally as per the course outline this topic was Courts and commencement of suits I have moved commencement of suits to topic five for my own convenience)</p>
<p>(a) Jurisdictional Court Structure
(b) Choice of appropriate court determined by certain factors:</p>
<p>(i) Jurisdictional considerations, i.e.,</p>
<ul>
<li>Constitutional conferment of jurisdiction</li>
<li>Statutory</li>
<li>Territorial</li>
<li>Functional</li>
<li>Subject matter</li>
<li>Islamic or customary law matter</li>
<li>Monetary limits</li>
<li>Whether defendant is reachable</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="topic-objectives">Topic Objectives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#topic-objectives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>By the end of the discussion of this topic and the relevant readings a student should be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>distinguish between forum and jurisdiction</li>
<li>identify the court structure in Kenya</li>
<li>determine the factors that guide choice of jurisdiction</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reading">Reading:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reading" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Peter Nganga Muiruri v. Credit Bank LTD &amp; 2 others [2008] eKLR</p>
<p>Mathias Were Diffu v. Pascal Nafuodo Ojwang[2007] eKLR</p>
<p>Articles 23, 58, 163, 164 and 165 of the Constitution of Kenya, 2010.</p>

<p>Supreme Court Petition Number 4 of 2012 – Jasbir Singh Rai&amp; Others vs Tarlochan Singh Rai&amp; Others
Supreme Court Petition Nos. 5,4&amp;3 of 2013 Raila Odinga&amp; 2 others v Independent Electoral &amp; Boundaries Commission &amp; 3 others [2013] Eklr Supreme Court Petition Number 27 of 2014 – Yusuf Gitau Abdallah vs The Building Centre (K) Ltd

<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="jurisdiction">JURISDICTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#jurisdiction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Kenya has courts at different levels. At each level the court has power to hear and determine cases. This is what is always known as a court's jurisdiction.</li>
<li>Jurisdiction is a creature of statute and therefore the powers of the court are provided by statute.</li>
<li>Jurisdiction is not a matter between the parties. However, any party to the proceedings may raise it or bring it to the attention of the court with the view that the court strikes out the matter. This is normally so if the question of jurisdiction is raised by the defendant. The parties however need not raise it of their own.</li>
<li>The court on its own motion may determine if it has jurisdiction. If it finds that it does not have jurisdiction, it must not proceed to hear the case.</li>
<li>Any power exercised out of jurisdiction of any given court is ultra vires. See Wilson Kinyanja v Owori CA 36 of 1998 [2001] Eklr</li>
<li>The locus clasicus for jurisdiction is The Owners of the Motor Vessel "Lillian S" V. Caltex Oil (Kenya) Ltd., Civil Appeal No. 50 of 1989</li>
</ul>
<p>The Owners of the Motor Vessel "Lillian S" V. Caltex Oil (Kenya) Ltd., Civil Appeal No. 50 of 1989</p>
<p>Nyarangi J.A. said of jurisdiction-</p>
<p>"I think that it is reasonably plain that a question of jurisdiction ought to be raised at the earliest opportunity and the court seized of the matter is then obliged to decide the issue right away on the material before it. Jurisdiction is everything. Without it, a court has no power to make one step. Where a court has no jurisdiction, there would be no basis for a continuation of proceedings pending other evidence. A court of law downs its tools in respect of the matter before it the moment it holds the opinion that it is without jurisdiction..."</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="jurisdictional-requirements">Jurisdictional Requirements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#jurisdictional-requirements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>In Milkah Nanyokia Masungo v. Robert Wekesa Mwembe &amp; 2 Others [2013] eKLR, the court was of the view that jurisdiction is everything and, without it, the court must down tools once it comes to the conclusion that it is lacking.</li>
<li>When filing a suit, a party ought to identify the jurisdiction of a court, which can either be territorial or pecuniary.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-territorial-jurisdiction">a) Territorial Jurisdiction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-territorial-jurisdiction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Territorial jurisdiction refers to a court's power over events and persons within the bounds of a particular geographical territory whereas pecuniary jurisdiction refers to the amount the court is supposed to award at the conclusion of the suit and, by this, the court has first to ascertain whether it is supposed to try the suit; if not, then it has no competent jurisdiction.</li>
<li>For a defendant in Kenya to be subject to a suit, he must be within the jurisdiction of that court.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>Hence, when filing a suit one must identify the court with the proper territorial and pecuniary jurisdiction</li>
<li>According to Section 12 of the Civil Procedure Act (Cap. 21, Laws of Kenya), a suit in Kenya is ordinarily instituted where the defendant resides or carries on business, or personally works for gain.</li>
<li>Section 15 of the Civil Procedure Act (Cap. 21, Laws of Kenya) sets out the factors to be considered in determining which jurisdiction a defendant is to submit to in a civil suit, which are:
i. where the defendant or each of the defendants (where there are more than one) at the time of the commencement of the suit, actually and voluntarily resides or carries on business, or personally works for gain; or
ii. where any of the defendants (where there are more than one) at the time of the commencement of the suit, actually and voluntarily resides or carries on business, or personally works for gain, provided either the leave of the court is given, or the defendants who do not reside or carry on business, or personally work for gain, as aforesaid, acquiesce to such jurisdiction; or
iii. where the cause of action, wholly or in part, arises.</li>
<li>Where the suit is for immovable property, one must consider the following:
i. Where the property is situated in Kenya, the suit shall be instituted in the court within the local limits of the jurisdiction in which the property is situated, or within the local limits of the jurisdiction where the defendant actually and voluntarily resides or carries on business, or personally works for gain.
ii. Where a suit is in respect of, or for compensation for, wrong to immovable property situated within the jurisdiction of different courts, the suit may be instituted in any court within the local limits of whose jurisdiction any portion of the property is situate, provided that, in respect of the value of the subject matter of the suit, the entire claim is cognisable by such court.</li>
</ul>
<p>b) Pecuniary Jurisdiction</p>
<ul>
<li>Section 11 of the Civil Procedure Act governs the filing of suits in the subordinate courts, and is to the effect that any suit shall be instituted in the lowest court competent to try it.</li>
<li>If this rule is not followed, the court in which the suit is filed is empowered to return the claim to the registry for presentation in the court of the lowest grade competent to try it.</li>
<li>Section 18 of the Civil Procedure Act further empowers the High Court to transfer matters from itself to the lower court if it is of the opinion that the issues raised can be adequately dealt with in such court.</li>
<li>The High Court is also empowered to withdraw any suit in any court subordinate to it and transfer it to itself.</li>
<li>The High Court under its original inherent jurisdiction can hear any matter while reserving its power to transfer a matter back to the lower court on the application of any of the parties.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="jurisdictional-consideration">Jurisdictional Consideration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#jurisdictional-consideration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Constitutional conferment of jurisdiction</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Presidential petitions must be in the Supreme Court (See Article 163 (3) (a)) and the high court also has jurisdiction to hear matters pertaining the Bill of rights (See Article 165 (3) (b)) this conferment is made within the constitution.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Statutory</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>See Section 4 of the Judicature Act which confers the High Court admiralty jurisdiction. and will decide "matters arising on the high seas or in territorial waters or upon any lake or other navigable inland waters in Kenya". The law applicable to be exercised "the conformity with international law and the comity of nations".</li>
<li>See also the National and Presidential Elections Act that confers the high court powers to determine matters arising from an election (Except presidential). The High Court may make an order as it deems fit, including the nullification of the election results upon hearing of a petition presented to it by a voter or loser in the election.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Territorial: As discussed above</li>
<li>Functional: See also subject matter jurisdiction</li>
<li>Subject matter: See Environment and Land Courts and Employment and Labour Courts</li>
<li>Islamic or customary law matter: See Kadhis Court on family matters where both parties are muslims.</li>
<li>Monetary limits: See pecuniary discussed above</li>
<li>Whether defendant is reachable</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="jurisdictional-court-structure">Jurisdictional Court Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#jurisdictional-court-structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The Courts operate two levels: Superior Courts and Subordinate Courts. The important aspects in the Structure of Courts are:
i.  The structure – The hierarchy or levels of Courts.
ii. Establishment – The composition or who presides in that Court.
iii. Jurisdiction – The powers of different Courts to hear and determine disputes. Jurisdictions are either Geographical / territorial limits of their powers or Functional powers (to hear Original matter, Appellate matter or both matters or subject matter (whether it is civil or criminal justice) or Pecuniary (the range of monetary or financial value of subject matter).</li>
</ul>
<p>The Figure below shows the court structure in Kenya</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260103-f47d485c.jpeg" alt="img-0.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-court-structure-in-kenya">The Court Structure in Kenya<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-court-structure-in-kenya" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The arrow on the figure shows the hierarchy of courts in Kenya. There are two levels of courts Superior Court (consist of Supreme Court, Court of Appeal and High Court) and Subordinate Courts (Resident Magistrate Court, Kadhi Courts, Court Martials, Tribunals, District Magistrate Courts Classes 1st, 2nd and 3rd.) The arrows show flow of appeal from one level to the next.</p>
<p>The arrows represent flow of appeals in both civil and criminal appeals except criminal appeals from District Magistrate class III which go to Resident Magistrates courts. District Magistrate courts are situated in all the districts except of District Magistrate Class III which in some sparsely populated Districts especially North Eastern Province Kenya where their powers have been delegated by the Chief Justice to the District Officers through notices in the Kenya Gazette.</p>
<p>This structure of the courts is based on the provisions of the Constitution, the Magistrates Court Act (Cap. 10), the Kadhis Court Act (Cap. 11) and the Armed Forces Act (Cap. 199) Laws of Kenya.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260103-89035f2a.jpeg" alt="img-1.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-superior-courts">A) SUPERIOR COURTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-superior-courts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-supreme-court">THE SUPREME COURT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-supreme-court" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The Supreme Court of Kenya is established under Article 163 of the Constitution of Kenya.</li>
<li>It comprises of 7 (Seven) Judges: the Chief Justice, who is the president of the Court, the Deputy Chief Justice, who is the deputy to the Chief Justice and the vice-president of the court and five other judges.</li>
<li>The Supreme Court is properly constituted for purposes of its proceedings when it has a composition of five judges and has exclusive original jurisdiction to hear and determine disputes relating to the elections to the office of President arising under Article 140 and subject to clause (4) and (5) of Article 163 of the Constitution, appellate jurisdiction to hear and determine appeals from the Court of Appeal and any other court or tribunal as prescribed by national legislation.</li>
<li>Appeals from the Court of Appeal to the Supreme Court are as a matter of right in any case involving the interpretation or application of this Constitution and in any other case in which the Supreme Court, or the Court of Appeal, certifies that a matter of general public importance is involved, subject to clause (5).</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>The Supreme Court may review a certification by the Court of Appeal and either affirms, vary or overturn it.</li>
<li>The Supreme Court may give an advisory opinion at the request of the national government, any State organ, or any county government with respect to any matter concerning county government.</li>
<li>All courts, other than the Supreme Court, are bound by the decisions of the Supreme Court.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-court-of-appeal">THE COURT OF APPEAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-court-of-appeal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Establishment: The Court of Appeal is established under Article 164 of the Constitution of Kenya 2010.</li>
<li>Composition: The Court of Appeal consists of a number of judges, being not fewer than 12 (twelve), as may be prescribed by an Act of Parliament and the Court is to be organized and administered in the manner prescribed by an Act of Parliament. The Court comprises of a President of the Court of Appeal who is elected by the judges of the Court of Appeal from among themselves. The Court of Appeal Judges retire at the age of 74 years.</li>
<li>Jurisdiction: The Court of Appeal is a superior court of record therefore it sets precedents. It has limited original jurisdiction. It was created to hear appeals from the High court.</li>
<li>The only moment the Court Appeal can have original jurisdiction is in punishment for contempt of court, and when stating execution of orders of the High Court. Procedure: The practice and procedure of the court of appeal are regulated by the rules of court made by the Rules Committee constituted under the Appellate Jurisdiction Act (Cap. 9). The Act provides that an uneven number of at least three judges shall sit for the determination of any matter by the court. The decision of the court shall be according to the opinion of a majority of the judges who sat for the purposes of determining that matter. (See the Gachoka's Case)</li>
<li>Is there a limit as to appeals? If you began in the small claims court, can you rise up till the Supreme Court? Yes. Higher Courts may certify that it moves up. This depends on the nature of the case e.g. public interest or the principle in the case. Check constitution on this. See Patrick Musimba v National land Commission (Odunga, J) See also Malindi Law Society Branch v Attorney General: Suspension of some sections of the Magistrates Act, No. 26 of 2016</li>
<li>The court has powers to:</li>
<li>i. Determine a case finally.</li>
<li>ii. Order for a trial.</li>
<li>iii. Order for a re-trial.</li>
<li>iv. Frame issues for the determination of the High Court.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>v. Receive additional evidence or order that it be taken by another court.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-high-court">THE HIGH COURT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-high-court" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li><strong>Establishment</strong>: The High Court is established under Article 165 and it consists of a number of judges to be prescribed by an Act of Parliament. The Court is organized and administered in the manner prescribed by an Act of Parliament. The Court has a Principal Judge, who is elected by the judges of the High Court from among themselves.</li>
<li><strong>Composition</strong>: Ordinarily, the High Court is duly constituted by one Judge sitting alone. However there are instances where two or more High Court Judges may be required to determine certain kinds of cases.</li>
<li><strong>Appointment of Judges</strong>: Are appointed by the President in accordance with the advice of Judicial Service Commission. They are laid down special qualifications required of a person to be eligible for appointment as a Judge, namely:</li>
<li>i. He / she is or has been a Judge of a Court having unlimited jurisdiction in civil and criminal matters in some part of the Commonwealth or in the Republic of Ireland or a court having jurisdiction in appeals from such a Court or;</li>
<li>ii. He / she is an Advocate of the High Court of not less than seven years standing or;</li>
<li>iii. He / she holds and has held for a period of or periods amounting in aggregate to not less than seven years, one or other of the qualifications specified in Section 12 of the Advocates Act.</li>
<li><strong>Jurisdiction</strong>:</li>
<li>i. The High Court has unlimited original jurisdiction in criminal and civil matters.</li>
<li>ii. The High Court has jurisdiction to determine the question whether a right or fundamental freedom in the Bill of Rights has been denied, violated, infringed or threatened.</li>
<li>iii. The High Court has jurisdiction to hear an appeal from a decision of a tribunal appointed under the Constitution or national legislation to consider the removal of a person from office, other than a tribunal appointed under Article 144.</li>
<li>iv. The High Court has jurisdiction to hear any question respecting the interpretation of this Constitution including the determination of: the question whether any law is inconsistent with or in contravention of the Constitution, the question whether anything said to be done under the authority of the Constitution or of any law is inconsistent with, or in contravention of the Constitution, any matter relating to constitutional powers of State organs in respect of county governments and any matter relating to the constitutional</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>relationship between the levels of government, and a question relating to conflict of laws under Article 191; any other jurisdiction, original or appellate, conferred on it by legislation.</p>
<p>v. The High Court does not have jurisdiction in respect of matters reserved for the exclusive jurisdiction of the Supreme Court under this Constitution or falling within the jurisdiction of the courts contemplated in Article 162 (2).</p>
<p>vi. The High Court has supervisory jurisdiction over the subordinate courts and over any person, body or authority exercising a judicial or quasi-judicial function, but not over a superior court. Also being a Superior court of record means that the decisions of the High Court as precedents, are binding on the subordinate courts by the doctrine of stare decisis.</p>
<p>vii. Although High Court has unlimited original jurisdiction in civil and criminal cases in actual practice, it will hear those criminal cases which cannot be tried by the subordinate courts i.e. murder and treason whereas in civil cases, it has jurisdiction where the value of the subject matter, in dispute exceeds Kshs. 500,000.00. The High Court has power to pass any sentence authorized by law.</p>
<p>viii. In addition to the ordinary civil and criminal jurisdiction or the High Court, there are other matters, which can only be heard by the High Court. Thus, the High Court enjoys special powers and jurisdiction in the following matters as conferred to it by the constitution and other legislations some of which are given hereinafter:-</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="high-court-special-powers">High Court Special Powers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#high-court-special-powers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-supervisory-jurisdiction">1. Supervisory Jurisdiction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-supervisory-jurisdiction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The Constitution confers specific, powers on the High Court to exercise supervisory jurisdiction in any civil and criminal proceedings before subordinate courts and may make such orders, issue such writs and give such directions as may consider appropriate for the purpose of ensuring that justice is duly administered by such courts. This includes the power of the High Court to transfer proceedings from one court to the other.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>To invoke the supervisory jurisdiction of the High Court a person must have exhausted all other available remedies and right of appeal. In exercise of its supervisory powers under judicial review, the high court may issue any of the prerogative orders of:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>i. Mandamus – The literal meaning of mandamus is “we command”. This is an Order issued by the High Court to any person or body commanding him or them to perform a public duty imposed by law or state. The order is available to compel administrative tribunals to do their duty e.g. to compel a licensing</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>board to issue a license on application of him who has met the prescribed criteria.</p>
<p>ii. Certiorari – The term means to “be informed”. This is an Order issued by the High Court directed at an inferior court body exercising judicial or quasi-judicial functions to have the records of the proceedings presented to the High Court for the purposes: To Secure an impartial trial, To review an excess of jurisdiction, To challenge an ultra vires act, To correct errors of law on the face of the record. To quash a judicial decision made against the rules of natural justice. An order of certiorari will be wherever anybody of persons having legal authority to determine questions affecting the rights and having a duty to act judicially, acts in excess of their legal authority. It therefore serves to quash what has been done irregularly.</p>
<p>iii. Prohibition – This is an order issued by the High Court to prevent an inferior court or tribunal from hearing or continuing to hear a case either In excess of its jurisdiction or in violation of the rules of natural justice.</p>
<p>iv. Writ of Habeas corpus – Harbeas corpus means „produce the body“, dead or alive. This order is issued where the personal liberty of a person is curtailed by arrest and confinement without legal justification. By issuing this order, the High Court calls upon the person holding the body to answer by what authority are they continuing to withhold the individual and with the aims at securing release of such persons held apparently without legal justification.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-interpretation-of-the-constitution">2. Interpretation of the Constitution<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-interpretation-of-the-constitution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The Constitution provides that where any question as to the interpretation of the constitution arises in any proceedings in any subordinate court, and the court is of the opinion that the question involves a substantial question of law, the court may, and shall if any party to the proceedings so requests, refer the question to the High Court.</li>
<li>The High Court shall be composed of an uneven number of judges, not being less than three when it determines the constitutional question referred to it. The decision of the High Court is binding on the Court that referred the question to the High Court and it must dispose of the case in accordance with the High Court’s decision.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-admiralty-jurisdiction">3. Admiralty Jurisdiction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-admiralty-jurisdiction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Section 4 of the Judicature Act Chapter 8 (1967) provide that the High Court will act as a court of admiralty and will decide “matters arising on the high seas or in territorial waters or upon any lake or other navigable inland waters in Kenya”. The law applicable to be exercised “the conformity with international law and the comity of nations”.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-election-jurisdiction">4. Election jurisdiction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-election-jurisdiction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Under the National Assembly and Presidential Election Act, the High court has special powers to hear and determine disputes arising from the national electoral process. The High Court may make an order as it deems fit, including the nullification of the election results upon hearing of a petition presented to it by a voter or loser in the election.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>For the High Court to nullify the election of a Member of Parliament, the petitioner must prove that an election offence has been committed. The composition of the High court is that one (1) Judge sits to determine dispute in parliamentary election while Three (3) Judges must sit if it is presidential election. Any appeal on the High Court decision on Presidential election goes to the Court of Appeal where at least five (5) Judges will sit to determine the appeal. Disputes in the election of councilors go to subordinate courts.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-succession-probate-jurisdiction">5. Succession/Probate Jurisdiction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-succession-probate-jurisdiction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The Probate Division of the High court has jurisdiction to hear any application and determine any dispute and pronounce such decree and issue such orders as may be expedient in inheritance matters e.g. the High Court may issue probate i.e. a person has been validly appointed by a will to administer the property of the deceased.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-matrimonial-cases">6. Matrimonial Cases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-matrimonial-cases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The court exercises jurisdiction in divorce matters. In exercise of its matrimonial jurisdiction, the High Court may issue orders for:</li>
</ul>
<p>i. Dissolution of marriage.
ii. Nullity of marriage.
iii. Separation and maintenance (alimony).
iv. Custody, adoption and guardianship of infants.
v. Spousal Property and financial adjustments etc.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-other-powers">7. Other powers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-other-powers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>To protect and enforce Fundamental rights and Freedoms of individuals which are set out in Chapter Four of the Constitution also otherwise referred to as Bill of Rights.</li>
<li>To hear and determine Bankruptcy proceedings.</li>
<li>To supervise winding up of dissolved companies</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="administration-of-the-high-court">Administration of the High Court<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#administration-of-the-high-court" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The High Court is divided into divisions. Matters pertaining to High Court are arranged in subject matter order.</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>The Commercial Division</li>
<li>The Family Division i.e. deals with matrimonial matters e.g. divorce</li>
<li>The Criminal Division</li>
<li>The Judicial Review and Constitutional Division.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The above division is purely administrative; it does not affect the powers of the judge as granted under the Constitution. All judges of the High Court can exercise powers in any division.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="b-subordinate-courts">B) SUBORDINATE COURTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-subordinate-courts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The Constitution has divided the Courts into two groups where we have the superior Courts and the subordinate Courts.</li>
<li>The Constitution provides for the subordinate Courts which are listed under
i. Article 169 (1) (a) as the Magistrates Courts,
ii. Article 169 (1) (b) as the Kadhi's Courts,
