<li>Abdirashid Adan Hassan v. Masterways Properties Ltd. [2013] Eklr</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-parties-to-a-suit">1. Parties to a Suit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-parties-to-a-suit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>On commencing a proceeding, a person becomes a plaintiff in an action or an applicant in an application.</li>
<li>On filing an action and being served with summons or other notice in an action, a person becomes a defendant without the necessity of the defence being filed or affidavit in reply as a respondent.</li>
<li>In an originating summons or petition, a party instituting cause is the applicant or petitioner, while the party in response becomes a respondent.</li>
<li>A "party" is a person who on the record of the court has commenced a proceeding or is being served with summons or has been added by order of the court to proceedings.</li>
<li>A plaintiff is <em>dominus litus</em>, i.e., he must be allowed to choose who to sue.</li>
<li>Where they are not sure of whom to sue for their cause of action, they may join two or more defendants in the action in order for the determination for who is liable and to what extent to be made between the parties. O 1, r 7 CPR, 2010.</li>
<li>Note that, a suit may not be defeated for misjoinder or non-joinder of a party or parties. O 1 r 9</li>
<li>Where a suit has been instituted with the wrong name of plaintiff or defendant through a <em>bona fide</em> mistake, the court may at any time within the suit strike out the wrong party and enjoin the right party to enable it to properly adjudicate and settle the question in the suit. O 1, r 10(2). See also <em>Tom Odhiambo Achillah T/A Achilla T. O. &amp; Co. Advocates v. Kenneth Wabwire Akide T/A Akide &amp; Company Advocates &amp; 3 others</em> [2015] eKLR.</li>
<li>The application to add, remove or substitute a plaintiff or defendant may be made before trial through chamber summons or it may be done in a summary manner during trial. O 1, r 14.</li>
<li>Where changes are made to the parties, the pleadings shall be amended and served on the rightly included parties, and if the court deems it, on the original parties. O 1, r 10(4).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="standing-to-sue-locus-standi">Standing to Sue/ locus standi<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#standing-to-sue-locus-standi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Locus standi or legal standing is the status which law requires of a person to enable him to invoke the jurisdiction of the courts in order to be granted a desired remedy.</li>
<li>Standing refers to the relationship which must exist between the plaintiff and the cause of action to enable the plaintiff to move ton court</li>
<li>The basic principle behind it is that the court's time should not be wasted over hypothetical and abstract questions or at the insistence of a mere busy body that has no genuine grievance.</li>
<li>In civil matters, a person must be a person aggrieved before such person can have <em>locus</em> to appear in court.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>In an application for judicial review or interpretation of the Constitution, the law on capacity to sue allows any person to sue on behalf of others in respect of public interest litigation. This is supported by Article 22(2)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The Constitution guarantees the right to institute court proceedings claiming that a right or fundamental freedom in the Bill of Rights has been denied, violated or infringed, or is threatened. Article 22(1).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Further, it guarantees the right to institute those proceedings on behalf of a group or class of persons. Article 22(2)(b).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>And in the interest of the public. Article 22(2)(c). See also <strong>Kituo Cha Sheria v John Ndirangu Kariuki &amp; Another[2013] eKLR</strong>.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>a) Natural Persons</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>While most natural persons may sue or be sued, limitations exist with regard to children, incompetent persons, aliens and convict.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Upon death such persons cease to exist as parties and actions on behalf of their estate are taken in a representative proceeding by the executors or administrators of the estate. <strong>Lomax v. Landells [1848]</strong></p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Where there are several co-plaintiffs and some of them die during the currency of the trial the substitution will only be allowed if the cause of action cannot be carried forward by the surviving plaintiffs. <strong>Rotich Cherutich &amp; 3 others v. Director of Surveyors &amp; another [2013] eKLR</strong>. See also <strong>David Thuo &amp; 8 Others v. First American Bank of Kenya Ltd [2005] eKLR</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A suit abates after one year of death, unless an application is made for substitution within that time. The court has the discretion to enlarge the time with good reason being given by the applicant. O 24, r 3.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A natural person may be a party in his given name, assumed or fictitious name.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Where an alias is used, a party should be described by using his proper name followed by the alias, e.g., <strong>AB also known as CD</strong>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Under the rule of <strong>idem sonans</strong>, absolute accuracy in spelling names is not required in legal documents. Clerical mistakes in describing a name do not vitiate a document.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When the defendant is doing business under a fictitious name, the true name of the party may be unknown to you when you are preparing the plaint. Even when you undertake the requisite due diligence, you may be unable to gather accurate information. It is therefore necessary to identify the defendant in the plaint by the fictitious name.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In such a case, when the true name of the defendant or defendants is determined, the plaint can generally be amended. O 1, r 9.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The Rules allow plaintiffs to name a newly discovered defendant even after the statute of limitations has run as long as the new party had received notice that the lawsuit has</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>been filed within the time allowed for service, would not be unduly prejudiced, and knew that but for a mistake, he or she would have been named as a party in the original suit. In such a case, the date of filing against the new party "relates back" to the original filing date. O 1, r 7, 9 and 10(2).</p>
<p>b) Agent</p>
<ul>
<li>It is not legally possible for an agent to institute suit on the behalf of a principal without the principal's authority.</li>
<li>Care should be taken not to swear the affidavit on behalf of the principal. In the Matter of the Estate of M'Magiri M'Mugira (Deceased) [2005] eKLR</li>
</ul>
<p>c) Minors/infants</p>
<ul>
<li>An infant is under a disability at law which prevents them from assuming the rights and liabilities of an adult.</li>
<li>A minor is a person under the age of 18 and they sue by their next friend and defend by their guardian ad litem.</li>
<li>The next friend must sign a written authority which is to be filed with the plaint.</li>
<li>The title of action should read:</li>
</ul>
<p>Serah Jerotich (a minor) by Cecilia Tarus (her mother and next friend), and,</p>
<p>Jonas Mambo (a minor) by, Mwadzile Mambo (his father and guardian ad litem) defendant</p>
<ul>
<li>The procedure for the appointment of the next friend or guardian ad litem is that a written authority to act must be filed together with a pleading.</li>
<li>Proceedings filed on behalf of minors without authority may be taken off the file by the court, however, the rules under O.32 are directory and not mandatory; and non-compliance with them does not automatically lead to throwing out the suit.</li>
<li>Court has direction under r.1(2) to either take the suit off the file or make such order in the premises as it may deem fit, e.g. amendment to include next friend.</li>
<li>Where an advocate represents a minor, and they fail to file authority resulting in the plaint being struck off the file, costs are to be paid personally by counsel. O.32 r.2(1)</li>
<li>It is mandatory to have a next friend and their authority to act for the minor be sought and filed and a decree obtained without the appointment of a next friend is a nullity. Credit finance Corporation Limited v. Karmari [1965] EA 545</li>
<li>Where no defence has been filed on or before the day fixed in the summons for a defendant who is a minor or a person of unsound mind, the plaintiff shall before</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>further proceeding with the suit apply to the court for an order that some proper person be assigned guardian ad litem of the defendant. O 32, r 3(1).</p>
<ul>
<li>The application may be made in the name or on behalf of the minor, or by the plaintiff in the suit. O 32, r 3(2).</li>
<li>When such application is made by the proposed guardian, the application must be accompanied by an affidavit verifying that they have no interests in the suit adverse to those of the minor and that they are fit to so represent the defendant. Order 32, rule 3(3).</li>
<li>The object of the next friend is the protection of the infants' rights and the guaranteeing of costs if the plaintiff's claim fails and to ensure due conduct of the proceeding.</li>
<li>A next friend has no power to consent to the dismissal of an action without court's approval.</li>
<li>Where an minor is a plaintiff in an existing action comes of age, their next friend should not take any further proceedings in the action. The former infant may either adopt or repudiate the proceedings within reasonable time. O 32, r 12(1).</li>
<li>Where they elect to proceed with the suit, they shall apply for an order discharging the next friend and for leave to proceed in their own name. O 32, r 12(2).</li>
<li>The title shall be corrected to read:</li>
</ul>
<p>"Serah Jerotich, late a minor, by Cecilia Tarus, her next friend, but now having attained majority"</p>
<p>O 32, r 12(3).</p>
<ul>
<li>Where they elect to abandon the suit they shall, if a sole plaintiff apply for an order to dismiss the suit on repayment of the costs incurred by the defendant or opposite party, or which may have been paid by his next friend. O 32, r 12(4).</li>
<li>The application shall be made ex parte by chamber summons however the next friend must be notified. O 32, r 12(5).</li>
<li>Where the minor is a co-plaintiff and elects to abandon the suit upon attaining majority, they may apply to have their name struck out and the court, if it considers that they are not a necessary party, shall dismiss them having regard to costs or otherwise as it deems fit. O 32, r 13(1).</li>
<li>Notice of such application shall be served on next friend, co-plaintiff and the defendant. O 32, r 13(2).</li>
<li>However, if the applicant is a necessary party to the suit, they court may direct them to be made a defendant. O 32, r 13(4).</li>
</ul>
<p>d) Mentally Incompetent Persons</p>
<ul>
<li>The above provisions of the rules relating to minors will apply mutatis mutandis to a person adjudged to be of unsound mind.</li>
<li>On a party becoming mentally incompetent during the pendency of a proceeding, the proceeding is stayed but not discontinued for the incompetent party is unable to</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>revoke the previous authority given to his counsel to commence or defend proceedings.</p>
<ul>
<li>In such a case proceedings may be taken to have the party declared insane.</li>
</ul>
<p>e) Recovery of mentally incompetent</p>
<ul>
<li>Where an incompetent party recovers during the pendency of a proceeding, they should apply for an order to discharge the appointment of the next friend or guardian ad litem.</li>
<li>When doubt exists as to the recovery of the party and the plaintiff considers that they are sane, they may apply to have the action by their representative dismissed with costs or have the court inquire whether they are competent to retain counsel to bring an action.</li>
<li>If the mentally incompetent person is found competent, the next friend would be discharged and the action continued personally by the party who regained sanity.</li>
<li>The status of a mentally incompetent party and of his representative should be set out in the introductory averments of a plaint.</li>
</ul>
<p>f) Aliens</p>
<ul>
<li>An alien is a subject of a foreign state not born in the country.</li>
<li>An alien fried can generally be sued or be sued in the courts in the same manner as a subject.</li>
<li>However, an alien friend cannot sue unless there is some cause for giving the court jurisdiction or something to the subject matter conveniently within the cognizance of the court.</li>
<li>As a general rule, an alien enemy cannot bring an action in the country of jurisdiction as plaintiff, although he may of course, be made a defendant.</li>
<li>The basis of this rule is that an alien enemy has the status of an outlaw and therefore cannot come into court to sue.</li>
<li>The policy of the courts is to give no assistance to proceedings, which may lead to the enrichment of an alien enemy and thereby tend to provide his country with the sinews of war.</li>
</ul>
<p>g) Foreign State</p>
<ul>
<li>It is a matter of International Law that our courts will not entertain an action against certain privileged persons and institutions unless the privilege is waived.</li>
<li>This class of persons includes foreign sovereigns or heads of state and governments, foreign diplomats and their staff, consular officers and representatives of international organizations and agencies like UN, AU and EU.</li>
<li>Refer to the words of Lord Denning MR in Thai-Europe Tapioca Service Limited v. Government of Pakistan Ministry of Food and Agriculture Directorate of Agriculture Supplies Imports and Shipping Wing [1975] 3 All ER 961 at 965</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>See also <em>Ministry of Defence of the Government of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland v. Joel Ndegwa</em>, Civil Appeal 31 of 1982.</li>
<li>However, it should be noted that there is no absolute immunity. The test is whether the foreign sovereign government was acting in a government or private capacity.</li>
<li>International law does not recognize immunity for a government department in respect of ordinary commercial transactions.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="h-companies-and-statutory-persons">h) Companies and Statutory Persons<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#h-companies-and-statutory-persons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A company, or Commission or Authority that is incorporated by an Act of Parliament may sue and be sued in its corporate name.</li>
<li>The term ‘person’ in the legal context includes a body corporate.</li>
<li>A change of company’s name does not render defective any legal proceeding instituted by or against a company.</li>
<li>Any legal proceeding commenced against a company by its former name may be commenced and continued against a company by its new name.</li>
<li>To bring a suit in the name of a company one must first obtain authority from the company by way of a special resolution.</li>
<li>A company’s mind as directed by its directors is always known to the public through resolutions which are duly registered at the company registry in order to safeguard and inform the public.</li>
<li>In liquidation, a liquidator may sue in the name of the company.</li>
<li>The receiver for debenture holders may also bring or continue an action in the name of the company.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-government">i) Government<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-government" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The AG is the principal legal adviser of the Government and one of the functions of the AG is to represent the Government in Courts or any legal proceedings to which the Government is a party (Art. 156) (S.12 GPA).</li>
<li>In all matters of constitutional interpretation, the AG must be added as a party to the proceedings.</li>
<li>In cases of public interest, the AG should be a party and if he is left out the court will join him as a respondent on its volition under O.1 r.10(2) CPR.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="j-representative-parties">j) Representative Parties<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#j-representative-parties" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The rules of the court provide that administrators or executors of the estate of a deceased person may sue or be sued on behalf of or representing the estate without joining any beneficiaries.</li>
<li>The administrator of an estate is appointed by a grant of letters of administration, while the executor named in a will being appointed by a court through a grant of letters of probate.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>An administrator should not commence an action in that capacity unless administration of that estate has been granted to them by the court.</li>
<li>Where there is more than one administrator, all must be made parties, even if one is an infant.</li>
<li>When one administrator refuses to join in an action as a plaintiff, the co-administrators may be added as defendants.</li>
<li>An individual or individuals may represent parties to a suit where they have the same interests in the suit. (O.1 r.8)</li>
<li>The parties representing the others shall give notice to those others by personal service, or where the numbers of those parties impede practicability of personal service, by public advertisement, as the court may so order. O 1, r 8(2).</li>
<li>Included in the notice to all potential members of the class is usually an explanation that any potential class member can request in writing that he or she be excluded from the class. If a member does not request exclusion that class member will be bound by any judgment in the case. O 1, r 8(2).</li>
<li>The parties represented must give the authority to be represented in writing and signed by the party giving authority, where after, the authority shall be filed in the case. O 1, r 13(2).</li>
<li>In <em>David Thuo &amp; 8 Others v First American Bank of Kenya Ltd, [2005] eKLR</em>, the applicant swore an affidavit on behalf of 114 co-employees seeking an injunction to restrain the bank from transferring its equity to a third party. Court was of the view that since amalgamation had already happened the employees ceased to have a common interest and their relief could only be in the form of damages.</li>
</ul>
<p>k) Partnerships</p>
<ul>
<li>A partnership may be sued or sue in the firm's name, as long as the cause of action arose and manifested when the partners were referred to as such firm name. O.30 r.1</li>
<li>The rules of the court facilitate the service of the process and the resultant judgment is enforceable not only against the firm property, but also against the property of any partner who has been individually served.</li>
<li>With leave, the judgment is generally enforceable against the property of any partner. But, a foreign partner may have to be sued individually.</li>
<li>It is good practice to state in the plaint more than just the firm name and to give the names of at least two partners followed by the words "trading as" followed by the firm name, for example,</li>
</ul>
<p>"Hamud Jembe and Hisham Indrani, a partnership T/A HIJ Potteries"...Plaintiffs.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Commencement of Civil Litigation Various ways generally</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Legal proceedings are commenced when a plaintiff makes a complaint or demand before a court in due form.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>We are going to look at three ways</li>
<li>a) By Pleadings</li>
<li>b) By Interpleader</li>
<li>c) By Third Party Proceedings</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-pleadings">a) Pleadings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-pleadings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Every pleading in civil proceedings shall contain information as to the circumstances in which it is alleged that the liability has arisen. (O2 r1)</li>
<li>Pleadings are written statements of parties to a suit, which are served, on each party.</li>
<li>Normally this statement of pleadings sets in summary form the nature of the case and the material facts that support the claim.</li>
<li>It is through the pleading that the court is able to know what the issues in dispute are and that require determination by it.</li>
<li>The sole object of pleadings is to:</li>
<li>i. Bring the parties to definite issues; and</li>
<li>ii. To diminish expense and delay; and</li>
<li>iii. To prevent surprise at the hearing.</li>
<li>A party is entitled to know the case of his opponent so that he can meet it.</li>
<li>In other words the sole object of pleadings is:</li>
<li>i. To ascertain the real dispute or issue between the parties;</li>
<li>ii. Narrow down the area of conflict, and</li>
<li>iii. To see where the two sides differ to preclude one party from taking the other by surprise, and</li>
<li>iv. To prevent miscarriage of justice.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="formal-requirements">Formal Requirements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#formal-requirements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Every pleading shall have as its heading, the court and location of the court, the title of the action</li>
<li>Every pleading shall be divided into paragraphs labeled consecutively</li>
<li>Each allegation should ideally be contained in a separate paragraph (O2 r2(1))</li>
<li>Dates, sums and other numbers should be expressed in figures (O2 r2(2))</li>
<li>The pleadings should contain a brief statement summarizing the material facts on which the party pleading relies on for his claim or defence BUT NOT the evidence that will prove the facts (O2 r3(1))</li>
<li>The effect of any document adduced as evidence or conversation referred to in the pleading shall be briefly stated, if need be, but the precise words of the document or the conversation shall not be stated, unless those words are themselves material (O2 r3(2))</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>Any fact presumed by law to be true shall not be pleaded unless specifically denied by the other party (O2 r3(3))</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pleadings">PLEADINGS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pleadings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nature-and-function-of-pleadings">Nature and Function of Pleadings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nature-and-function-of-pleadings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The word “pleading” is defined to include a statement of claim, defence, reply and any subsequent pleading, and as not including a summons or notice of motion. Normally this statement of pleadings sets in summary the nature of the case and the material facts that support the claim. Statements of claim, defences, replies, rejoinders, surrejoinders, rebutters, surrebutters, counterclaims and defences to counterclaims are all pleadings although some are rarely used in practice.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pleadings contain the particulars of the claim or the defence and help to narrow the issues and reveal the case that each party is making. Pleadings are supposed to:</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>i. Disclose whether there is a reasonable cause of action or defence
ii. Define the scope of discovery or interrogatories
iii. Determine the range of admissible evidence
iv. Identify the relief sought from the court
v. Give parties notice of the case to be met and a reasonable opportunity to respond and prepare their case on the basis on the issues disclosed and thus satisfy some of the requirements of procedural fairness
vi. If there are subsequent proceedings, pleadings in the earlier case identify the scope of the defence, known as res judicata, that the previous case or certain issues in it had already been decided.
vii. Define the issues which are in dispute</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dare-v-pulham-1982-148-clr-658-at-664">Dare v Pulham (1982) 148 CLR 658 at 664.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dare-v-pulham-1982-148-clr-658-at-664" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>"Pleadings and particulars have a number of functions: they furnish a statement of the case sufficiently clear to allow the other party a fair opportunity to meet it ... they define the issues for decision in the litigation and thereby enable the relevance and admissibility of evidence to be determined at the trial ... and they give a defendant an understanding of a plaintiff’s claim in aid of the defendant’s right to make a payment into court."</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="banque-commerciale-sa-en-liquidation-v-akhil-holdings-ltd-1990-169-clr-279-at-286">Banque Commerciale SA, En Liquidation v Akhil Holdings Ltd (1990) 169 CLR 279 at 286.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#banque-commerciale-sa-en-liquidation-v-akhil-holdings-ltd-1990-169-clr-279-at-286" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>"The function of pleadings is to state with sufficient clarity the case that must be met ... In this way, pleadings serve to ensure the basic requirement of procedural fairness that a party should have the opportunity of meeting the case against him or her and, incidentally, to define the issues for decision."</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bailey-v-federal-commissioner-of-taxation-1977-136-clr-214-at-219">Bailey v Federal Commissioner of Taxation (1977) 136 CLR 214 at 219<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bailey-v-federal-commissioner-of-taxation-1977-136-clr-214-at-219" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>"Particulars fulfil an important function in the conduct of litigation. They define the issues to be tried and enable the parties to know what evidence it will be necessary to have available and to avoid taking up time with questions that are not in dispute. On the one hand they prevent the injustice that may occur when a party is taken by surprise; on the other they save expense by keeping the conduct of the case within due bounds."</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>It is no argument that the opposite party knows the facts.</li>
<li>“[I]t is a misapprehension to think that the only function of particulars is to reveal to a party facts of whose existence he is unaware. As I have indicated, particulars have the important function of informing a party of the nature of the case he has to meet and of limiting the issues of fact to be investigated by the court.”</li>
<li>Pleadings have to be drafted and served according to the rules of procedure.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="principles-of-pleadings">Principles of Pleadings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principles-of-pleadings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Each party should only plead material facts;</li>
<li>Any material facts that are not clearly denied will be deemed to have been admitted;</li>
<li>Any issue not pleaded cannot be canvassed in court.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rules-of-pleadings">Rules of Pleadings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rules-of-pleadings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Rules of Pleadings are found in Order 2.</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Rule 1</strong> of this Order provides a general rule to be followed in all pleadings that “(1) Every pleading in civil proceedings, including proceedings against the Government, shall contain information as to the circumstances in which it is alleged that the liability has arisen and, in the case of the Government, the departments and officers concerned.”</li>
</ol>
<p>That is, the pleadings must disclose a cause of action. It was stated in Auto Garage .v. Motokov (1971) EA 514 that there are three prerequisites for the existence of a cause of action; and they are as follows:</p>
<p>i. that the plaintiff enjoyed a right;
ii. that right was violated; and
iii. that the defendant is liable.</p>
<p>Pleadings that do not lay out the circumstances under which the liability sought to be imposed upon the defendant are faulty and must be guarded against.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li><strong>Rule 2.</strong> (1) Requires that “Every pleading...be divided into paragraphs numbered consecutively, each allegation being so far as appropriate contained in a separate paragraph.”</li>
<li><strong>Rule 2.</strong> (2) Requires that “Dates, sums and other numbers... be expressed in figures and not words.”</li>
<li><strong>Rule 3</strong> (1) provides that “…every pleading shall contain, and contain only, a statement in a summary form of the material facts on which the party pleading relies for his claim or defence, but not the evidence by which those facts are to be proved,”</li>
<li><strong>Rule 3</strong> (2) allows for “the effect of any document or the purport of any conversation referred to in the pleading, if material, to be briefly stated, and the precise words of the document or conversation not to be stated, except in so far as those words are themselves material.”</li>
<li><strong>Rule 3</strong> (3) provides that “A party need not plead any fact if it is presumed by law to be true or the burden of disproving it lies on the other party, unless the other party has specifically denied it in his pleading.”</li>
<li><strong>Rule 4</strong> states that some matters must be specifically pleaded. These include:</li>
</ol>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>i. any matter, for example performance, release, payment, fraud, inevitable accident, act of God, any relevant Statute of limitation or any fact showing illegality-</p>
<p>a) which he alleges makes any claim or defence of the opposite party not maintainable;
b) which, if not specifically pleaded, might take the opposite party by surprise; or
c) which raises issues of fact not arising out of the preceding pleading.</p>
<p>ii. a defendant to an action for the recovery of land shall plead specifically every ground of defence on which he relies, and a plea that he is in possession of the land by himself or his tenant shall not be sufficient.</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>By rule 5, a party may in any pleading plead any matter which has arisen at any time, whether before or since the filing of the plaint.</li>
<li>By rule 6, No party may in any pleading make an allegation of fact, or raise any new ground of claim, inconsistent with a previous pleading of his in the same suit.</li>
<li>By rule 7, particulars of defamation must be specifically pleaded.</li>
<li>By rule 8, particulars of evidence in mitigation in a defamation action must be specifically pleaded by the defendant.</li>
<li>Rule 9 a party may by his pleading raise any point of law.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="matters-which-must-be-specifically-pleaded-particulars-given">Matters Which Must Be Specifically Pleaded &amp; Particulars Given<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#matters-which-must-be-specifically-pleaded-particulars-given" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>If a party is relying on misrepresentation or fraud, then they must plead misrepresentation and particulars of that misrepresentation. Even when you plead negligence, you have to plead the particulars of negligence for instance failure by an employer to provide protective clothing for factory workers or failure to fence off an unsafe area. In libel cases the words that are said to be defamatory must be pleaded and the particulars of the words that constitute the libel must be pleaded. In general, damages must be pleaded.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="alternative-inconsistent-prayers">Alternative &amp; Inconsistent Prayers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#alternative-inconsistent-prayers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Alternative means a choice between 2 things. In civil litigation, you are allowed to tell the court that I am pleading for (a) and in the alternative, I am pleading for (b). This is to prevent a 2nd litigation. You can have alternative and inconsistent pleadings but they must be reconcilable.</li>
<li>Any allegation of fact made by a party in his pleading shall be deemed to be admitted by the opposing party unless it is traversed by that party in his pleading or a joinder of issue under rule 10 operates as a denial of it. This principle of pleading is laid out in Order 2 Rule 11. A traverse may be made either by denial or by a statement of non-admission; either expressly or by necessary implication. Every allegation of fact made in a plaint or counterclaim which the party on whom it is served does not intend to admit shall be specifically traversed by him in his defence or defence to counterclaim; and a general denial of such allegations, or a general statement of non-admission of them, shall not be a sufficient traverse of them. Any allegation that a party has suffered damage and any allegation as to the amount of damages shall be deemed to have been traversed unless specifically admitted.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="signing">Signing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#signing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Rule 16 provides that “Every pleading shall be signed by an advocate, or recognised agent (as defined by Order 9, rule 2), or by the party if he sues or defends in person.”</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="what-pleadings-should-contain">WHAT PLEADINGS SHOULD CONTAIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-pleadings-should-contain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) Order VI Rule 3(1) provides that, subject to this rule and rules 6,7 and 8, every pleading shall contain only a statement form of the material facts on which the party pleading relies for his claim or defence, but not the evidence by which those facts are to be proved, and the statement shall be as brief as the nature of the case admits. Under this rule, the facts in a particular case, and not the evidence.</p>
<p>b) Order VI rule 8(1) provides that: “subject to sub rule (2) every pleading shall contain the necessary particulars of any claim, defence or other matter pleaded”</p>
<p>c) Order VIA Rule 1 is to the effect that pleadings can be amended without leave of court as long as the pleadings have not closed. If pleadings are not amended under this rule, then they can be amended on specific issues provided with leave of court under Order VIA, Rule 3</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="plaint">Plaint<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plaint" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="every-plaint-must-contain">Every plaint must contain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#every-plaint-must-contain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Description of Court</li>
<li>Case number</li>
<li>Names of the parties</li>
<li>Description and place of residence of the Plaintiff or his business address;</li>
<li>A similar description of the Defendant including address of service</li>
<li>If it is a minor the plaint should contain a statement to that effect.</li>
<li>It should contain facts constituting cause of action</li>
<li>Facts showing that the court has jurisdiction;</li>
<li>The prayers of relief sought;</li>
<li>The amount if any</li>
<li>Value of the subject matter</li>
<li>Date of the plaint</li>
<li>Signature of the Plaintiff or his agent;</li>
<li>Whenever it is for the recovery of money precise amount must be stated;</li>
<li>Whenever your plaint refers to a document, it must have an accurate description of that item;</li>
</ol>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="must-specifically-pleaded">MUST specifically pleaded<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#must-specifically-pleaded" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A party in pleading in reply to a plaint must plead specifically any matter such as performance, payment, fraud, act of God, statute of limitation or any fact showing illegality –</li>
<li>a) Which he alleges makes claim or defence of the other party not maintainable</li>
<li>b) Which if not specifically pleaded, might take the other party by surprise</li>
<li>c) Which raises issues of fact not arising out of the preceding pleadings (O2 r4(1))</li>
<li>However, where party is a defendant to an action for recovery of land, then he needs to specifically plead every ground of defence he relies on (O2 r4(2))</li>
<li>No party may in subsequent pleadings make allegations of facts or raise any new grounds that are inconsistent with his previous pleadings in the same suit (O2 r6(1))</li>
<li>However, he may plead any matter which has arisen before or since the filing of the plaint (O2 r5).</li>
<li>A party may by his pleadings raise a point of law (O2 r9)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="particulars">Particulars<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#particulars" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Every pleading shall contain the particulars of any claim or defence including:</li>
<li>a) particulars of any misrepresentation, fraud or willful default on which the party pleading relies; and</li>
<li>b) where a party pleading alleges any condition of the mind of any person whether disability of mind, malice, fraudulent intention upon which party pleading relies (O2 r10(1))</li>
<li>Where a party alleges as a fact that a person had knowledge or notice of some fact, the court may, on such terms as it thinks just, order that party to serve on any other party</li>
<li>a) where he alleges knowledge, particulars of the facts on which he relies; and</li>
<li>b) where he alleges notice, particulars of the notice (r10(3))</li>
<li>This order should ideally be made after the filing of the defence, unless order is necessary to allow the defendant to plead (r10(4))</li>
<li>No costs shall be awarded for a party who requests for such order unless notice has been sought as under Form No. 2 of Appendix B served in duplicate (r10(5)).</li>
<li>Particulars delivered shall be in Form No. 3 of Appendix A which shall be filed by the party delivering it together with the original notice and shall form part of the pleadings (r10(6))</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-processes">Other processes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-processes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>All applications to the court shall be made by way of notice of motion and be heard in open court, unless the court or the rules order that such application be made otherwise, i.e., by originating summons or chamber summons (O51 r1).</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>Upon hearing an application, if the court deems that sufficient notice has not been given or that notice has not been given to the other party, the court may adjourn the matter and order such notice to be served upon terms that the court may deem to impose (O51 r5).</li>
<li>The pleadings should contain a brief statement summarizing the material facts on which the party pleading relies on for his claim or defence BUT NOT the evidence that will prove the facts (O2 r3(1))</li>
<li>The effect of any document adduced as evidence or conversation referred to in the pleading shall be briefly stated, if need be, but the precise words of the document or the conversation shall not be stated, unless those words are themselves material (O2 r3(2))</li>
<li>Any fact presumed by law to be true shall not be pleaded unless specifically denied by the other party (O2 r3(3))</li>
<li>Every application shall bear at the foot the words: "If any party served does not appear at the time and place above mentioned such order will be made and proceedings taken as the court may think just and expedient" (O51 r13(2))</li>
<li>The application shall be served upon the respondent together with the list of authorities, if any, within 7 days of the hearing date (r13(3).</li>
<li>The respondent wishing to respond may do so by way of:
a) Notice of preliminary objection; and/or
b) Replying affidavit; and/or
c) A statement of grounds of opposition (O51 r14(1))</li>
<li>The should be served upon the applicant within 3 days before the hearing date (r14(2))</li>
<li>The applicant may with leave of the court file a supplementary affidavit to the respondent's replying affidavit or statement of grounds of opposition (r14(3))</li>
<li>If the respondent fails to respond to the application served upon him by the applicant or fails to serve the applicant within 3 days before the hearing, the application may be heard ex parte (r14(4))</li>
<li>The court may set aside any order made ex parte (O51 r15)</li>
<li>The court may in its discretion limit the time for oral submissions or allow written submissions (O51 r16)</li>
<li>The court may order hearing in chamber or in open court as it deems convenient to dispose of such application (O51 r8 &amp; 9)</li>
<li>NOTE: We cite the enabling section of the law in every originating summon, notice of motion, chamber summon and any other process because the court has to straight away know that it is allowed by the statutes</li>
<li>However, the same will not be a ground of objection or necessitate striking out of application (O51 r10(1))</li>
<li>An application shall not be defeated on a technicality or want of form that does not affect the substance of the application (r10(2))</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>i. Originating Summons</p>
<ul>
<li>The originating summons is only used where the Civil Procedure Rules provide for it or some other statutes especially permit that method of approaching the court.</li>
<li>The method of O.S. is intended for simpler, shorter and speedier process.</li>
<li>Usually when you approach the court by O.S. there are no witnesses and evidence is by way of affidavit.</li>
<li>The question for decision by the court is raised directly in the summons and the evidence is raised in the affidavit.</li>
<li>The issues are raised in a concise manner but with sufficient particulars to enable the court identify the issues and the course of action.</li>
<li>The remedy or relief sought is also stated clearly therein.</li>
<li>O.S. is used where the parties have a special relationship.</li>
<li>It is used in cases related with agreements for sale or purchase of immovable property under r3 but only in cases where the existence of the agreement or contract is not in dispute and also where its validity is not in dispute.</li>
<li>r4 deals with summons by mortgagor, mortgagee and others for reliefs in the nature of sale, foreclosure, delivery of possession up to the mortgagee by the mortgagor; redemption, reconveyance, delivery of possession to mortgagor.</li>
<li>r5 - has to do with Caveats.</li>
<li>r6 - Application for extension of time under the rules of Limitations of Actions Act will go by way of O.S.</li>
<li>r7 Application for land ownership by virtue of adverse possession is made by way of O.S.</li>
<li>When you apply for a file to be reconstructed it is also through O.S.</li>
<li>Under r8 which provides for fixing of the cause directions by parties.</li>
<li>O.S is also used where a specific legislation expressly provides for its use e.g Advocates Act, Limitation of Actions Act, Succession Act, e.t.c.</li>
<li>An O. S. shall be in Form No. 26 or No. 27 of Appendix A with variations to it as the circumstances may require.</li>
<li>It shall be prepared by the applicant or their advocate and filed in court.</li>
<li>Where necessary it shall be served upon the other party according to the rules of service laid down in the rules (r14)</li>
<li>The summons shall be filed and entered in the register of suits with the letters "O.S" indicated after the serial number so as to distinguish from plaints (r 15)</li>
<li>The registrar shall within 30 days of filing the OS, and with notice to the parties, list it for directions before a judge in chambers (r16)</li>
<li>The date and hour of attendance under the OS to which an appearance is scheduled, shall after appearance be fixed for hearing in chambers before the judge it has been assigned (r17)</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>If at the time of directions, the parties dispute the correctness and sufficiency of facts in the summons and affidavits, the judge may order such further evidence as deemed necessary to support the summons, and may give directions as he may deem just for trial or make any amendments necessary to make the summons relevant to the facts (r18)</li>
<li>Where it appears to the court, at any stage of the proceedings commenced by OS, that the proceedings should be continued as if the cause had begun by filing a plaint, then the court may order the proceedings continue as such and order any affidavits filed to stand as pleadings</li>
<li>The court may direct parties to or not too file further particulars or to apply for particulars of those affidavits</li>
<li>If the court makes such order, Order 11 shall apply (r19).</li>
</ul>
<p>ii. Notice of Motion</p>
<ul>
<li>A Notice of Motion must include a concise statement of the nature of the claim or the relief or remedy required and the evidence relied on, if any, should be by affidavit (O51 r4)</li>
<li>No motion shall be made without notice to the other party (O51 r3)</li>
<li>However, if the court deems that delay may seriously prejudice the party making the application, it shall make the order ex parte with regard to such terms as to costs or otherwise and subject to such undertakings as the court may deem to be just having regard to the party against whom the order is made. The party affected by order may move to have it set aside (proviso to r3).</li>
<li>Any application such as referred to in section 25(2) of the Government Proceedings Act shall be made by way of Notice of Motion (O51 r2).</li>
<li>Examples where a notice of motion can be used:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Application for orders for Judgment on Admission;</li>
<li>Application of Summary Judgment;</li>
<li>Application of Stay of Proceedings;</li>
<li>Application for lifting of an injunction, variation or discharge of it;</li>
<li>Application for Release Orders e.g. Habeas Corpus Order.</li>
<li>Substantive application for Judicial Review</li>
<li>Burial disputes</li>
<li>Certain Constitutional Applications.</li>
</ol>
<p>iii. Chamber Summons</p>
<ul>
<li>Applications by way of Chamber Summons are used when seeking orders within a pending suit.</li>
<li>The Application must always be brought and sought under a specific rule.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>Chamber Summons was historically heard in chambers thus the name Chamber Summons.</li>
<li>These applications are normally requested for certain orders and the courts will not usually grant ex parte orders unless it has heard both sides.</li>
<li>Service is of the essence.</li>
<li>If it is an urgent matter and irreparable harm will be occasioned, the court can grant the order ex parte after hearing one side.</li>
<li>An ex parte order is only granted upon the undertaking by that party that they shall file the substantive suit and/or serve the other side within a period specified by the Court.</li>
<li>Every summons shall state in general terms the grounds of the application usually supported by evidence in an affidavit.</li>
<li>In this country the practice of transacting court business in Chambers as opposed to open court is no longer differentiated (Pius Weyusia Wamalabe v. The Attorney General Misc. Civ. App. 527 of 2004)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="written-submissions">Written Submissions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#written-submissions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>If you apply by way of Chamber Summons or Notice of Motion accompanied by an Affidavit, evidence of service, response from the other side (grounds upon which they object and the Supporting Affidavit and the Evidence that they have served you with it.</li>
<li>Parties may be required to file written submissions that they intend to make in court. Affidavit.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-affidavit">iv. Affidavit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-affidavit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The general rule is that the manner of proving facts in a court of law is by oral evidence; however, sometimes the court may order that evidence be presented to the court by way of an Affidavit.</li>
<li>Affidavits may also be used in certain applications where the statute provides for it.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="whether-affidavits-are-pleadings">WHETHER AFFIDAVITS ARE PLEADINGS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#whether-affidavits-are-pleadings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Several case law have dealt with the above matter. However further appreciation of the question includes a proper appreciation of what pleadings should contain as stipulated above. In the case of Muchangi Nduta &amp; CO Advocates V Dr Francis P. Kiranga where the advocate argued that his firm was instructed by the plaintiff to act for him in respect of the subject matter of kshs 5,125,537. This amount was reflected in the affidavit of the defendant. The advocate said that the taxing master refused to rely on that affidavit because he found that an affidavit is not a pleading.</p>
<p>The respondent opposed the prayer on this item and faulted the advocate for relying on the amount reflected in the replying affidavit for determination of the subject matter on the amount reflected in the plaint. The court in determining the matter relied on the definition given under Section 2 of the civil procedure act and rejected the advocates submission that the figures in the</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>replying affidavit can be used to determine the subject matter in view of the definition of pleadings herein before. The figure in question should have been expressly stated in the plaint and defence.</p>
<p>Under Order VIA Rule 1 of the civil procedure Act, pleadings can be amended without leave of court as long as the pleadings have not been closed. However in cases of affidavits, they cannot be amended and in cases where there is fault with the affidavit, a fresh one should be filed. The above was dealt in the case of <em>Saanon V Commissioner of lands and 5 others</em> the defendants raised a preliminary point of law related to an affidavit sworn by the plaintiff. The defendant attacked the affidavit on the ground that it had been amended. They contended that the amended affidavit should be expunged from the record and thereafter be struck out for being unverified as per order 7 rule I (2) and (3) of the civil procedure rules.</p>
<p>The plaintiff argued that the amendments complained of only covered the inclusion of two names of the new parties, the new title amended affidavit. He argued that it was in no way amended except on the title to align it with the suit for identification purposes.</p>
<p>Court held that an affidavit contains mainly matters of fact sworn to be true upon knowledge, information on belief. Once such facts have been sworn on oath therefore, they can't be negatived on or contravened by the person.</p>
<p>However, formal errors on the face of the affidavit such as the ones stated above does not in any way alter the meaning. Thus from the above it is only on minor instances that an affidavit can be amended and not the subject matter and as such does not qualify to be a pleading.</p>
<p>In the case of <em>Eurobank Limited V Riveton Investments &amp; 2 others</em>, the court was of the opinion that the definition that is provided in section 2 of the civil procedure act is inclusive rather than exclusive. It was however of the opinion of court that affidavits are constituted of evidentiary statements made under oath (as much as they contain facts within evidence) whilst pleadings constitute no more than allegations or assertions made by either the plaintiff or the defendant or by a party is laying out in broad terms its case. The court further opined that Order VI Rule 3 of the civil procedure Rules provides that facts not evidence should be contained in a pleading. As such, since affidavits contain evidentiary statements, they cannot of necessity be pleadings.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="conclusion">CONCLUSION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#conclusion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>From the above discussion, it is evident that an affidavit is not a pleading because in essence an Affidavit is itself evidence on oath, and by analogy cannot be a pleading and it is a document that does not institute a suit.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-interpleader-proceedings">b). Interpleader Proceedings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-interpleader-proceedings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This is a proceeding filed by a person holding property that is being adversely claimed by two or more people. It is filed by an interpleader for the court to determine who the lawful owner of the property is.</li>
<li>If the application is made by a defendant in a suit, the court may stay all further proceedings in the suit and proceed with the interpleader only (O34 r3)</li>
<li>The application is made by way of O.S unless made in a pending suit by which case it shall be by way of C. S. (r1)</li>
<li>The applicant must satisfy the court by way of affidavit that:</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>(a) The Applicant is a neutral party with no claim or interest whatsoever, in the subject matter other than costs/charges.
(b) There is no collusion between the applicant and either of the parties; and
(c) The claimant is willing and ready to deal with the subject matter in whatever manner the court directs (r2)</p>
<ul>
<li>If the claimant appears in pursuance of summons the court may order either a claimant be made a defendant in any suit commenced or issues between claimants be stated and tried, where the court will direct who shall be plaintiff or defendant (r4)</li>
<li>The court may, with consent of one or both parties and with regard to the value of the subject matter, where desirable, dispose off the merits of the claim and decide on the matter summarily on such terms as may be just (r5).</li>
<li>Should a claimant be served with summons to appear to substantiate his claim and he does not appear or he does not comply with any order made after his appearance, the court may make an order declaring him and any other person claiming under him forever barred against the applicant (r7)</li>
<li>No such order shall however be sustained against the Government unless upon application by summons to be served not less than 7 days before the return day (proviso to r7)</li>
<li>Where the issue is a question of law and facts are not disputed, the court may decide upon that question without the trial of an issue(r8)</li>
<li>And the applicant can be granted relief even if the titles of the claimant have no common origin and may be adverse to or independent of each other (r9)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-third-party-notices-see-chapter-6">3. Third Party Notices (See Chapter 6...)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-third-party-notices-see-chapter-6" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-plaint-generally">THE PLAINT (GENERALLY)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-plaint-generally" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The plaint is the pleading in which the plaintiff states the basis of the lawsuit. Generally the plaint does the following:</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Identifies the plaintiffs and defendants in the lawsuit, and describes their status and capacity to sue and be sued</li>
<li>Describes the factual basis for the lawsuit</li>
<li>Makes a request or demand for some relief from the court.</li>
<li>Contains a statement showing that the court in which it is filed has the proper jurisdiction and venue.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="format">Format<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#format" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>The caption - the part of the plaint that identifies the court in which the plaint is filed, the names of the plaintiffs and defendants, the title of the document and track.</li>
</ol>
<p>REPUBLIC OF KENYA
IN THE HIGH COURT AT NAIROBI
ENVIRONMENT AND LAND DIVISION
E.L.C. NO. OF 2014</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>JOHN WHITE HEAD...PLAINTIFF
-VERSUS-
KEY NORTH EAR...DEFENDANT</p>
<p><strong>PLAINT (FAST TRACK)</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>The choice of the case track is determined by the parties from either small track, fast track or multi-track (O.3 r.1); where:
a) Small claim shall indicate that the case involves a simple claim involving just two parties and the monetary value of the suit does not exceed Kshs49,999
b) Fast track is for cases with undisputed facts and legal issues, it involves relatively few parties and will likely be concluded within 180 days after the pre-trial directions
c) Multi-track is for cases with complex facts and legal issues or involves several parties and will likely be concluded within 240 days after pre-trial directions.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>The body – a description of the parties, factual basis for the lawsuit, and a description of the loss or damages incurred.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The plaint shall be divided into paragraphs and numbered consecutively.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Description of the parties, the brief facts and the claim/allegation shall be contained in separate paragraphs as far as possible (O2 r2(1)).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The description of parties shall only be of relevant or material information and shall include the address for service.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>There should be a brief statement summarizing the material facts upon which the party relies for his claim. No evidence should be pled (O2 r3(1)).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The facts should disclose where course of action arose (O4 r1(1)(d).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dates, sums and other numbers shall be expressed in figures (O2 r2(2)).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Every plaint shall contain the particulars of any claim including:
a) particulars of any misrepresentation, fraud or willful default on which the plaintiff relies; and
b) where a party pleading alleges any condition of the mind of any person whether disability of mind, malice, fraudulent intention upon which party pleading relies (O2 r10(1))</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The claims may be multiple, and if so, the particulars of each claim should be included after each claim.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The claims may be in the alternative, therefore giving the plaintiff options on what claim shall be settled by the court.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>NOTE claims in the alternative cannot be settled together. The court settles the claim that has been appropriately proved and which the court deems such settlement shall justly determine the matter.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>The prayer – a request for some relief or remedy from the court.</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>It shall not be necessary to ask for general damages and costs &amp; interest thereon as the same shall be granted by the court as it thinks just (O4 r6).</li>
<li>However, every plaint shall specifically state the relief sought, either specifically or in the alternative (O4 r6).</li>
<li>There shall be as many prayers as there are claims and they should be headed to distinguish which prayer is for which claim (O4 r7)</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Statements showing proper jurisdiction and venue.
i. A statement averring the jurisdiction of the court to ensure party is aware that the court has territorial and pecuniary jurisdiction over the matter; and
ii. a statement to aver that there is no suit pending nor has there been any previously determined proceeding on the subject matter (O4 r1(f)) (cap21, s.6 – sub judice &amp; s.7 – res judicata)</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>A statement indicating that demand has been made to right the wrong but the same has not been complied with. It is necessary to evidence notice has been made to the other party of the suit.</li>
<li>NOTE the demand letter is an accompanying document as under O3 r2(d) and where it is pleaded, it should have been made.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li>The subscription and verification – the signature of the advocate filing the document, the date, and plaintiff’s statement (verifying affidavit), under penalty of perjury, that the contents of the plaint are true</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The advocate shall sign the plaint and indicate giving his address as the person who has drawn it to adhere with s.35 cap16</li>
<li>The address of the person being served should also be provided</li>
<li>A verifying affidavit sworn by the plaintiff should accompany the plaint (O4 r1(2)).</li>
<li>Ensure that the verat is contained on the same page as the signature of the plaintiff</li>
<li>The suit will commence once the plaint has been filed (O3 r1(1)).</li>
</ul>
<p>Issues for consideration</p>
<ul>
<li>Before you begin to draft any plaint you should analyze your case, determine the purpose of your pleading and outline the general content of your document. Specifically you should know:
i. Who will be named as parties and how they will be named
ii. The type of claims or causes of action that will be included in the plaint</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>iii. The type of relief you are demanding
iv. How you will show that jurisdiction and venue are proper.</p>
<ul>
<li>Only when you have done this preliminary analysis should you begin to actually draft a plaint.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="parties-to-the-lawsuit">Parties to the lawsuit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parties-to-the-lawsuit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-real-party-in-interest">1. Real Party in Interest<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-real-party-in-interest" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>The plaintiff in any lawsuit should be the one who is entitled to the relief sought in the plaint.</li>
<li>This is known as the real party in interest.</li>
<li>However, at times a special relationship exists that creates a different situation. For example, an executor may wish to sue on behalf of an estate, or a trustee may sue on behalf of a trust, or a collection agency may wish to sue on a debt assigned to it for collection.</li>
</ul>
