<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="status">Status<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#status" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Status of a party refers to the type of entity that describes the party.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Most commonly a party to a lawsuit will be an individual, a corporation, a partnership or other unincorporated business, or a governmental agency.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The status of the party will usually be described both in the caption and in a separate allegation within the body of the plaint.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Therefore: PARADISE FOUND, INC...DEFENDANT</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In addition, within the body of the plaint you would include a paragraph describing the status, such as the following: The Defendant, PARADISE FOUND, INC., is and was at all times herein mentioned a corporation duly organized and existing under the Companies Act, Cap 486 Laws of Kenya.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="capacity">Capacity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#capacity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>You also need to make certain that the parties named in the plaint have capacity, or the legal right, to sue, or be sued.</li>
<li>Children and incompetence do not have the capacity to pursue their own lawsuits.</li>
<li>Every suit by a minor shall be instituted in his name by a person who shall be called the next friend of the minor (O32 r2(1)) who shall sign a written authority to the advocate for such purpose which shall be filed (r2(2)).</li>
<li>Where the defendant is a minor, the court upon being satisfied of his minority, will appoint a guardian ad litem, defend the suit(O32 r3(1)).</li>
<li>Even the parents of a child cannot file a lawsuit on their child's behalf unless they have been appointed as guardians by the court.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>An order for the appointment of a guardian ad litem may be obtained upon application in the name or on behalf of the minor or by the plaintiff (O32 r3(2)).</li>
<li>The application is by motion or a petition supported by an affidavit verifying that proposed guardian has no interest adverse to those of the minor in the suit and that they are competent to be so appointed (O32 r3(3))</li>
<li>The following is an example of how parties would be designated in such a case.</li>
</ul>
<p>MARY MWASUDI, a minor, by GEORGE MWASUDI, her next friend...PLAINTIFF</p>
<p>Vs</p>
<p>DEF CORPORATION...DEFENDANT</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="corporations-and-other-business-entities">Corporations and Other Business Entities<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#corporations-and-other-business-entities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A corporation is a "person" for legal purposes, including lawsuits.</li>
<li>As such it has capacity to sue and be sued in the corporate name.</li>
<li>However, exceptions do occur. If the corporation fails to act like a corporation – not holding meetings, failing to keep corporate assets separate from personal assets, etc., and – then the individuals behind the corporation can be sued individually (piercing the corporate veil)</li>
<li>The directors, officers, or shareholders of a corporation will also be named individually as defendants if they have personally done something wrong.</li>
<li>An unincorporated association, such as a partnership, does not have legal existence, separate and apart from the partners.</li>
<li>It is proper, therefore, for such an organization to sue and be sued in the name of its members.</li>
<li>However, where the members claim to be partners and were carrying on business in Kenya when the cause of action arose, may sue or be sued in the firm name (O30 r1).</li>
<li>When suing a partnership or other unincorporated business entity, it is common to list both the partners' names and the business name: ABOUD ALI and MANSOUD ALI, a partnership, T/A HEARTH &amp; HOMES REAL ESTATE CO. ...DEFENDANTS</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="governmental-agencies">Governmental Agencies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#governmental-agencies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>There are limits which regulate the circumstances under which a governmental entity can be sued.</li>
<li>Even when a statute permits the government to be sued, the law requires that notice be given to a governmental agency before actually filing suit</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>In such a case it will be necessary to allege in the body of the plaint that this has been done (O.1 r.11).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="special-problems-with-parties">Special Problems with parties<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#special-problems-with-parties" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Parties using fictitious names. If a plaintiff uses a fictitious name in his business, a lawsuit that he files related to that business should identify the plaintiff by his proper name.</li>
<li>If he wishes, the plaintiff may indicate that he is doing business under another name.</li>
<li>The plaintiff would then be identified as follows:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="martin-kachumbari-t-a-kachumbari-diner-plaintiff">MARTIN KACHUMBARI, T/A KACHUMBARI DINER ...PLAINTIFF<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#martin-kachumbari-t-a-kachumbari-diner-plaintiff" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>When the defendant is doing business under a fictitious name, the true name of the party may be unknown to you when you are preparing the plaint.</li>
<li>You can undertake the requisite due diligence but you may be unable to gather accurate information.</li>
<li>It is therefore necessary to identify the defendant in the plaint by the fictitious name.</li>
<li>In such a case, when the true name of the defendant or defendants is determined, the plaint can generally be amended (O1 r9)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fictitious-defendants">Fictitious Defendants<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fictitious-defendants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This term refers to defendants whose very identity is unknown.</li>
<li>Fictitiously named defendants are commonly named in plaints to cover a situation in which a new defendant is discovered after the statute of limitations has run.</li>
<li>In such a case the advocate argues that the plaint was filed against the newly discovered defendant within the statute of limitations, he was just referred to by an incorrect name.</li>
<li>The advocate then tries to amend the plaint to "correct" the name.</li>
<li>The CPR, 2010 allows plaintiffs to name a newly discovered defendant even after the statute of limitations has run as long as the new party had received notice that the lawsuit has been filed within the time allowed for service, would not be unduly prejudiced, and knew that but for a mistake, he or she would have been named as a party in the original suit.</li>
<li>In such a case, the date of filing against the new party "relates back" to the original filing date (O1 r7, 9, 10(2)).</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="joining-multiple-parties">Joining Multiple Parties<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#joining-multiple-parties" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Joinder that is allowed but not required is known as permissive joinder; and joinder that is required is known as compulsory joinder.</li>
<li>The rules regarding permissive joinder, joinder of parties that is allowed but not required, are usually very liberal.</li>
<li>Parties are permitted to be joined together in a plaint as plaintiffs or defendants as long as there is some common question of law or fact and the claim arises out of the same occurrence or series of occurrences. (O1 r1 &amp; 3).</li>
<li>Generally, if the court cannot resolve the matter without the presence of a party, then joinder of the party is required. (O1 r10(2)).</li>
<li>Example: suppose that title to a certain piece of real property is in question, and four different individuals are claiming ownership.</li>
<li>If one of those parties files a lawsuit to determine ownership (known as quiet title action), he would have to name the other three claimants as defendants.</li>
<li>The court could not determine ownership unless all four parties were before the court. When parties are required to be joined in the lawsuit, they are sometimes referred to as indispensable parties.</li>
<li>Even when it appears that joinder of certain parties is essential to the case, if jurisdiction over one of the parties is impossible to obtain, the court may allow the matter to proceed without that party being named.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="representative-suits">Representative Suits<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#representative-suits" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>At times the number of potential plaintiffs in an action becomes too numerous to be practical.</li>
<li>When this happens, a representative suit can result.</li>
<li>A representative suit occurs when one or more parties who share a claim with a multitude of others file a lawsuit in their own names and also claim to represent numerous others in a similar situation.</li>
<li>To maintain a representative suit, the party filing the lawsuit must usually get permission from the court to proceed with the action.</li>
<li>If the court grants permission, it will also direct that all members of that class being represented get notice of the action (O1 r8(1)).</li>
<li>The parties represented must give the authority to be represented in writing and signed by the party giving authority, where after, the authority shall be filed in the case (O1 r13(2)).</li>
<li>Generally, the court also orders that all class members who can be identified should get individual notice, where practicable.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>Included in the notice to all potential members of the class is usually an explanation that any potential class member can request in writing that he or she be excluded from the class.</li>
<li>If a member does not request exclusion, that class member will be bound by any judgment in the case.(O1 r8(2)).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="self-reflection">Self-reflection<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#self-reflection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The Constitution guarantees the right to institute court proceedings claiming that a right or fundamental freedom in the Bill of Rights has been denied, violated or infringed, or is threatened. (Art.22(1))</li>
<li>Further, it guarantees the right to institute those proceedings on behalf of a group or class of persons (Art.22 (2) (b)) and in the interest of the public. (Art.22 (2) (c)).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="jurisdiction-and-venue">Jurisdiction and venue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#jurisdiction-and-venue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The plaint in any action must contain some allegation showing that the lawsuit is being filed in the proper court.</li>
<li>The jurisdiction of the courts is either territorial or pecuniary.</li>
<li>Territorial jurisdiction refers to the area to which the jurisdiction of the court extends.</li>
<li>Pecuniary jurisdiction relates to the maximum monetary value for the cases which the court is going to entertain.</li>
<li>Generally, a claim must be instituted in the court of the lowest grade competent to hear it.</li>
<li>However, where a case involves an important point of law, it may be instituted in a court other than that of the lowest grade. (s.11).</li>
<li>Suits involving immovable property must be instituted in the courts within the local limits whose jurisdiction the property is situated. (s.12)</li>
<li>In cases of personal injuries, breaches of contracts or statutory obligations they should be instituted where the cause of action arose or where the defendant resides or works for gain. (s.14).</li>
<li>Where there is more than one defendant, the suit may be filed in a court in whose jurisdiction one of the defendants resides or works.(s.15)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="claim-or-cause-of-action">Claim or cause of action<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#claim-or-cause-of-action" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>When reviewing the facts that are alleged in the plaint, the defendant's advocate and the court should be able to tell that there is a legal basis for the lawsuit, even though the legal basis need not be expressly stated in the plaint.</li>
<li>The plaint must contain sufficient facts to put the defendant on notice as to why he is being sued, this is known as notice pleading.</li>
<li>The use of more detailed allegations in a plaint may have an effect on later discovery and disclosure rights and obligations and should be carefully considered.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>Facts and not legal theories should be alleged. For example,</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example-1">Example 1:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Plaint for Specific Performance of Contract to Convey Land</strong></p>
<p>On or about December 1, 2013, plaintiff and defendant entered into an agreement in writing a copy of which is hereto annexed as Exhibit A</p>
<p>In accord with the provisions of the said agreement plaintiff tendered to the defendant the purchase price and requested a conveyance of the land, but defendant refused to accept the tender and refused to make the conveyance.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="particulars-of-breach-of-contract">Particulars of Breach of Contract<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#particulars-of-breach-of-contract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>failing to adhere to the terms of the contract</p>
<p>refusing to accept the terms of the contract</p>
<p>refusing to convey make the conveyance over to the plaintiff as according to the terms of the contract</p>
<p>Plaintiff now offers to pay the purchase price.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reasons-wherefore-plaintiff-demands">Reasons wherefore plaintiff demands<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reasons-wherefore-plaintiff-demands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The defendant be required specifically to perform said agreement,</p>
<p>Damages in the sum of Kshs.100,000, and</p>
<p>That if specific performance is not granted plaintiff have judgment against defendant in the sum of Kshs.3,500,000</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="handling-multiple-claims">Handling multiple claims<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#handling-multiple-claims" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A plaint may contain any number of causes of action or counts.</li>
<li>Whenever a cause of action arises out of the same general factual situation, the rules of pleading usually allow them to be joined in the same plaint.</li>
<li>As a general rule, if the claims provide different remedies or are proven by different facts or evidence in the case, they should probably be separated into distinct causes of action.</li>
<li>However, because the rules of pleading are so liberal, if two or more claims were combined into one cause of action, the court would either allow the pleading to stand as written or allow it to be amended.</li>
<li>A question arises when a plaint contains two inconsistent causes of action.</li>
<li>For example, consider the following situation:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="example">EXAMPLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#example" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Brian signs a contract with Dave to buy a house for Kshs.2,000,000</p>
<p>Before the time for the deal to close, Dave informs Brian that he has changed his mind and will not sell</p>
<p>As of the date of sale, the value of the house has increased to Kshs.2,200,000</p>
<p>Brian now has a choice.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>Does he want the house, or should he make Dave pay for any damages that he incurred because he did not get the house (the damages being the difference the purchase price and the fair market value at the time and place of sale).</p>
<p>If he gets the house at the original contract price, he will not have incurred the loss of profit in the house.</p>
<ul>
<li>Therefore, asking both for specific performance of the contract and for damages because it was not performed is inconsistent.</li>
<li>The rules of pleading usually allow the plaintiff to allege causes of action that are inconsistent.</li>
<li>However, the plaintiff will not get a judgment on both of them.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="handling-multiple-parties">Handling multiple parties<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#handling-multiple-parties" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Multiple plaintiffs they should be joined within the same cause of action if they have a joint claim or if they are suing for the same thing.</li>
<li>For example, where Paul &amp; Margaret Mbugua, husband and wife are suing for the same thing, i.e., the damages that they sustained in buying a non-existent plot, they are not each suing for half of the damages.</li>
<li>They are suing together for the total damages. Therefore they should be joined in the same cause of action.</li>
<li>When the plaintiffs are suing for something different, however, their claims should be in separate causes of action.</li>
<li>For example, suppose that James and Bertha Menge, husband and wife, are both injured in the same automobile accident and wish to sue the driver of the other vehicle.</li>
<li>In such a case they are suing for different things.</li>
<li>He is suing for his injuries, and she is suing for her injuries. This would therefore have two separate causes of action.</li>
<li>However, the two causes of action would be in one plaint.</li>
<li>When there is some common factual or legal basis among the various causes of action, they can be joined in one plaint.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="demand-for-relief">Demand for Relief<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#demand-for-relief" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Every plaint filed in an action contains a demand for relief from the court, often called a prayer.</li>
<li>Courts have the power to two different types of relief, money damages and equitable relief.</li>
<li>Money damage usually means the award of money to the plaintiff as compensation for some loss.</li>
<li>Equitable relief, involves the court ordering the defendant to do something or to stop doing something.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="money-damages">Money damages<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#money-damages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>These damages are known as compensatory damages as they compensate the plaintiffs for a loss they have sustained.</li>
<li>They may be referred by other names depending on the kind of suit, for example in personal injury suits they may be known as special damages – out of pocket expense, e.g., doctors bills, loss of earnings, or general damages – pain and suffering, loss of use of a limb or disfigurement caused by a scar.</li>
<li>Sometimes the money damages would be in form of punitive or exemplary damages.</li>
<li>These are meant to punish the defendant and are awarded only when the defendant has committed some extremely offensive act or that it is in the public interest that such party be so punished as the breach of right affects society.</li>
<li>In the course of the suit, the parties will inevitably incur substantial expenses, or costs.</li>
<li>These can include filing fees, process server fees, deposition fees, and expert witness fees.</li>
<li>Costs are not included in compiling the plaintiff’s damages.</li>
<li>If the plaintiff wins the lawsuit, he will generally be awarded certain costs in addition to the actual damages.</li>
<li>However, should the defendant win the case, he will be awarded his costs from the plaintiff.</li>
<li>The issue of cost is however discretionary to the court.</li>
<li>One element that is usually not included in the list of recoverable costs (unless the lawsuit is based on a contract that specifically provides for the payment thereof) are the advocate’s fees.</li>
<li>Parties are expected to pay their own advocate’s fees.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="equitable-relief">Equitable relief<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#equitable-relief" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Some legal disputes cannot be settled by an award of money damages.</li>
<li>For example, suppose Max sells Fred his business.</li>
</ul>
<p>As part of the sales agreement, Max agrees not to open a competing business within a 50km radius for a period of two years.</p>
<p>However, two months after the sale, Max opens a competing business across the street from Fred.</p>
<p>As a result, Fred’s business income substantially decreases. Although the money damages might compensate Fred for his past loss, if Max continues in business Fred will continue to lose money.</p>
<ul>
<li>Fred would therefore prefer that the court order Max to close down his competing business.</li>
<li>Such an order would be known as equitable relief.</li>
<li>A plaint may combine a request for equitable relief and money damages.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>Some of the more common types of equitable relief are:
i. Specific performance
ii. Rescission
iii. Restitution
iv. declaratory relief
v. quiet title and
vi. injunction.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="provisional-remedies">Provisional remedies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#provisional-remedies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>In most courts, substantial time elapses between the filing of a plaint and the actual trial in that case.</li>
<li>When injunctive relief is the primary object of a suit, the plaintiff often requests some immediate provisional remedy from the court as soon as a plaint is filed.</li>
<li>Provisional remedies usually include a temporary restraining order, which usually compels the defendant to stop certain conduct immediately.</li>
<li>This order will remain in effect for a very short time, usually until a hearing can be scheduled in court.</li>
<li>This hearing is for arguments from either side in support or against the TRO to remain in effect until the main trial or to be removed.</li>
<li>Should the court decide to keep the restraining order in effect, it will issue a preliminary injunction, an order remains in effect until the trial, at which time the injunction would become permanent if the plaintiff proves his case.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cases">Cases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Justus Kyalo Mutunga v. Labh Singh Harnam[2012]Eklr</p>
<p>Gachui Akothae Rengerua v Zena Salim Ahmed (Suing as the administratrix of the estate of Salim Ahemed Salem)[2012] eKLR</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="plaint">PLAINT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plaint" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This is the usual method of commencement of suits where there is a substantial dispute as to the facts.</li>
<li>It is preferable that the person institutes an ordinary suit which is normally by way of plaint.</li>
<li>The procedure is provided for under Order 4 of the Civil Procedure Rules. The suit is instituted by way of plaint which must comply with the rules contained in Orders 2 so far as applicable.</li>
<li>The main feature of the ordinary suit is the exchange between the parties of written pleadings as a result of which they join issue upon questions of fact.</li>
</ul>
<p>Every plaint must contain:</p>
<ol>
<li>Description of Court</li>
<li>Case number</li>
<li>Names of the parties</li>
<li>Description of the Plaintiff and his address of service;</li>
<li>A similar description of the Defendant including address of service</li>
<li>If it is a minor the plaint should contain a statement to that effect.</li>
<li>It should contain facts constituting cause of action</li>
<li>Facts showing that the court has jurisdiction;</li>
<li>The prayers of relief sought;</li>
<li>The amount if any</li>
<li>Value of the subject matter</li>
<li>Date of the plaint</li>
<li>Signature of the Plaintiff or his agent;</li>
<li>Whenever it is for the recovery of money precise amount must be stated;</li>
<li>Whenever your plaint refers to a document, it must have an accurate description of that item;</li>
<li>An averment that there is no other pending suit between the parties over the same subject matter in another court.</li>
</ol>
<p>Verifying Affidavit accompanying the plaint.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sample-1-plaint-negligence-as-a-result-of-an-accident">SAMPLE 1 PLAINT: NEGLIGENCE AS A RESULT OF AN ACCIDENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sample-1-plaint-negligence-as-a-result-of-an-accident" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="republic-of-kenya">REPUBLIC OF KENYA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#republic-of-kenya" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>IN THE HIGH COURT AT MERU CIVIL SUIT NO. OF 2012 ANITA WANJA M'IKIRIMA (suing as legal representative of the estate of PURITY KAGWIRIA (deceased)...PLAINTTIFF</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="versus">VERSUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#versus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>JAPHET MBAE RUTERE ...1ST DEFENDANT</p>
<p>DENNIS MWONGERA MBAE...2ND DEFENDANT</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="plaint">PLAINT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plaint" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>"Fast Track"</p>
<ol>
<li>The Plaintiff is an adult of sound mind residing and working for gain within Imenti South District and her address of service for purposes of this suit is care of; KIAUTHA ARITHI &amp; CO. ADVOCATES 1ST FLOOR, KCB BUILDING NJURI NCHEKE STREET P.O. BOX 2418-60200 MERU.</li>
<li>The 1st Defendant residing and working for gain within the Republic of Kenya and his address of service for purposes of this suit is P.O. BOX 368 - 60202, NKUBU (service to be effected through the Plaintiff's Advocates office).</li>
<li>The 2nd Defendant is a male adult of sound mind residing and working for gain within the Republic of Kenya and his address of service for purposes of this suit is P.O. BOX 368 - 60202, NKUBU (service to be effected through the Plaintiff's Advocates office).</li>
<li>At all material times relevant to this suit the 1ST Defendant was the registered owner of motor vehicle registration No. KAM 413Y Toyota saloon and the 2nd Defendant was his driver, agent, servant and/or employee.</li>
<li>On or about the 31st day of December 2008, at around 10.30 p.m. the deceased was lawfully standing off Meru - Nkubu road at Equator area when the 1st Defendant so negligently, recklessly and carelessly drove, controlled and/or managed motor vehicle registration No. KAM 413Y that he caused it to veer off the road and crush the deceased occasioning upon her fatal injuries which led to her death.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="particulars-of-negligence-of-the-2nd-defendant">PARTICULARS OF NEGLIGENCE OF THE 2ND DEFENDANT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#particulars-of-negligence-of-the-2nd-defendant" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a) Driving at a speed which was too fast in the circumstances.
b) Failing to keep any or any proper look-out or to have any or any sufficient regard for pedestrians on the said road.
c) Mounting on the pedestrian path and there colliding with the deceased.
d) Failing to exercise or to maintain any or any sufficient or adequate control of the said motor vehicle.
e) Failing to heed the presence of the deceased on the said road.
f) In the alternative driving a defective motor vehicle incapable of proper control.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>g) Failing to stop, slow down or in any other way so manage or control the said motor vehicle as to avoid mounting the said pedestrian path and there colliding with the deceased.
h) Causing the death of the deceased.</p>
<p>Where applicable the Plaintiff shall rely on the doctrine of Res Ipsa Loquitor.</p>
<ol start="6">
<li>The Plaintiff's claim is brought under the Fatal Accident Act Cap 32 Laws of Kenya and the Law Reform Act Cap 26 Laws of Kenya.</li>
<li>Particulars pursuant to the Law Reform Act. At the time of her death, the said PURITY KAGWIRIA was 25 years of age. She enjoyed good health and was living a happy and vibrant life with a normal expectation of life and by her sudden and premature death, her expectation of a healthy and happy life was considerably shortened and her said estate has suffered expenses, loss and damage.</li>
<li>Particulars pursuant to the Fatal Accidents Act
a) The Plaintiff herein instituted this suit as the legal representative of the estate of the deceased.
b) The name of the dependant for whose benefit this action is brought is;
i) ANITA WANJA M'KIRIMA - Mother
c) The nature of the claim in respect of which damages are sought is as follows.</li>
</ol>
<p>At the time of her death of the deceased was aged 25 years of age, she enjoyed good health and lived a happy and vigorous life. She was a businesswoman by profession. Her income from her cereal business brought her an income of Kshs.20,000/= per month. She had good prospects of considerable advancement in her cereal business where her annual income was likely to increase progressively from month to month out of the said income, she used part of the same to support her family who were dependants upon here and by her death they have lost the said means of support and have therefore suffered loss and damage. As a result, she suffered special damages amounting to the following;</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="particulars-of-special-damages">PARTICULARS OF SPECIAL DAMAGES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#particulars-of-special-damages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>a) Police abstract - Kshs. 200/=
b) Death certificate - Kshs. 250/=
c) Post mortem - Kshs. 2,500/=
d) Mortuary charges - Kshs. 4,800/=
e) Post mortem report - Kshs. 5,000/=
f) Funeral and burial expenses - Kshs.39,470/=
g) Legal fees in grant of letters of administration -MeruHc. Misc. Succ. No. 171/09 - Kshs.30,000/= Total - Kshs.82,220/=
9. The Plaintiff's claim against the Defendant is for general damages under both the Law Reform Act and Fatal Accidents Act, Special damages, costs and interests of the suit.
10. The 1st Defendant being the registered owner of motor vehicle registration No. KAM 413Y must have allowed, condoned and/or commissions of his driver, agent, servant and/or employee and is therefore vicariously liable for his tortious actions.
11. Despite demand and notice of intention to sue having been given, the Defendants have refused, failed, ignored and/or neglected to make good the Plaintiff's claim hence necessitating the institution of this suit.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ol start="12">
<li>There is no other suit pending or concluded between the same parties herein and over the same subject matter.</li>
<li>The cause of action arose within the jurisdiction of this Honourable court.</li>
</ol>
<p>REASONS WHEREFORE the Plaintiff prays for judgment against the Defendants jointly and severally for;</p>
<p>a) General damages under both the Law Reform Act and the Fatal Accidents Act.
b) Special damages of Kshs.82,220/=
c) Costs of this suit.
d) Interest at court rate on (a), (b) and (c) above.</p>

<p>-PLAINT-
"FAST TRACK"</p>
<ol>
<li>The Plaintiff is an adult of sound mind and understanding working for gain within the Republic of Kenya address for service for the purpose of this suit is care of Firm 2C &amp; Company Advocates, 7th Floor, Firm House, Njia Panda Road, Mtaani, Private Bag 00400, DarajaMbili.</li>
<li>The 1st Defendant is a limited liability company duly registered under the Companies Act Cap 486 of the Laws of Kenya. Service of summons for purposes of this suit shall be effected through the Plaintiff's advocate's offices aforesaid.</li>
<li>The 2nd Defendant is an adult of sound mind and understanding working for gain as a driver, servant or agent for the 1st Defendant, within the Republic of Kenya. Service of summons shall be effected through the Plaintiff's advocate's offices aforesaid.</li>
</ol>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>
<p>At all material times herein, the Plaintiff was a passenger in motor vehicle registration number KAZ 009I while the 1st Defendant was the registered owner of the said motor vehicle.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>On the 12th of December, 2012 at about 11:00 am the Plaintiff was lawfully traveling as a fare paying passenger from MwishowaLami bus stage to Biashara Market when the 2nd Defendant, in the ordinary course of his employment so carelessly, negligently and/or recklessly drove, managed and/or controlled motor vehicle registration number KAZ 009I, along the said road that it lost control, veered off the road and violently overturned.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The Plaintiff contends that the said accident was caused or substantially contributed by the sole negligence of the 2nd Defendant and the 1st Defendant is therefore vicariously liable for the Plaintiff's injuries, loss and damage.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="particulars-of-negligence">PARTICULARS OF NEGLIGENCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#particulars-of-negligence" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a. Driving at a speed, which was excessive in the circumstances.
b. Failing to apply brakes in sufficient time to avoid causing the accident.
c. Causing or permitting the motor vehicle to veer off the road.
d. Failing to stop, slow down, to swerve or in any other way so to manage or control the motor vehicle as to avoid the accident.</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>By reason of the said accident the Plaintiff sustained injuries and has suffered loss, pain and damage.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="particulars-of-injuries-pain-loss-and-suffering">PARTICULARS OF INJURIES, PAIN, LOSS AND SUFFERING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#particulars-of-injuries-pain-loss-and-suffering" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a. Fractured leg
b. Head injuries</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>The plaintiff suffered special damages.</li>
</ol>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="particulars-of-special-damages">PARTICULARS OF SPECIAL DAMAGES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#particulars-of-special-damages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>a. Medical expenses Kshs. 50,000/=
b. Medical report Kshs. 2,000/=
c. Police Abstract Kshs. 200/=
d. Taxi fare to &amp; from Kshs. 4,000/=

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="re-demand-letter">RE: DEMAND LETTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#re-demand-letter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>We have instructions from the above named Miss Everlyne Musakhu, herein after referred to as “our client,” to write to you as follows:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p><strong>That</strong> on the 12th Day of December 2012 at around 1100 hours our client was a fare paying passenger in your company van, Registration Number KAZ 009I, from Mwisho wa Lami bus stage to Biashara market to sell her merchandise.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>That</strong> as a result of negligent driving of your driver, one Dereva Hatari, your said van veered off the road at Kona Mbaya and rolled severally. Consequently, our client sustained head injuries and a fractured leg for which she was hospitalized at Matibabu Hospital for a period of six months and incurred a hug medical bill.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>That</strong> our client has not only lost her livelihood of making and selling <em>mandazis</em> since the accident, but has also been confined to the use of clutches. She suffers persistent headaches and occasional memory lapse.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>This is therefore to demand your <strong>admission of liability</strong> within seven days from the date of this letter for the shock, pain and damages suffered by our client. In case we do not hear from you, we shall seek appropriate legal redress.</p>
<p>Wakili JS (Esq.)</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>(For Firm 2C &amp; Company Advocates)</p>
<p>FIRM 2C &amp; COMPANY ADVOCATES</p>
<p>CLIENT'S INSTRUCTION SCHEDULE</p>
<p>I, MISS EVELYNE MUSAKHU National ID. N0. 21212121 of P.O. Box 333-00100 Darajambili and being a residence of Kongo slums in Darajambili market in the Republic of Kenya, do hereby issue the following instructions to Mr. Wakili of Firm 2C &amp; Co. Advocates as hereunder.</p>
<p>FACTS OF THE MATTER</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>That my mother, Mrs. Valentina Musakhu, and I eked out a living from making and selling mandazis and chapatis at Biashara market. Occasionally, we sold ripe bananas in the same market.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That on the 12th Day of December 2012 at around 00900 hours I set out on a journey to Biashara market to sell a basket full of mandazi. I had left my mother at home making chapatis which she would later bring to sell at the same market.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That upon reaching the bus stage at Mwisho wa Lami in Kongo slums, I found three other women, with whom I am familiar, waiting for a public service vehicle to Biashara market. They were also businesswomen from Kongo slums taking their merchandise to the market. They are Fatma Ali, Jirani Mwema and Mama Tuzo. This was about 0930 hours.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That we exchanged pleasantries after which Mama Tuzo informed me that there was a matatu strike. They had waited at the stage for vehicles for a long time without success.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That at around 1045 hours, a van belonging to Mataka Co. Ltd pulled up at the stage and offered to ferry us to Biashara market at the normal public service fare. By this time the number of people waiting to travel to Biashara market had increased appreciably.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That Fatma Ali, Jirani Mama, Mama Tuzo, a man who I did not know and I boarded the van. I sat in the front cabin with the driver as the rest sat in the wagon. Each of us paid the driver KSh. 100.00 as fare before he allowed us to board the van. He then drove off towards Biashara market some 20 km away.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>
<p>That after some 5 km, as we approached the Kona Mbaya bend, the driver received a phone call on his mobile phone which he returned. I heard him say; “Yes Sir, my name is Dereva Hatari.” ... I realized that the van was fast approaching the Kona Mbaya bend. I don’t know what happened next as I lost my consciousness. When I regained my senses, I was told that I was admitted in Matibabu Hospital with head injuries and a fractured leg all sustained in a road accident.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That I remained admitted at Matibabu Hospital for six months, during which time I lost my source of livelihood. I was discharged from the hospital on the 13th Day of May 2013. I have since then not fully recovered because am still on crutches and suffer a constant headache. My eyesight is also impaired and I occasionally experience memory lapses. Every fortnight I attend a follow up Clinic. This is very expensive for my mother who since the accident has lost her livelihood.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That after I regained consciousness, a police officer from Kona Mbaya Police Station visited me and took my statement on the events leading to my hospitalization.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That on discharge, my mother informed me that Fatma Ali who survived the accident without any visible injuries had reported the matter at Kona Mbaya police station.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That I am now seeking your legal assistance in the matter. Kindly advise me on the way forward.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>These instructions have been issued by I, EVELYNE MUSAKHU, this 27th day of February, 2014 to Mr. Wakili of Firm 2C &amp; Co. Advocates at the said law firm.</p>
<p>Signed ---; before ---</p>
<p>(Evelyne Musakhu)</p>
<p>(Mr. Wakili for Firm 2C &amp; Co. Advocates)</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="firm-2c-company-advocates">FIRM 2C &amp; COMPANY ADVOCATES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#firm-2c-company-advocates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="client-s-instruction-schedule">CLIENT'S INSTRUCTION SCHEDULE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#client-s-instruction-schedule" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>I, MRS. VALENTINA MUSAKHU National ID. N0. 31313131 of P.O. Box 333-00100 Darajambili and a resident of Kongo slums in Darajambili market in the Republic of Kenya, do hereby issue the following instructions to Mr. Wakili of Firm 2C &amp; Co. Advocates as hereunder.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="facts-of-the-matter">FACTS OF THE MATTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#facts-of-the-matter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>That I am a resident of Kongo slums in Darajambili market. Up and until the 12th Day of December 2012 my daughter Evelyne Musakhu and I were engaged in the business of making and selling mandazis and chapatis at Biashara market. We occasionally sold ripe bananas in the same market.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That on the 12th Day of December 2012 my daughter Evelyne Musakhu was involved in a motor traffic accident at around 1100 hours, at Kona Mbaya area while travelling in a van belonging to Mataka Co. Ltd. to Biashara market to sell a basket full of mandazi which we had baked morning. I was meant to join her later at the market to sell the chapatis which she left me baking at home.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That when I heard that she was admitted at Matibabu Hospital, I suspended my activities and rushed to the hospital on foot to see her. Matatu operators were on strike so I could not get a public service vehicle to board. I stayed in hospital for the entire six months she was admitted caring for her.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That before she was discharged from the hospital on the 13th Day of May 2013 I went to Mataka Company on the 22nd Day of April 2013 at around 0900 hours to talk to the Company Manager about the accident.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That when I reached the company gate, I was ushered in by the security guards. They directed me to the Manager's office where I narrated the story to him and asked if the company could help us with hospital bill and other expenses since my daughter was involved in an accident while in their company van.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That all of a sudden, the manager stood up shouting at me as he called the security personnel to come and throw me out of the company premises. Immediately, three security men arrived at the manager's office. They roughed me up and pushed me out of the office.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ol start="7">
<li>
<p>That on our way out one of the guards beat me up with a rungu and could not listen when his lady colleague pleaded with him; “Onyango, please do not beat her up. Allow her to leave in peace.” The security man angrily yelled at the lady: “Nyagothie, this is none of your business. Can you stick to your cleaner’s job?” He even threatened to beat up Nyagothie who had by then moved between us in a bid to restrain him from continuing to beat me up. I sustained head, neck and arm injuries.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That after Onyango threw me out of the gate I proceeded to Mataka Place police station to report the matter. I recorded a statement with the police then proceeded to Matibabu Hospital where I was treated. The doctor who attended to me completed a P3 form for me. I offset the medical bill incurred. As a result of the injuries sustained, am unable to resume my mandazi business.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That I am now seeking your legal assistance in the matter. Kindly advise me on the way forward.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>These instructions have been issued by I, VALENTINA MUSAKHU, this 27th day of February, 2014 to Mr. Wakili of Firm 2C &amp; Co. Advocates at the said law firm.</p>
<p>Signed ---; before ---</p>
<p>(Evelyne Musakhu)</p>
<p>(Mr. Wakili for Firm 2C &amp; Co. Advocates)</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="originating-summons">ORIGINATING SUMMONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#originating-summons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>An application to the court by way of O.S13</li>
<li>The most common way of approaching the court is by way of plaint.</li>
<li>The Originating Summons method is less common and is only used where the Civil Procedure Rules provide for it or some other statutes especially permit that method of approaching the court. It is a shortened version of the Plaint.</li>
<li>The method of O.S. is intended for simpler, shorter and speedier process.</li>
<li>Usually when you approach the court of O.S. there are no witnesses and evidence is by way of Affidavit.</li>
<li>The question for decision by the court is raised directly in the Summons and the Evidence is raised in the Affidavit.</li>
<li>The issues are raised in a concise manner but with sufficient particulars to enable the court identify the issues and the course of action. The remedy or relief sought is also stated clearly therein.</li>
<li>Order 37 Rule 3 It is used in cases related with agreements for sale or purchase of immovable property Order 37 Rule 3 but only in cases where the existence of the Agreement or Contract is not in dispute and also where the validity is not in dispute.</li>
<li>Order 37 Rule 4 – Summons by a mortgagee, mortgagor and others. “Any mortgagee or mortgagor, whether legal or equitable, or any person entitled to or having property subject to a legal or equitable charge, or any person having the right to foreclose or redeem any mortgage, whether legal or equitable, may take out as of course an originating summons, returnable before the judge in chambers, for such relief of the nature or kind following as may be by the summons specified, and as the circumstances of the case may require; that is to say, sale, foreclosure, delivery of possession by the mortgagor, redemption, reconveyance, delivery of possession by the mortgagee.”</li>
<li>Order 37 Rule 5 – has to do with Caveats approach the court by way of Chamber Summons if there is a pending suit in court. Anything to do with the Government Lands Act should be by O.S where there is a pending suit go with the C.S.</li>
<li>Order 37 Rule 6 Application for extension of time under the rules of Limitations Act will go by way of O.S.</li>
<li>Order 37 Rule 7 Application for Land ownership by virtue of adverse possession is made by way of O.S. When you apply for a file to be reconstructed it is also through O.S. Appendix A Forms 26 and 27.</li>
<li>Order 37 Rule 8A which provides for fixing of the cause directions by parties, the court is enjoined to list the OS for directions within 30 days.</li>
<li>Order 37 rule 9 the issue whether or not the OS should be disposed of by oral evidence is to be decided at the time of directions and not on the hearing of the summons.</li>
<li>Where directions are that the matter be heard by way viva voce evidence the provisions of Order 11 come into play.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>Originating summons can also be applied where specific legislations asks for it, e.g. application under limitation of actions, advocates act, matters of adverse possession, etc.</li>
<li>Once you have prepared one, it is filed in the same way as you file the plaint. The registrar will put in the file (O.S) at the end of the case number.</li>
<li>Within 30 days of filing, the registrar will notify the parties that it has been filed.</li>
<li>The matter will then be listed before a judge for purposes of giving further directions on the way forward.</li>
<li>There is usually no need to enter an appearance in OS matters.</li>
<li>But in some circumstances it must be responded to by way of entering appearance. For example, where there is likely to be a dispute in a matter, the parties may appear before the court to seek direction and resolution especially the party disputing.</li>
<li>Oral evidence is not required at the hearing of an OS as it is usually supported by affidavit evidence.</li>
<li>If the matter however becomes complicated, the judge can direct for further evidence to be entered either orally or further affidavits.</li>
<li>If this does not work, the judge can direct for the matter to be converted into a normal proceeding as if the matter had been began by plaint.</li>
<li>If this is directed, Or 11 of the CPR will then be applied.</li>
<li>OS is employed only where the matter is simple and straight forward.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="additional-notes">ADDITIONAL NOTES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-notes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>It is another method of commencing proceedings or suit. It is a shortened version of the Plaint.</li>
<li>The method of O.S. is intended for simpler, shorter and speedier process.</li>
<li>Order 37 sets out a number of matters that can be brought out by way of originating summons. Where a specific legislation expressly provides for the use of originating summons e.g. cap 16 and 22.</li>
<li>Usually when you approach the court of O.S. there are no witnesses and evidence is by way of Affidavit.</li>
<li>The question for decision by the court is raised directly in the Summons and the Evidence is raised in the Affidavit.</li>
<li>The issues are raised in a concise manner but with sufficient particulars to enable the court identify the issues and the course of action.</li>
<li>The remedy or relief sought is also stated clearly therein.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>Within 30 days of filing the registrar will notify the adverse parties and then place the file before the judge for directions.</li>
<li>It is responded to by entering appearance after which hearing commences.</li>
<li>Oral evidence is not required at the hearing of a suit commenced by way of originating summons. This is because an affidavit is filed together by the Originating summons however the judge may order for more evidence to be supplied either by way of further affidavit or orally. (Order 37 Rule 18).</li>
<li>It is used in cases related with agreements for sale or purchase of immovable property under Order 37 Rule 3 but only in cases where the existence of the Agreement or Contract is not in dispute and also where the validity is not in dispute.</li>
<li>If the evidence become more complex, then the court may direct that it changes to proceed in the normal way as if it had begun by way of plaint, in such a way then order 11 would apply.</li>
<li>Order 37 Rule 5 – has to do with Caveats approach the court by way of Chamber Summons if there is a pending suit in court.</li>
<li>Anything to do with the Government Lands Act should be by O.S where there is a pending suit go with the C.S.</li>
<li>Order 37 Rule 6 Application for extension of time under the rules of Limitations Act will go by way of O.S. Order 37 Rule 7 Application for Land ownership by virtue of adverse possession is made by way of O.S.</li>
<li>When you apply for a file to be reconstructed it is also through O.S.</li>
<li>Under order 37 Rule 8A which provides for fixing of the cause directions by parties, the court is enjoined to list the OS for directions within 30 days and under rule 9 the issue whether or not the OS should be disposed of by oral evidence is to be decided at the time of directions and not on the hearing of the summons.</li>
<li>Where directions are that the matter is heard by way of viva voce evidence the provisions of Order 11 come into play.</li>
</ul>
<p>Forms - Appendices A Forms 26 &amp; 27.</p>
<p><strong>Advantages</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>No contracted pleading</li>
<li>No witnesses</li>
</ol>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>It is short and speedy- questions to be formed are already set out in the OS.</li>
<li>Evidence is affidavit evidence</li>
<li>It is a quick and cheap method of proceeding</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="how-available-is-it">How available is it?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-available-is-it" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>You don't have free ended freedom. OS must be prescribed by rules i.e. you do not have absolute right to use it. The matters are prescribed by the rules, if the matter isn't under those set out by the rule then use a plaint because a plaint does not have limitation.</li>
<li>The right to proceed with originating summons must be found in the CPA or in any statute provided by law.</li>
<li>Major provisions in the CPA that prescribe the way the matters are to be by OS is under order 37 but this list isn't exhaustive, other statutes will say this matter will be with OS e.g. under the Anti-Corruption and Economic Crimes Act one uses an OS.</li>
<li>The matters listed are based on the assumption that there is 'no dispute factual matter'. If the matter is simple, short and undisputable on matters of fact then you use a plaint.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="kulsumbhai-v-abdul-hussein-1957-ea-699">Kulsumbhai v Abdul Hussein 1957 EA 699<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#kulsumbhai-v-abdul-hussein-1957-ea-699" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bring proceedings in form of OS in the determination of an estate.</p>
<p>Questions whether Wakf's Trustee created 8 years earlier whether there was failure of objectives in the will which dictator? Provided object/ purpose to provide annual feast of yanal and the feast had been stopped. Wanted to see whether the will was valid.</p>
<p>Preliminary issue arose and it is contended that OS was the wrong procedure to use i.e. the heirs or people to benefit were not clearly set up. Court upheld the preliminary objection but the court could not determine who the heirs were and the quest was if it was void the trust??and if it was to be void it wasn't an easy way to use OS and therefore the court could not use it as it was going to involve complex issues.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="wakf-commissioner-vs-munyao-pg-12-1982-1988">Wakf Commissioner Vs. Munyao pg 12(1982- 1988)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#wakf-commissioner-vs-munyao-pg-12-1982-1988" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It involved plaintiff's allegations of multi-administration failure to distribute the assets and failure to account. Therefore evidence was called thereby becoming complicated. Therefore the court ruled it is not the best way to bring the proceedings to court.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="kenya-anti-corruption-commission-v-pattni">Kenya Anti-Corruption Commission v Pattni<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#kenya-anti-corruption-commission-v-pattni" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>It's a contradiction whereby complicated matters were concerned by OS. Partnership matters where a partner has defrauded others then do not commence by way of OS. Form of OS is prescribed in Form 13A or B or Appendix B. Use the plaintiff and the defendant. Say in the matter of ... In OS is appearance is also required. (Summons to enter appearance).</p>
<p>Form 13 &amp; 13A - the summons should be inter-parties and not ex parte. A plaint is also a purpose document. Use notice of motion when the Act is silent on which document is to be used in court. Originating summons rely on affidavit evidence which must be served on the opposite party. The court also allows in some instances oral evidence to substantiate the affidavit evidence. Order 50 Rules 7. Order 50 Rule 13(1). Things like costs should not be requested for in an originating summons. Originating summons should have warnings attached to it at the end. NOTE if you do not enter appearance... It is signed by the advocate who works for the applicant or the applicant himself.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
