<ol start="4">
<li>The Petitioner is an Administrator by profession while the Respondent is a businessman in Nairobi.</li>
<li>That both the Petitioner and the Respondent are resident and domiciled in the Republic of Kenya.</li>
<li>That there have been no previous proceedings and there are no proceedings pending between the parties herein touching on the marriage herein.</li>
<li>That during the subsistence of the marriage, the Respondent has treated the Petitioner with cruelty the principle particulars of which are as follows; -</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="particulars-of-cruelty">Particulars of Cruelty<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#particulars-of-cruelty" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>a. The Respondent always comes home very late in the night without explaining where he was for the better part of the night. The Respondent has further made it a habit to spend his nights out of the matrimonial home drinking alcohol and returning home in a drunken stupor.
b. The Respondent did not offer the necessary protection to the Petitioner when the Petitioner was residing with him at a rented house in Kakamega during the post-election crisis of 2007/2008 although the Respondent knew the petitioner was Kikuyu and under imminent attack in Western Province where the parties were living.
c. The Respondent has consistently failed to pay rent on time occasioning the parties to be thrown out of the house hence causing the Petitioner and the children of the marriage undue agony and embarrassment.
d. The Respondent has consistently made irrational decisions without consulting the Petitioner who is his spouse to wit during the December 2007 General Elections the Respondents single handedly made the decision to run for a Parliamentary seat without any consultation whatsoever with the Petitioner who was his wife. Further the Respondent resigned from his employment as an Operations Officer with the World Health Organization without any consultation with the Petitioner, his wife. The Respondent made up his mind to buy land in Karen and later changed his mind to co-buy the same parcel of land with a third party without any consultations with the Petitioner.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>e. The Respondent has refused to acknowledge that the Petitioner can be a role player in the running of the family and always shrugs off the Petitioner's request that the parties sit down to discuss investment options of the family.</p>
<p>f. The Respondent has consistently failed to pay School fees for the children of the marriage on time leading to the children's send off from school on several occasions. The Respondent has on several occasions issued bounced cheques in favour of the school where the children of the marriage study occasioning the family untold embarrassment and inconvenience to the children's schooling.</p>
<p>g. The Respondent has consistently failed to meet his part of the agreement with the Petitioner that he meets school fees and rent and subsequent acquisition of a matrimonial home for the family.</p>
<p>h. The Respondent has generally failed to perform family responsibilities.</p>
<p>i. The Respondent has failed to show any concern and affection towards the children who keep asking the Petitioner "where is dad" and the Petitioner has to keep cheating them that he is in the office. The Respondent always states that loving a child is spoiling a child.</p>
<p>j. The Respondent has consistently failed to attend to the school events involving the children of the marriage.</p>
<p>k. The Respondent's conduct has psychologically affected the Petitioner causing her stress and necessitated the Petitioner to undergo stress treatment.</p>
<p>l. Respondent has insisted that he is the man of the house and often quarrels petitioner whenever Petitioner undertakes repairs at the house hence causing trauma to both the Petitioner and the children of the marriage.</p>
<p>m. The Respondent has insisted that he is not going to change from the foregoing.</p>
<p>n. The Respondent has refused to attend counseling in spite of proposals to that effect by the Petitioner.</p>
<ol start="8">
<li>
<p>That the Petitioner has not been an accessory to, connived at or condoned the Respondent's cruelty complained of in this Petition.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That this Petition is neither presented nor prosecuted in collusion with the Respondent.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That this Honourable Court has Jurisdiction to hear and determine this matter.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>REASONS WHEREFORE the Petitioner prays for: -</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>(a) That the marriage between the Petitioner and the Respondent be dissolved.
(b) An order restraining the Respondent from molesting, assaulting or otherwise harassing the Petitioner.
(c) That the Respondent be condemned to bear the costs of this cause.
(d) Any further or other relief that this Honourable Court may deem just and fit to grant to the Petitioner in the circumstances.</p>

<p>-VERIFYING AFFIDAVIT-</p>
<p>I, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX of Post Office Box Number VILLAGE MARKET NAIROBI do hereby make oath and state as follows: -</p>
<ol>
<li>That I am the Petitioner herein and hence competent to swear this Affidavit.</li>
<li>That I do hereby declare that the contents of the Petition filed herein are true to my personal knowledge.</li>
<li>That I have not been an accessory to, condoned, connived at or conduced to the Respondent's cruelty as set out in the Petition.</li>
<li>That this Petition has not been presented or prosecuted in collusion with the Respondent.</li>
<li>That there is no other suit pending in any court over the same matter.</li>
<li>That what is deponed herein is true to the best of my knowledge, information and belief save where otherwise stated.</li>
</ol>
<p>SWORN at Nairobi by the said
XXXXXXXXXXXXXX
) DEPONENT</p>

<p>SAMPLE COMPLETE PETITION-MIRACLE BABIES CASE</p>
<p>REPUBLIC OF KENYA
IN THE HIGH COURT OF KENYA AT NAIROBI
CONSTITUTIONAL PETITION NO. OF 2006</p>
<p>IN THE MATTER OF SECTIONS 60 AND 84 OF THE CONSTITUTION OF KENYA</p>
<p>AND</p>
<p>IN THE MATTER OF ALLEGED CONTRAVENTION OF FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS AND FREEDOMS UNDER SECTIONS 70 AND 79 OF THE CONSTITUTION OF KENYA</p>
<p>AND</p>
<p>IN THE MATTER OF THE CONSTITUTION OF KENYA (SUPERVISORY JURISDICTION AND PROTECTION OF FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS AND FREEDOMS OF THE INDIVIDUAL) HIGH COURT PRACTICE RULES, 2006</p>

<p>CERTIFICATE OF URGENCY</p>
<p>I, OTIENDE AMOLLO, an Advocate of the High Court of Kenya and Managing Partner in the firm of Rachier &amp; Amollo Advocates DO CERTRIFY that the Application annexed hereto is EXTREMELY URGENT on the grounds THAT:</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>The Applicant is the author of an article titled “German Couple in bid to adopt “Deya baby”” (hereinafter referred to as “the article”), which article appeared in the Wednesday Standard Edition of 28th June 2006.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That following the publication of the article by the Applicant, summons were issued in Criminal Case Number 2702 of 2004 requiring the Applicant to appear before the criminal court to testify with a view to not only disclosing the source of the information contained in the article but also clarifying to the said criminal court whether a child referred to in the article belonged to one Bishop Deya.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The fore-stated summons are not only bad in law contrary to the provisions of the Children’s Act, 2001, but also amount to an infringement of the Applicant’s right to freedom of expression as guaranteed by sections 70 and 79 of the Constitution of Kenya.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The proceedings relating to summoning of the Petitioner/Applicant in Criminal Case Number 2702 of 2004 is scheduled for the 31st August 2006 and unless this Honourable Court urgently intervenes, the Petitioner/Applicant is apprehensive that her right to freedom of expression is likely to continue to be infringed during the process.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>I certify that the annexed Application is of utmost urgency.</p>
<p>Dated at Nairobi this day of 2006.</p>
<p>RACHIER &amp; AMOLLO ADVOCATES

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="republic-of-kenya">REPUBLIC OF KENYA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#republic-of-kenya" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>IN THE HIGH COURT OF KENYA AT NAIROBI
CONSTITUTIONAL PETITION NO. OF 2006</p>
<p>IN THE MATTER OF SECTIONS 60 AND 84 OF THE CONSTITUTION OF KENYA</p>
<p>AND</p>
<p>IN THE MATTER OF ALLEGED CONTRAVENTION OF FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS
AND FREEDOMS UNDER SECTIONS 70 AND 79 OF THE CONSTITUTION OF
KENYA</p>
<p>AND</p>
<p>IN THE MATTER OF THE CONSTITUTION OF KENYA (SUPERVISORY
JURISDICTION AND PROTECTION OF FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS AND FREEDOMS
OF THE INDIVIDUAL) HIGH COURT PRACTICE RULES, 2006</p>
<p>AND</p>
<p>IN THE MATTER OF SUMMONS ISSUED TO EVERLYNE KWAMBOKA IN
CRIMINAL CASE NO. 2702 OF 2004</p>
<p>BETWEEN</p>
<p>EVERLYNE KWAMBOKA: PETITIONER</p>
<p>AND</p>
<p>ATTORNEY GENERAL: 1ST RESPONDENT
CHIEF MAGISTRATE,
CENTRAL LAW COURTS: 2ND RESPONDENT</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chamber-summons">CHAMBER SUMMONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chamber-summons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Pursuant to sections 70, 79, and 84 of the Constitution, Rules 11, 12, 20, 21 and 29 of the Constitution of Kenya (Protection of Fundamental Rights and Freedoms of the Individual) High Court Practice and Procedure Rules 2006 and Sections 3A of the Civil Procedure Act and all enabling provisions of law.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>LET ALL PARTIES CONCERNED attend the Honourable Judge in chambers on the ______ day of ______ 2006 at 9.00 O'clock in the forenoon or so soon thereafter as the Honourable Judge may direct as counsel for the Applicants may be heard on an application for ORDERS:</p>
<ol>
<li>THAT this matter be certified urgent and service of this application be dispensed with in the first instance owing to the urgency hereof.</li>
<li>THAT pending inter parties hearing of this Application, this Honourable Court be pleased to stay all the proceedings, relating in any manner whatsoever, to summoning of the Petitioner/Applicant in Criminal Case Number 2702 of 2004 to give evidence.</li>
<li>THAT pending determination of this Petition, this Honourable Court be pleased to stay all the proceedings, relating in any manner whatsoever, to summoning of the Petitioner/Applicant in Criminal Case Number 2702 of 2004 to give evidence.</li>
<li>THAT this Honourable court be pleased to issue such further order(s) as may deem just.</li>
<li>THAT the costs of this suit be awarded to the Petitioners.</li>
</ol>
<p>THIS HUMBLE APPLICATION is grounded on the following reasons:</p>
<ol>
<li>The Petitioner wrote and/or caused to be published an Article titled 'German Couple in bid to adopt "Deya baby"" (hereinafter referred to as "the article"), which article appeared in the Wednesday Standard Edition of 28th June 2006.</li>
<li>The Petitioner reported in the article, in crux, that a German couple had moved to an undisclosed court, seeking to be granted guardianship of one of Gilbert Deya's "miracle babies" (also undisclosed), a subject in an undisclosed criminal case that had not been concluded.</li>
<li>That following the publication of the article by the Petitioner, the 1st Respondent made an oral Application in Criminal Case Number 2702 of 2004 seeking for orders inter alia that the Petitioner be summoned to appear before the court and disclose the source of her article.</li>
<li>The Petitioner was accordingly summoned by the 2nd Respondent to appear before it, with a view to not only disclosing the source of her article but also clarifying to the said criminal court whether the child referred to in the subject article belonged to one Bishop Deya.</li>
</ol>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>
<p>The summons requiring the Petitioner to identify the source of her report amounted to an interference with her freedom of expression as enshrined in sections 70 and 79 of the Constitution of Kenya.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The interference with the Petitioner's freedom of expression as guaranteed by the Constitution was not within the prescription of law of sufficient precision, and thus a breach of section 79 of the constitution.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The fore-stated interference was neither reasonable nor meant to pursue a legitimate aim in the circumstances, and was thus in breach of the constitution.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Further, the subject interference is not justifiable in a democratic society where freedom of expression constitutes one of its essential foundations.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In any event, the necessity of the subject interference was not convincingly established as by law required and that the mode of interference of summoning her to reveal her source was neither relevant nor sufficient in the circumstances of the case.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Freedom of expression is one of the essential foundations of a democratic society and protection of journalistic sources is one of the basic conditions for press freedom as acknowledged in the constitution and international human rights instruments.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>WHICH APPLICATION is supported by the Affidavit of EVERLYNE KWAMBOKA annexed hereto and on such other or further grounds as may be adduced at the Hearing hereof.</p>
<p>Dated at Nairobi this day of 2006.</p>
<p>RACHIER &amp; AMOLLO ADVOCATES
ADVOCATES FOR THE APPLICANT</p>
<p>DRAWN &amp; FILED BY:</p>
<p>RACHIER &amp; AMOLLO
ADVOCATES
REINSURANCE PLAZA
7TH FLOOR, TAIFA ROAD

NAIROBI</p>

<p>IN THE HIGH COURT OF KENYA AT NAIROBI

<p>IN THE MATTER OF SECTIONS 60 AND 84 OF THE CONSTITUTION OF KENYA</p>
<p>AND</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="supporting-affidavit">SUPPORTING AFFIDAVIT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#supporting-affidavit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>I, EVERLYNE KWAMBOKA of Post Office Box Number 30080 GPO Nairobi within the Republic do hereby take oath and swear as follows:</p>
<ol>
<li>THAT I am adult female of sound mind, the Petitioner herein, fully conversant with the facts of this case and hence competent to swear this Affidavit.</li>
</ol>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>THAT I am a journalist by profession and currently working for The Standard Limited as inter alia a print media reporter.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I am the author of the article titled ‘German Couple in bid to adopt “Deya baby”’ (hereinafter referred to as “the article”), that appeared in the Wednesday Standard Newspaper Edition of 28th June 2006.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT in the article, I reported about a German couple that had moved to an undisclosed court, seeking to be granted guardianship of one of Gilbert Deya’s “miracle babies” (also undisclosed), a subject in an undisclosed criminal case that had not been concluded. Annexed hereto and marked as EK1 is a copy of the subject newspaper report.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I am informed by my counsels on record which information I verily believe to be true that following the publication of the article as contained in EK1 above, the 1st Respondent made an oral Application in Criminal Case Number 2702 of 2004 seeking for orders inter alia that I be summoned to appear before the court and disclose the source of the article. Annexed hereto and marked as EK2 is a copy of the subject summons and pleadings in the children’s cause.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I was summoned by the 2nd Respondent to appear before it, with a view to not only disclosing the source of the article but also clarifying to the said criminal court whether the child referred to in the subject article belonged to one Bishop Deya.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I am fully aware of the right to freedom of expression as enshrined in sections 70 and 79 of the Constitution of Kenya and the limitations thereon.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I verily believe that the fore-stated summons requiring me to appear in court with a view to identify the source of the journalistic information as contained in the article amount to an interference with my freedom of expression.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I am advised by my counsels on record which advise I verily believe to be true, that the limitations to enjoyment of freedom of expression as enshrined in the Constitution were not met in the circumstances of this case to warrant the interference with my freedom of expression.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT further to paragraph 9 above, I am advised by my advocates on record that the following limitations to the enjoyment of freedom of expression as duly recognized by the Constitution, are not present in the circumstances of this case.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>i. The interference is not prescribed by a specified law of sufficient precision that would have enabled me to otherwise foresee to a degree that is reasonable in the circumstances, the consequences which a given action may entail.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>ii. The interference was neither reasonable nor meant to pursue a legitimate aim in the circumstances.</p>
<p>iii. The interference is not justifiable in a democratic society where freedom of expression constitutes one of its essential foundations.</p>
<p>iv. The necessity of the subject interference was not convincingly established as by law required and that the mode of interference of summoning me to reveal the source was neither relevant nor sufficient in the circumstances of the case.</p>
<ol start="11">
<li>
<p>THAT being conscious of my human rights, I am aware that freedom of expression is one of the essential foundations of a democratic society and that the protection of journalistic sources is one of the basic conditions for press freedom as acknowledged in the constitution and international human rights instruments.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I am also well versed with the fact that without protection of journalistic sources, sources may be deterred from assisting the press in informing the public on matters of public interest thus undermining press and the public's right to information.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I am advised that the constitution being the supreme source of law the interpretation of any statutory provisions including the Evidence Act, all other statutes must be within the spirit of the Constitution.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I swear this Affidavit in support of the application for the application for conservatory orders pending hearing and determination of the Constitutional Petition in this cause.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT in the above circumstances, I pray for the reliefs sought herein.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT all that I have deposed to herein is well within my knowledge save where the same is based on information and belief sources and grounds whereof I have disclosed.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>SWORN at Nairobi by the said EVERLYINE KWAMBOKA
This day of 2006 DEPONENT</p>
<p>BEFORE ME</p>
<p>COMMISSIONER FOR OATHS</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="republic-of-kenya">REPUBLIC OF KENYA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#republic-of-kenya" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>IN THE HIGH COURT OF KENYA AT NAIROBI
CONSTITUTIONAL PETITION NO. OF 2006</p>
<p>IN THE MATTER OF SECTIONS 60 AND 84 OF THE CONSTITUTION OF KENYA</p>
<p>AND</p>
<p>IN THE MATTER OF ALLEGED CONTRAVENTION OF FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS
AND FREEDOMS UNDER SECTIONS 70 AND 79 OF THE CONSTITUTION OF
KENYA</p>
<p>AND</p>
<p>IN THE MATTER OF THE CONSTITUTION OF KENYA (SUPERVISORY
JURISDICTION AND PROTECTION OF FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS AND FREEDOMS
OF THE INDIVIDUAL) HIGH COURT PRACTICE RULES, 2006</p>
<p>AND</p>
<p>IN THE MATTER OF SUMMONS ISSUED TO EVERLYNE KWAMBOKA IN
CRIMINAL CASE NO. 2702 OF 2004</p>
<p>BETWEEN</p>
<p>EVERLYNE KWAMBOKA: PETITIONER</p>
<p>AND</p>
<p>ATTORNEY GENERAL: 1ST RESPONDENT
CHIEF MAGISTRATE,
CENTRAL LAW COURTS: 2ND RESPONDENT</p>
<p>PETITION</p>
<p>TO: THE HIGH COURT OF KENYA
NAIROBI</p>
<p>The Humble Petition of EVERLYNE KWAMBOKA of P.0 Box 30080 GPO Nairobi in the Republic of Kenya is as follows :-</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="that">THAT:-<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#that" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>The Petitioner wrote and/or caused to be published an Article titled ‘German Couple in bid to adopt “Deya baby”’ (hereinafter referred to as “the article”), which article appeared in the Wednesday Standard Edition of 28th June 2006.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The Petitioner reported in the article, in crux, that a German couple had moved to an undisclosed court, seeking to be granted guardianship of one of Gilbert Deya’s “miracle babies” (also undisclosed), a subject in an undisclosed criminal case that had not been concluded.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>That following the publication of the article by the Petitioner, the 1st Respondent made an oral Application in Criminal Case Number 2702 of 2004 seeking for orders inter alia that the Petitioner be summoned to appear before the court and disclose the source of her article.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The Petitioner was accordingly summoned by the 2nd Respondent to appear before it, with a view to not only disclosing the source of her article but also clarifying to the said criminal court whether the child referred to in the subject article belonged to one Bishop Deya.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is the Petitioner’s contention that the summons requiring her to identify the source of her report amounted to an interference with her freedom of expression as enshrined in sections 70 and 79 of the Constitution of Kenya.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The Petitioner contends and shall demonstrate that the interference with her freedom of expression as guaranteed by the Constitution was not within the prescription of law of sufficient precision, and thus a breach of section 79 of the constitution.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The Petitioner further contends that the fore-stated interference was neither reasonable nor meant to pursue a legitimate aim in the circumstances and was thus in breach of the constitution.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is the Petitioner’s contention that the subject interference is not justifiable in a democratic society where freedom of expression constitutes one of its essential foundations.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It is the Petitioner’s contention that the necessity of the subject interference was not convincingly established as by law required and that the mode of interference of summoning her to reveal her source was neither relevant nor sufficient in the circumstances of the case.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The Petitioner contends that freedom of expression is one of the essential foundations of a democratic society and that safeguards afforded to the press are of particular importance.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ol start="11">
<li>
<p>It is the Petitioner's contention that protection of journalistic sources is one of the basic conditions for press freedom as acknowledged in the constitution and international human rights instruments so that without such protection, sources may be deterred from assisting the press in informing the public on matters of public interest thus undermining press and the public's right to information.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In the above circumstances, the Petitioner contends that the interference amounted to a breach of the Constitution of Kenya and that the Constitution of the Republic of Kenya as read together with The Constitution of Kenya (Supervisory Jurisdiction and Protection of Fundamental Rights and Freedoms of the Individual) High Court Practice and Procedure Rules, 2006 make provision for redress as herein</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>YOUR PETITIONERS</strong> therefore humbly pray for Orders <strong>THAT</strong>:-</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>A Declaration that the summons issued to the Petitioner requiring her to identify the source of her report that appeared in the Wednesday Standard Edition of 28th June 2006 was in breach of Section 79 of the Kenya thus unconstitutional..</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Order that costs of this suit and damages be awarded to the Petitioner.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Any other/further order or relief that this Honourable Court may deem fit to grant.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>WHICH PETITION</strong> is grounded on the Affidavit of EVERLYNE KWAMBOKA annexed hereto and on such other or further grounds as may be adduced at the Hearing hereof.</p>
<p>Dated at Nairobi this day of 2006.</p>
<p><strong>ACHIER &amp; AMOLLO ADVOCATES</strong>
<strong>ADVOCATES FOR THE PETITIONER</strong></p>
<p><strong>DRAWN &amp; FILED BY:</strong></p>
<p>RACHIER &amp; AMOLLO
ADVOCATES
REINSURANCE PLAZA
7TH FLOOR, TAIFA ROAD
P.O. BOX 55645
NAIROBI</p>
<p>Advocates for the above named Petitioner</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="republic-of-kenya">REPUBLIC OF KENYA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#republic-of-kenya" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>IN THE HIGH COURT OF KENYA AT NAIROBI
CONSTITUTIONAL PETITION NO. OF 2006</p>
<p>IN THE MATTER OF SECTIONS 60 AND 84 OF THE CONSTITUTION OF KENYA</p>
<p>AND</p>
<p>IN THE MATTER OF ALLEGED CONTRAVENTION OF FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS
AND FREEDOMS UNDER SECTIONS 70 AND 79 OF THE CONSTITUTION OF
KENYA</p>
<p>AND</p>
<p>IN THE MATTER OF THE CONSTITUTION OF KENYA (SUPERVISORY
JURISDICTION AND PROTECTION OF FUNDAMENTAL RIGHTS AND FREEDOMS
OF THE INDIVIDUAL) HIGH COURT PRACTICE RULES, 2006</p>
<p>AND</p>
<p>IN THE MATTER OF SUMMONS ISSUED TO EVERLYNE KWAMBOKA IN
CRIMINAL CASE NO. 2702 OF 2004</p>
<p>BETWEEN</p>
<p>EVERLYNE KWAMBOKA: PETITIONER</p>
<p>AND</p>
<p>ATTORNEY GENERAL: 1ST RESPONDENT
CHIEF MAGISTRATE,
CENTRAL LAW COURTS: 2ND RESPONDENT</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="supporting-affidavit">SUPPORTING AFFIDAVIT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#supporting-affidavit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>I, EVERLYNE KWAMBOKA of Post Office Box Number 30080 GPO Nairobi within the Republic do hereby take oath and swear as follows:</p>
<ol>
<li>THAT I am adult female of sound mind, the Petitioner herein, fully conversant with the facts of this case and hence competent to swear this Affidavit.</li>
</ol>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>THAT I am a journalist by profession and currently working for The Standard Limited as inter alia a print media reporter.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I am the author of the article titled ‘German Couple in bid to adopt “Deya baby”’ (hereinafter referred to as “the article”), that appeared in the Wednesday Standard Newspaper Edition of 28th June 2006.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT in the article, I reported about a German couple that had moved to an undisclosed court, seeking to be granted guardianship of one of Gilbert Deya’s “miracle babies” (also undisclosed), a subject in an undisclosed criminal case that had not been concluded. Annexed hereto and marked as EK1 is a copy of the subject newspaper report.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I am informed by my counsels on record which information I verily believe to be true that following the publication of the article as contained in EK1 above, the 1st Respondent made an oral Application in Criminal Case Number 2702 of 2004 seeking for orders inter alia that I be summoned to appear before the court and disclose the source of the article. Annexed hereto and marked as EK2 is a copy of the subject summons and pleadings in the children’s cause.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I was summoned by the 2nd Respondent to appear before it, with a view to not only disclosing the source of the article but also clarifying to the said criminal court whether the child referred to in the subject article belonged to one Bishop Deya.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I am fully aware of the right to freedom of expression as enshrined in sections 70 and 79 of the Constitution of Kenya and the limitations thereon.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I verily believe that the fore-stated summons requiring me to appear in court with a view to identify the source of the journalistic information as contained in the article amount to an interference with my freedom of expression.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I am advised by my counsels on record which advise I verily believe to be true, that the limitations to enjoyment of freedom of expression as enshrined in the Constitution were not met in the circumstances of this case to warrant the interference with my freedom of expression.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT further to paragraph 9 above, I am advised by my advocates on record that the following limitations to the enjoyment of freedom of expression as duly recognized by the Constitution, are not present in the circumstances of this case.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>i. The interfere is not prescribed by a specified law of sufficient precision that would have enabled me to otherwise foresee to a degree that is reasonable in the circumstances, the consequences which a given action may entail.</p>
<p>ii. The interference was neither reasonable nor meant to pursue a legitimate aim in the circumstances.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>iii. The interference is not justifiable in a democratic society where freedom of expression constitutes one of its essential foundations.</p>
<p>iv. The necessity of the subject interference was not convincingly established as by law required and that the mode of interference of summoning me to reveal the source was neither relevant nor sufficient in the circumstances of the case.</p>
<ol start="11">
<li>
<p>THAT being conscious of my human rights, I am aware that freedom of expression is one of the essential foundations of a democratic society and that the protection of journalistic sources is one of the basic conditions for press freedom as acknowledged in the constitution and international human rights instruments.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I am also well versed with the fact that without protection of journalistic sources, sources may be deterred from assisting the press in informing the public on matters of public interest thus undermining press and the public's right to information.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I am advised that the constitution being the supreme source of law the interpretation of any statutory provisions including the Evidence Act, all other statutes must be within the spirit of the Constitution.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT I swear this Affidavit in support of the application for the application for conservatory orders pending hearing and determination of the Constitutional Petition in this cause.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT in the above circumstances, I pray for the reliefs sought herein.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>THAT all that I have deposed to herein is well within my knowledge save where the same is based on information and belief sources and grounds whereof I have disclosed.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>SWORN at Nairobi by the said EVERLYINE KWAMBOKA
This day of 2006 DEPONENT</p>
<p>BEFORE ME</p>
<p>COMMISSIONER FOR OATHS
THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>

<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="affidavits">AFFIDAVITS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#affidavits" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The general rule is that the manner of proving facts in a court of law is by oral evidence; however, sometimes the court may order that evidence be presented to the court by way of an Affidavit.</li>
<li>Affidavits may also be used in certain applications where the statute provides for it.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="rules-relating-to-drawing-up-of-affidavits">RULES RELATING TO DRAWING UP OF AFFIDAVITS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rules-relating-to-drawing-up-of-affidavits" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Order 19 Rule 2 provides that in instances where evidence has been given to the court by way of an affidavit, the court may either upon the application by one of the parties or on its own motion require that the Deponent of an Affidavit appears in court for cross examination.</li>
<li>Even where you are allowed by the statutes to give the evidence by way of affidavit the court reserves the right to call the deponent of the affidavit.</li>
<li>Order 19 rule 18 specifically outlaws technical or formal objections.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="contents-of-an-affidavit">CONTENTS OF AN AFFIDAVIT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#contents-of-an-affidavit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>The general rule is that the affidavit must contain facts within the deponent's personal knowledge; there is an exception to this law in interlocutory proceedings you can have facts in the affidavit that are based on information and belief.</li>
<li>If it is not interlocutory proceedings you have to seek the leave of the court if you want to include facts based on information and belief and if you include the information and belief you must quote source and information based in belief you must include the ground for belief.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="life-insurance-corporation-of-india-vs-panesar">Life Insurance Corporation of India vs. Panesar<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#life-insurance-corporation-of-india-vs-panesar" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In this case the plaintiff had sued the defendant for monies due under an insurance policy. He was asking for the money to be paid in Kenyan currency. After the Defendant had entered appearance, the plaintiff applied for summary judgment.</p>
<p>The defendant opposed application for summary judgment claiming that it had a good defence and they filed an Affidavit supporting their grounds of opposition. This Affidavit stated that 'the policies of insurance specifically provide for payment in Indian Rupees.' What happened that was that that statement was challenged. That was a fact based on information and yet the</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>source had not been stated. The statement was not defective because the source of information was the insurance policy itself. The deponent had received the source. The court said that it would have been prudent to attach the Policy Document.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="riddlesburger-case-and-caspair-v-harrycandy">Riddlesburger Case and CaspAir v. Harrycandy.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#riddlesburger-case-and-caspair-v-harrycandy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In this case the plaintiff an air pilot sued the defendant for recovery of money due to him. Thereafter the Air pilot left the country and was unable to come to the court at the time of the hearing of the case. His lawyers then applied for his evidence to be taken by way of a commission. The Affidavit supporting that application was sworn by the advocate and that affidavit contained among other things the fact that the pilot or the plaintiff was prevented by his duties at work an expense among other factors from being able to come to court to give evidence. That affidavit of the advocate was challenged for being defective. It was challenged on the grounds that the advocate did not state what he knew for a fact, what he was informed or what he believed. The Court of Appeal held that affidavit of the advocate was defective.</p>
<ul>
<li>If you are swearing an affidavit on behalf of several applicants, you must say so in the affidavit. <strong>Mwangi King'ori vs. City Council of Nairobi.</strong> If you don't indicate that your Affidavit will be found to be fatally defective. Affidavit should be in separate paragraphs so it comes out more clearly.</li>
<li>It should be dated and signed and indicate the place i.e. signed in Nairobi on this day of...</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sample-supporting-affidavit">SAMPLE -SUPPORTING AFFIDAVIT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sample-supporting-affidavit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="republic-of-kenya">REPUBLIC OF KENYA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#republic-of-kenya" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="in-the-principal-magistrates-court-at-kapsabet">IN THE PRINCIPAL MAGISTRATES COURT AT KAPSABET<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-the-principal-magistrates-court-at-kapsabet" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="kapsabet-law-courts">KAPSABET LAW COURTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#kapsabet-law-courts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="civil-suit-no-191-of-2009">CIVIL SUIT NO. 191 OF 2009<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#civil-suit-no-191-of-2009" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>SIMON MUKALANI...PLAINTIFF/APPLICANT
VS
KAPCHORUA TEA COMPANY LTD...DEFENDANT/RESPONDENT</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="supporting-affidavit">SUPPORTING AFFIDAVIT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#supporting-affidavit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I, MARK MUKALANI IGONYA residing at Malava and of Post Office Box 41280-00100, Nairobi within the Republic of Kenya do make oath and state as follows;</p>
<ol>
<li>THAT I am the brother to the Plaintiff, SIMON MUKALANI, now deceased and I have been issued with a Grant of Letters of Administration Ad Litem for his estate and hence competent to swear this Affidavit.</li>
<li>THAT the deceased died on the 7th of January 2005 as can be seen from the copy of the death certificate annexed hereto and marked “MM I 1”.</li>
<li>THAT after the death of my late brother, I went to the offices of F.E Jamal Advocate and inquired about the position of this matter and was informed, which information I verily believe to be true, that before my brother’s death this matter was pending in court and had not been finalized.</li>
<li>THAT I was further informed by F.E Jamal Advocate which information I also believe to be true that in order for the matter to continue to full hearing my late brother is to be substituted.</li>
<li>THAT I subsequently applied for and obtained a Limited Grant of Letters of Administration Ad Litem, annexed hereto and marked “MM I 2” is a copy of the Limited Grant.</li>
<li>THAT in view of the fact that I have been issued with a Grant of Letters of Administration Ad Litem for the estate of my late brother, I wish to continue with this matter and would like to substitute my late brother.</li>
<li>THAT it is in the interest of justice that the application herein be granted as it will cause no prejudice to the Defendant/Respondent.</li>
<li>THAT what is stated hereinabove is true to the best of my knowledge information and belief save where otherwise stated where sources have been disclosed.</li>
</ol>
<p>SWORN by the said MARK MUKALANI IGONYA
At Nairobi this ...day of...2011.
BEFORE ME</p>
<p>COMMISSED FOR OATHS
Drawn and Filed by:
F.E Jamal
Advocate
2nd Floor, GV Plaza,

P.O.Box 30683-00100

P.O Box 834
KAKAMEGA</p>

<p>I, JOSEPH KIRAKA of P.O. Box 1234, Nairobi, do hereby make oath and state as follows:</p>
<ol>
<li>THAT I am the Plaintiff herein and well versed with the facts of this case and therefore competent to make this Affidavit and have the authority of the 2nd Plaintiff to swear the same.</li>
<li>THAT I have read the contents of the Plaint herein and verify the contents to be true;</li>
<li>THAT there is no other suit pending in this court or at all, and that there has been no previous proceedings in any court on the same subject matter and involving the same parties herein.</li>
</ol>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="replying-affidavit">REPLYING AFFIDAVIT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#replying-affidavit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
