<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="filing-commencement-insitution-of-suits">FILING/ COMMENCEMENT/ INSITUTION OF SUITS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#filing-commencement-insitution-of-suits" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This is done by presenting to the right court registry the pleadings required for commencing the suit plus the necessary accompanying document and paying the requisite fees as set out by the court registry once assessed.</li>
<li>A case is not filed until it has been paid for.</li>
<li>Date of receipt and date of filing are not the same. Date of filing is the date the documents were paid for.</li>
<li>Some law firms circumvent this by keeping a deposit in the court, in which case the filing fees are simply deducted from the standing deposit. In this case, the filing date will be the date of receipt.</li>
<li>On the date of filing, present as many copies of the filing documents as there are defendants, including a copy for the court and one for the advocate. E.g. for 10 defendants, present 12 copies.</li>
<li>The filing must be in the right registry. The registry must be for the court with both pecuniary and territorial jurisdiction.</li>
<li>The court will allow for pleadings filed in the wrong registry to be returned and filed in the proper registry.</li>
<li>Once filed, the case is registered with a serial number in the current year. Thereafter there is issued a summons to enter appearance.</li>
<li>This is, in practice, done concurrently with the filing of the pleadings since the summons are prepared by the plaintiff.</li>
<li>The registry will put a seal on the summons then returned to the plaintiff to serve.</li>
<li>Service may be by the court or the plaintiff. The latter is faster.</li>
<li>The purpose of these summons is to allow the defendant to prepare and enter a defence.</li>
<li>This is in compliance with the rules of natural justice.</li>
<li>This makes the summons a very fundamental document. This is entitled the same way as the plaint and specifies the time within which the defendant may put in his response.</li>
<li>In fixing this time, the registry must have regard to the distance from the court to the address of the defendant as given in the plaint.</li>
<li>The time must be reasonable to allow receipt and preparation to enter defence. The validity of the summons is fixed by the Rules at 12 months.</li>
<li>The plaintiff may however seek an extension, if properly justified, from the court. The extension is for another 12 months.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="concurrent-summons">Concurrent summons<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#concurrent-summons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>One issued during the lifespan of the previous summons, where it is feared that the first may expire before the defendant is served.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>The application for renewal is ex parte. The renewed summons must be stamped by the court.</li>
<li>Service may be done by the court on payment of a prescribed fee or by an authorized process server.</li>
<li>The latter is given a geographical jurisdiction. The summons must be upon the defendant personally.</li>
<li>There are however circumstances where an agent may be served, i.e. an adult member of the family, the defendant's advocate or at the last known address of the defendant.</li>
<li>It can also be done by affixing it to the residence, or pursue substituted service, with the leave of the court, e.g. by notice in the newspapers.</li>
<li>In this case, use a paper with the largest circulation in the country and printed in an language the defendant can understand.</li>
<li>The court may also instruct the applicant to publish in more than one paper.</li>
<li>Service on the Government must be done according to the provisions of the Act, and must be served upon the Attorney General, or their registered office. After service, the process server must prepare a return/affidavit of service.</li>
<li>This document is on oath detailing the process of the service, i.e. time of service, the manner of service, the name and address of the person identifying the defendant where necessary.</li>
<li>If the defendant was known to the server, then they must state so.</li>
<li>The document must then be witnessed.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="issue-and-service-of-summons">ISSUE AND SERVICE OF SUMMONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#issue-and-service-of-summons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="issue-of-summons-is-covered-under-o-5-r-1">Issue of Summons is covered under O.5 r.1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#issue-of-summons-is-covered-under-o-5-r-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Upon filing the suit summons shall issue to the defendant to appear and answer in court.</li>
<li>The summons shall be prepared by the plaintiff or his advocate and filed with a copy of the plaint.</li>
<li>The summons shall be signed and sealed with the seal of the court by a judge or an officer designated by him within 30 days from date of filing.</li>
<li>Cognisance shall be had of the defendant's place of residence to allow him to make an appearance. However, the period shall not be less than 10 days.</li>
<li>The summons shall be collected for service within 30 days of issue or of notice of issue</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="duration-and-renewal-of-summons-r-2">Duration and renewal of summons r.2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#duration-and-renewal-of-summons-r-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Summons shall be valid initially for 12 months from the date of issue.</li>
<li>A concurrent summon shall be valid initially for the period of validity of the original summons as long as they have not expired by the time the concurrent summons are issued.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>Where the summons have not been served on the defendant, the court may extend the validity of such summons from time to time if it deems just to do so.</li>
<li>An application for extension of validity of summons shall be made by filing an affidavit of service indicating how many attempts have been made at service and their results.</li>
<li>An order may be made without advocate or plaintiff being heard.</li>
<li>If no application is made for extension of validity of summons, the court may without notice dismiss the suit upon expiry of 24 months from date of issue of original summons</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="enlargement-of-time">Enlargement of time<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#enlargement-of-time" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>So what would happen if an extension of the validity of summons was sought after the expiry of the requisite 12 or 24 months?</li>
<li>O.50 r.1.</li>
<li>Where a limited time has been fixed for doing any act or taking any proceedings under these Rules, or by summary notice or by order of the court, the court shall have power to enlarge such time upon such terms (if any) as the justice of the case may require, and such enlargement may be ordered although the application for the same is not made until after the expiration of the time appointed or allowed.</li>
<li>The court therefore has discretionary jurisdiction to enlarge the time for filing an application seeking the extension of validity of expired summons.</li>
<li>However, it is accepted in practice that a court should not exercise its discretion to enlarge time, where the claim should be barred by the limitation of statues in absence of the enlargement in time. Doyle v Kaufman (1887) 3 QBD 7</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="service-on-corporation-r-3">Service on corporation r.3<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#service-on-corporation-r-3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Service on corporations should be served on the secretary, director or principal officer of the corporation.</li>
<li>If the process server is unable to get hold of any officers of the company he can undertake service by:</li>
<li>i. leaving it at the registered office of the corporation</li>
<li>ii. by sending it by prepaid registered post or by a licensed courier service provider approved by the court to the registered postal address of the corporation, or</li>
<li>iii. by leaving it at the place where the corporation carries on business, or</li>
<li>iv. by sending it by registered post to the last known postal address of the corporation</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="delivery-or-transmission-of-summons-for-service-r-5">Delivery or transmission of summons for service r.5<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#delivery-or-transmission-of-summons-for-service-r-5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Once the summons have been issued by the court to the defendant the summons will be delivered for service –</li>
<li>i. to any person authorized by the court</li>
<li>ii. to an advocate, or advocate’s clerk approved by court</li>
<li>iii. To any subordinate court having jurisdiction in the place defendant resides</li>
<li>iv. To an officer appointed by the Police Act or AP Act</li>
<li>v. To a licensed courier service provider approved by court</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mode-of-service-r-6-7-8-11">Mode of service r.6, 7,8,11<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mode-of-service-r-6-7-8-11" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Service of summons shall be by tendering or delivering a duplicate of the summons and the recipient signs an acknowledgement on the original</li>
<li>Where there are many defendants, service shall be made on each defendant</li>
<li>Where practicable, service shall be made on defendant in person, unless he has an agent authorized to accept service – for. e.g. Advocate with instructions to accept service and enter appearance – judgement in default of appearance may be entered after this service</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mode-of-service-on-governmentr-9">Mode of service on governmentr.9<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mode-of-service-on-governmentr-9" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Service on the government shall be effected by leaving the document at the office of the AG or his designated agent or a person belonging to that office</li>
<li>By posting it in a prepaid registered envelope addressed to AG or designated agent</li>
<li>For purpose of the Rules, documents served on government in connection with civil proceedings shall not require personal service</li>
<li>Where defendant refuses service or cannot be found r.14</li>
<li>Where the serving officer, after using all due and reasonable diligence, cannot find the defendant, or any person on whom service can be made, the serving officer shall affix a copy of the summons on the outer door or some other conspicuous part of the house in which the defendant ordinarily resides or carries on business or personally works for gain, and shall then return the original to the court from which it was issued, together with an affidavit of service.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="affidavit-of-service-r-15">Affidavit of Service r.15<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#affidavit-of-service-r-15" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The serving officer in all cases in which summons has been served shall swear and annex to the original summons an affidavit of service stating the time when and the manner in which summons was served and the name and address of the person served and witnessing the delivery of summons.</li>
<li>The affidavit of service shall be in Form No 4 of Appendix A.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="substituted-service">Substituted service<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#substituted-service" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Where the court is satisfied that for any reason the summons cannot be served as under the rules of this Order, the court may on application order the summons -</li>
<li>to be served by affixing a copy thereof in some conspicuous place in the court-house,</li>
<li>and also upon some conspicuous part of the house, if any, in which the defendant is known to have last resided or carried on business or personally worked for gain</li>
<li>Instead of going through the grief of having to extend summons, one should consider the option of simply applying through Order 5, rule 17(4) for substituted service by advertisement as under Form 5 Appendix A</li>
<li>The procedure need not be expensive as the full title of the court case need not be included</li>
<li>Use the following format:</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="substituted-service-by-advertisement">SUBSTITUTED SERVICE BY ADVERTISEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#substituted-service-by-advertisement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(O. 5 r. 17)</p>
<p>To Jameson Walker</p>
<p>P. O. Box 53H8, 00700 Nairobi</p>
<p>Take notice that a plaint has been filed in the Milimani High Court at Nairobi in civil suit no. 123456 of 2013 in which you are named as the defendant. Service of summons to you has been ordered by means of this advertisement. A copy of the summons and plaint may be obtained at the court at P. O. Box 48010-00100 Nairobi.</p>
<p>And further take notice that unless you enter an appearance within 21 days the case will be heard in your absence.</p>
<p>GM Advocates</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="service-out-of-kenya-r-21">Service out of Kenya r.21<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#service-out-of-kenya-r-21" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This will be allowed by the court where:
i. The subject-matter of the suit is immovable property situate in Kenya</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>ii. Where any act, deed, will or contract involving immovable property situate in Kenya needs to be construed, rectified, set aside or enforced in the suit</p>
<p>iii. Any relief is sought against a person domiciled or ordinarily resident in Kenya</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The suit is for settlement of the estate of a deceased whom at the time of his death was domiciled in Kenya, or for the execution of trusts where the person to be served is a trustee and it is executed according to Kenyan law.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Where the suit is in respect to a contract which is:
i. made in Kenya
ii. made by or through an agent residing or trading in Kenya, on behalf of a principal trading or residing outside Kenya
iii. governed by the Laws of Kenya
iv. which provides that the courts of Kenya have jurisdiction to hear and determine suit on the contract</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Suit is founded on a tort committed in Kenya</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>An injunction is sought to be done in Kenya, a nuisance to be prevented in Kenya with or without damages being sought</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Where a person residing out of Kenya is a necessary party to a suit brought against a party served in Kenya</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="application-for-leave-to-serve-out-of-kenya-r-25">Application for leave to serve out of Kenya r.25<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#application-for-leave-to-serve-out-of-kenya-r-25" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Application to be supported by an affidavit or evidence, stating that the deponent believes that the plaintiff has a good cause of action</li>
<li>It should also state in what place the defendant is or will probably be found</li>
<li>Or whether the person is a Commonwealth citizen or a British protected person or not</li>
<li>And the grounds on which the application is made</li>
<li>It appears to the court that the case is a proper one to serve out of Kenya</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="service-out-of-kenya">Service out of Kenya<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#service-out-of-kenya" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Where the person is Commonwealth citizen, service will be served in the manner Court directs, r.27</li>
<li>Notice of summons shall be served upon a person who is not a Commonwealth citizen and shall be as in Form No. 6, Appendix A, r.28</li>
<li>r.29</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>The notice shall be sealed with the seal of the High Court of Kenya and shall be forwarded by the Registrar to the Cabinet Secretary in charge of Foreign affairs together with a copy translated in the language of the country in which service is to be effected with a request for further transmission of the notice through the diplomatic channel to the Government of the country in which leave to serve notice of summons has been effected; request to be in Form 7, Appendix A</li>
<li>An Official Certificate or a declaration upon oath transmitted through diplomatic channels from the government or court of the foreign country to the High Court will be evidence of service of notice of summons to the defendant</li>
<li>If it declares that efforts to serve notice of summons have been without effect, through an ex parte application by the plaintiff to the court, it may order for substituted service of notice as in Form 9 Appendix A</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cases">Cases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Justus Nyaribo v Clerk to Nyamira County Assembly [2013] eKLR Petition Case No. 2 of 2013 (it would be an absurdity if a person duly appears in court and then seeks an order declaring that the summons has not been duly served on them)</li>
<li>Rose Florence Wanjiru v Standard Chartered Bank of Kenya Limited &amp; 2 others [2014] eKLR</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="general-rules-relating-to-service-of-summons">GENERAL RULES RELATING TO SERVICE OF SUMMONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#general-rules-relating-to-service-of-summons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Provisions of Order 5 of the Civil Procedure Rules govern the service of summons.</li>
<li>It provides the procedure through which a party maybe informed that a suit has been instituted against them.</li>
<li>They are asked to defend themselves and failure to appear in court and defend them could result in judgment being made against them.</li>
<li>No man shall be condemned unheard is the principle being upheld. This principle is guarded by the courts and against abuse because a person can say that if a man will not be condemned until they are heard they can decide not to appear in court so the rules guard against this abuse.</li>
<li>Once you have prepared your plaint you can now take it to court for presentation. You take it to the registry; pay the filing fees, the plaint will be stamped and the case will be given a case number.</li>
<li>After that the court will embark on the process of preparing the summons, which will be served upon the defendant.</li>
<li>In practice it is not the court that prepares the summons you just extract the standard format and the lawyer does this.</li>
<li>Under Order 5 rule 1(1) the summons must be signed and sealed within 30 days from the date of filing of the suit and shall be collected within 30 days of issue or notification whichever is later, failing which the suit abates.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>Once the summons has been prepared the deputy registrar or the chief executive of that court will sign them.</li>
<li>Once the plaintiff already has filed and they also have the summons, it is up to them to have them served upon the defendant at this stage.</li>
<li>Normally the service will be done by an authorised process server, or by the court itself, which is rare, or through the advocate’s offices where parties are represented.</li>
<li>In practice the advocates will have a clerk who doubles up as a process server.</li>
<li>Once you obtain summons from the court, they are valid for 12 months beginning from the date it is issued and after that they expire.</li>
<li>In situations where you attempt to serve a person and you cannot get them in 12 months you apply to the court for an extension.</li>
<li>You will apply to the court by way of Chamber Summons accompanied by an Affidavit indicating the difficulty or the various attempts that you have tried to serve. If you don’t serve and don’t seek an extension after 12 months and you don’t validate it your suit will be dismissed after 24 months.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ways-of-effecting-service">WAYS OF EFFECTING SERVICE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ways-of-effecting-service" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-personal-service">a) Personal Service<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-personal-service" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>It is a requirement under Order 5 Rule 8 that service of sermon must be effected on the defendant personally or on their authorised agent. An advocate is deemed as an agent.</li>
<li>Under Order 5 rule 12 it is an express requirement that for service to be made on agents or adult member of the family, a reasonable number of attempts must have been made.</li>
<li>In the Elkanah Case the court was asked to rule on whether it was sufficient to leave a Hearing Notice on the only address furnished by the defendant. Was that advocate an authorised agent? The court held that yes if you effect service on an advocate whose address was left behind by the defendant then that service is deemed to be good service.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-instances-where-there-are-many-defendants">b) Instances Where There Are Many Defendants<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-instances-where-there-are-many-defendants" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>What happens when there are many defendants, the same rule applies. You have to serve each and every one of those defendants separately.</li>
<li>You cannot serve one defendant on behalf of the others.</li>
<li>If the many defendants have a common advocate, then you can serve the advocate. Order 5 Rule 8</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>c) When The Defendant Cannot Be Found</p>
<ul>
<li>What do you do when the defendant cannot be found? The person serving must make all diligent effort to find the defendant.</li>
<li>Once they have exhausted that, then they can now leave it with someone else e.g. you can leave it with the wife/husband if you go to their house, you can leave it with an adult person.</li>
<li>(Order 5 Rule 12) in their place of residence or place of work</li>
<li>See Waweru Case</li>
</ul>
<p>In this case the defendant applied to have an ex parte judgment set aside on the ground that the Plaint and the Sermons were not served or were not properly served.</p>
<p>In assessing this case and coming up with a decision, the court looked at the Return of Service and the Supporting Affidavit sworn by the Process Server. The procedure is usually once the process server has served the defendant he signs an affidavit narrating the circumstances of how he served the defendant. In Waweru the process server in their affidavit never stated the fact that they had bothered to make an inquiry as to the whereabouts of the defendant. What he only said in his affidavit was that he left the sermons with the defendant's wife telling her that she should keep them until the husband returns. The court held that since no inquiry as to the whereabouts of the defendant was made, it could not be said that the defendant could not be found so as to allow service to be effected on the wife. The case looks at the meaning of 'the defendant cannot be found' within the meaning of Order 5 Rule 12.</p>
<ul>
<li>See also Elkanah</li>
</ul>
<p>In Elkanah, this case was similar to Waweru, the affidavit of the process server stated that the defendant could not be found and therefore service had been effected on the wife. It later transpired at the application to set aside the judgment that the defendant was actually in India at the time. The court held that that does not fall within the meaning of Rule 12 because if the process server had made all diligent effort and inquiry as to where the defendant was, he would have known that the Defendant was in India. There is actually a way of serving a person who is outside the jurisdiction of the court.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>Apart from leaving it with an adult member or with a spouse, you can also serve a person by affixing the sermons on the door of their residence or their place of work. (O. 5. r 14). The court interpreted the conditions under which you can serve by affixing on the door. In Elkanah the process server accompanied by the agent of the plaintiff visited the residence of the defendant to serve sermons and when they got there they did not find the defendant. What they did is affix the sermons on the door of the house and the process server swore an affidavit to the effect that the defendant could not be found and they had put it on the door as a result. Subsequently, judgment was entered and the defendant applied to have the judgement set aside on the ground that it was not true that the defendant could not be found and the circumstances were such that it did not justify service by affixing on the door. This issue went all the way to the court of appeal.</p>
<p>The court of Appeal set out the conditions that justify affixing on the door and it stated that “that before a process server can validly effect service by affixing a copy of the sermons on a door, he must by virtue of Order 5 Rule 14 of the Civil Procedure Rules first use all due and reasonable diligence to find the defendant or any of the persons mentioned in Rule 9, 11 and 12. And it is only when all this has been exhausted and none of the other persons are available that then service can be effected by affixing on the door. The court went further to say that when you do that, the full particulars of the premises should be indicated in the affidavit of service”.</p>
<p>The second rule that the court established was that service by affixing on the door is wholly ineffective if the Affidavit of Service does not show or establish that all due and reasonable diligence has been used in attempting to find a Defendant and other authorised persons.</p>
<p>d) Where The Defendant Is The Government</p>
<ul>
<li>It is prudent for the plaintiff if the government is the defendant to acquaint themselves with the provisions of the Government Proceedings Act.</li>
<li>The Act makes pertinent requirements, which must be followed if the government is a party.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>The Civil Procedure Rules outlines the procedure for serving the government when they are a defendant.</li>
<li>The Attorney General being the government legal adviser is mandated to receive all legal service where the government is a party; you can serve the AG personally or deliver the summons to the offices that he occupies in his legal capacity.</li>
<li>You can also serve an agent of the Attorney General. In normal practice the Attorney General has mandated personnel who can receive services on his behalf.</li>
<li>You can also serve the AG by registered mail and the time within which delivery should be effected should be same as that or ordinary post.</li>
</ul>
<p>e) When the Defendant Is A Corporate Or Company</p>
<ul>
<li>The accepted practice is to serve the company secretary, a director or any principal officer of the company. When serving the principal officer one must take full particulars of the officers and indicate it in the affidavit. If you cannot find any of these persons then you can effect a service by way of registered post to the last known available address of the corporation you can look this up in the company registry.</li>
<li>Under Order 5 rule 3(b) (iii) (in case of corporations) and 5(1) (e) summons may be served by licensed couriers.</li>
</ul>
<p>f) When the Defendant Is A Prisoner Or A Person In Custody</p>
<ul>
<li>Where the defendant is confined in a prison, service on prisoners to be effected on them in the presence of the officer in charge and not to be sent to the officer for service¹ Order 5 rule 18 now requires (SUBSTITUTED SERVICE (O. 5. r. 17)</li>
<li>Suppose all other situations fail and you cannot trace the defendant and they don't have an authorised agent or colleagues they work with that you can leave with the sermons a person cannot completely be traced. The Act provides another type of service called substituted service.</li>
<li>Substituted service can only be resorted to after you have made an application to the court and the court has granted you an order for substituted service.</li>
</ul>
<p>¹Order 5, rule 18.</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>In that order the court can allow you to serve by putting the sermons in the court notice board or a conspicuous part of the court house or any other building that the defendant could be found or the last place that they worked.</li>
<li>The second way is that the court can order that service be effected by way of advertisement.</li>
<li>The advert must conform to Form No. 5 of Appendix A. Service by way of advertising is better. You make the application by way of Chamber Summons supported by an Affidavit.</li>
</ul>
<p>g) When the Defendant Is A Foreigner</p>
<ul>
<li>If you read Order 5 Rule 21 the High Court has jurisdiction to order service on any person provided the course of action arose in Kenya. Service can also be ordered by the High Court anywhere in the commonwealth.</li>
<li>You can serve a foreigner within Kenya provided the course of action against them arose in Kenya and if the foreigners are lawfully in Kenya and on their own volition.</li>
<li>See Riddlesbarger Case</li>
</ul>
<p>Where the court was saying what it means for a person to be voluntarily within the jurisdiction of the court for the purpose of service. In this case the person served was on transit in Kenya. The argument was; was it proper service to serve them on transit at the airport. The person was a shareholder of a company that was registered in Kenya and therefore the defendant was in Kenya voluntarily.</p>
<p>h) When Person Resides Outside The Jurisdiction Of The Court</p>
<ul>
<li>In such a case you can serve them outside jurisdiction only after the Court grants you permission to do so.</li>
<li>You will apply to the court for leave to serve outside the jurisdiction of the court.</li>
<li>Application is by way of Chamber Summons supported by an Affidavit.</li>
<li>Normally you will tell the court the mode of service that you want to use.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="return-of-service">RETURN OF SERVICE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#return-of-service" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Contents of the return of service will indicate
i. Mode of service used;
ii. Time of actual service;
iii. Manner in which the service was effected;
iv. Name and address of the person identifying whomever you are serving.
v. witness of receipt of summons</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What happens if you fail to make a return of service? If you fail to make a return of service one can challenge the validity of the service and they may apply to set aside the judgment.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>M B Automobiles Case. A failure to file a return of service is tantamount to no service at all.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Karatina Garments Ltd V. Nyanarua Cc 667 [1975] Klr 1976 :Under Order 10 rule 3 failure to serve either a memorandum of appearance or defence within the prescribed time may lead to any of those documents being struck out either by the court or on application hence the necessity to file affidavit of service.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="entering-appearance">ENTERING APPEARANCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#entering-appearance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>This is filing a formal document which simply states that 'Please enter appearance for the defendant' - this should be filed in court.</li>
<li>It shall be affected by delivering or posting to the relevant officer a Memorandum of Appearance on Form No 12 Appendix A.</li>
<li>In Kenya it is not the actual formal appearance. It is filed within the prescribed time as stated in the summons to enter appearance. In the memorandum specify the correct names and address of service.</li>
<li>One can enter appearance by himself/herself or by his/her advocate.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types-of-appearance">Types of Appearance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-appearance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>a) As prescribed by the rules
b) As a matter of practice</p>
<ul>
<li>Unconditional appearance/ General (Form 25 App A)</li>
<li>Conditional appearance</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>a) Unconditional Appearance / General</p>
<ul>
<li>It is where the defendant does not dispute the jurisdiction of the court and the defendant is willing to comply.</li>
<li>Is an acknowledgement that the plaintiff has served the plaint and summons to entree appearance upon the defendant (an acknowledgment of service or notice of intention to defend)</li>
</ul>
<p>b) Conditional appearance</p>
<ul>
<li>The defendant is challenging the jurisdiction of the court or the defendant is wrongly sued (misjoinder).</li>
<li>The defendant reserves the right to seek the setting aside of the plaintiff striking it out as a first step. Conditional appearance is to avoid the consequences of non-appearance.</li>
<li>Order 1 Rule 13(1) the defendant may enter appearance on behalf of others upon authorization in writing.</li>
<li>Pursuant to order 30 the general rule is that every individual partner should enter appearance.</li>
<li>If a partner disputes the existence of a partnership, then he should not raise the liability the liability of the partnership in defence because he is not authorized to speak on behalf of the partnership.</li>
<li>Under Order 6 rule 2(3) appearance is to be served within seven days of appearance and affidavit of service filed.</li>
<li>Rule 6 provides that documents may either be delivered by hand or by approved licensed courier service provider (these are only documents under this order).</li>
<li>If a dispute arises as delivery a certificate of posting or other form of proof of service is to be filed.</li>
<li>Note, that a defence may be treated as appearance under Order 6 rule 3 if it contains the necessary particulars.</li>
</ul>
<p>Multiple defendants</p>
<ul>
<li>Where there is more than one defendant, one of the defendants may be authorized to enter appearance on behalf of him/herself and the others, provided that the others have made the authorization expressly in writing.</li>
</ul>
<p>Partners</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<ul>
<li>Every individual partner should enter appearance. This does not mean that each should enter a separate memorandum of appearance.</li>
<li>They may enter one memorandum of appearance, provided that the names of those partners entering appearance are set out in that memorandum.</li>
<li>The partners are free to enter any of the two methods of appearance. If one of them enters a conditional appearance denying the existence of the partnership, then they are estopped from entering a defence on the liability of the partnership in future.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="consequences-of-non-appearance">CONSEQUENCES OF NON-APPEARANCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#consequences-of-non-appearance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>In case the claim is for a liquidated demand the plaintiff will apply for judgement against the defendant.</li>
<li>Failure to enter appearance is in this situation interpreted as an admission of claim by the defendant hence no need for trial.</li>
<li>Application is by way of a letter to the registrar.</li>
<li>The defendant having been duly served and having failed to enter appearance, kindly enter judgement for the plaintiff herein against the defendant who has failed to enter appearance for the sum of Kshs...</li>
<li>Thereafter the court will check whether the defendant was served and a return of service filed. It will then enter final judgment and the plaintiff can extract a decree to fulfil that judgment.</li>
<li>On the other hand where the claim is for an unliquidated demand the court will assess how much will be awarded to the plaintiff. The court will enter interlocutory judgment against the defendant.</li>
<li>After interlocutory judgment the case is set down for assessment of damages. At the hearing for assessment the plaintiff adduces evidence to court to assist it reach the appropriate amount for compensation. Only evidence relating to the quantum is to be adduced e.g. the injuries suffered.</li>
<li>A judgment entered in default of appearance may be set aside on good grounds by the defendant e.g.</li>
</ul>
<p>i. The defendant hadn't been properly served
ii. Service was done too late in the circumstances
iii. It was not reasonably practicable to respond</p>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<p>iv. The defendant was hospitalised</p>
<ul>
<li>Where there was no service judgment will be set aside automatically.</li>
</ul>
<p>Consequences of non-appearance
Entering an appearance is mandatory.</p>
<ul>
<li>Where there is a liquidated claim and there is non-appearance, the plaintiff is entitled to ask for judgment for that sum with interest.</li>
<li>This is because the defendant is deemed to have admitted the claim.26 Here, the plaintiff need not make a formal application to court, they may simply write to the Registrar attaching the affidavit (return) of service (Form 13 Appendix A).</li>
<li>Upon the registry receiving the application, the registry will verify by cross checking on the file whether there was due service.</li>
<li>If the registrar establishes that there was proper service and the time has elapsed, the court will then enter judgment. If it was in regard to a liquidated claim, the judgment will be final.</li>
<li>This judgment is referred to as a default judgment/ judgment in default of entering appearance. Where it is for an unliquidated claim, e.g. in matters of trespass, if the defendant does not enter appearance, the court will enter an interlocutory judgment.</li>
<li>This judgment determines that the defendant is liable and is therefore entered to in finalizing the issue of liability.</li>
<li>Questions of injury or loss are therefore no longer in issue. The remaining issue is therefore what the plaintiff is entitled to. The judgment is not final.</li>
<li>After it is entered, the suit is then set down for assessment of damages. The process is therefore two pronged;</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>Interlocutory judgment</li>
<li>Assessment of damages</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>The assessment is done in the form of a hearing where the plaintiff is to adduce evidence to assist the court to reach a fair amount in compensation.</li>
<li>This in only evidence that relates to the quantum, i.e. evidence regarding what loss or injury the plaintiff suffered, how much they spent and how much they are liable to spend in future to mitigate the loss. At this stage, evidence to do with liability is no longer admitted. Liability is no longer in issue.</li>
</ul>
<p>NB:
If entering a default judgment against the government, you must seek the court.</p>
<ul>
<li>A judgment entered in default of appearance may however be set aside on good cause shown to the court.</li>
<li>The defendant may apply to the court to have it set aside with good cause. One of the grounds is that he defendant had not been properly served, or was served too late. Where there was no service, the setting aside was automatic.</li>
<li>An appearance is made by the advocate on behalf of the defendant. The defendant is however entitled to enter appearance by themselves.</li>
</ul>
<p>THESE NOTES HAVE BEEN COMPILED BY JOSEPH MCDONALD.</p>
<p>ATP 100-CIVIL LITIGATION</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="sample-memorandum-of-appearance">SAMPLE: MEMORANDUM OF APPEARANCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sample-memorandum-of-appearance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
